('96', 1, 8, 10, 1389) July 7, 1947 Are all the Bal Mandirs which are coming up these days worthy of the name?
('96', 1, 8, 11, 1477) This is a question to be considered by all who are interested in children’s.
('96', 1, 8, 12, 1554) education.
('96', 1, 8, 13, 1565) The country needs good facilities for children’s education as much as it needs food, cloth and houses to meet its physical needs, for its future depends on the children.
('96', 1, 8, 14, 1735) [From Gujarati]
('96', 1, 9, 15, 1751) Bihar Pachhi Dilhi, p.

('96', 1, 10, 18, 2224) How long a state of affairs like this can last, it is not easy for me to say.

('96', 8, 4, 10, 11511) 19. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 8, 5, 11, 11540) NEW DELHI, July 7, 1947
('96', 8, 6, 12, 11564) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Last evening I told you why it was that the prospect of freedom that is about to be ours did not fill me with joy.
('96', 8, 6, 13, 11701) Today I wish to tell you how you can turn a bad thing into a good thing.
('96', 8, 6, 14, 11774) What has happened has happened.
('96', 8, 6, 15, 11806) Nothing is to be gained by brooding over it or blaming others.
('96', 8, 6, 16, 11869) In legal terms it will be only a few days before freedom comes into effect.
('96', 8, 6, 17, 11945) All the parties have arrived at an agreement and they cannot go back upon their word.
('96', 8, 6, 18, 12031) Only God an undo what man has decided to do.
('96', 8, 6, 19, 12076) The easiest way would be for the Congress and the League to come to an understanding without the intervention or the help of the Viceroy.
('96', 8, 6, 20, 12214) In this the League would have to take the first step.
('96', 8, 6, 21, 12268) I do not in the least imply by this that the decision about Pakistan should be undone.
('96', 8, 6, 22, 12355) It should be taken as final, no more open to discussion now.
('96', 8, 6, 23, 12416) But if ten representatives of either party sit together in a mud hut and resolve that they will not leave the hut till they have arrived at an understanding, then I can say that the decision they arrive at will be a thousand times better than the present Bill which is before the British Parliament and which envisages the setting up of two Dominions.
('96', 8, 6, 24, 12768) If all the Hindus and Muslims who come to see me or write to me do not
('96', 8, 7, 25, 12839) 1 This was addressed to a member of Bihar Harijan Uddharak Mandal who came to see Gandhiji.
('96', 9, 0, 1, 12931) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 9, 1, 2, 12972) deceive me, then it is clear that no one is happy with the division of India.
('96', 9, 1, 3, 13050) They all accept it against their will.
('96', 9, 1, 4, 13089) There is also another method, perhaps as difficult.
('96', 9, 1, 5, 13141) The army is going to be divided—the army which so far had one single purpose— whatever that purpose might have been.
('96', 9, 1, 6, 13258) This division of the army certainly fills the heart of every patriot with fear and misgivings.
('96', 9, 1, 7, 13353) Why are two armies being created?
('96', 9, 1, 8, 13387) Are they to defend the country against foreign aggression or are they to fight against each other and prove to the world that we are good only for fighting and killing each other?
('96', 9, 1, 9, 13567) I have deliberately painted before you this frightful picture so that you may be warned.
('96', 9, 1, 10, 13656) The way to escape this is, at any rate in my view, attractive.
('96', 9, 1, 11, 13719) Will the Hindu masses and all those who have taken part in the struggle for freedom pass the test today?
('96', 9, 1, 12, 13824) Will they rise up and say that they have no need for an army or at least take a pledge that this army will not be used against their Muslim brethren whether they be living in India or Pakistan.
('96', 9, 1, 13, 14018) By saying this they will turn their thirty year old weakness into strength.
('96', 9, 1, 14, 14094) Maybe the method I suggest will be considered foolish.
('96', 9, 1, 15, 14149) However, I must say that God has the power to turn foolishness into wisdom as He has done so many times in history.
('96', 9, 1, 16, 14265) Those who have set out on the dangerous course of dividing the army should pay heed to what I say.
('96', 9, 1, 17, 14364) [From Hindi]
('96', 9, 2, 18, 14377) Prarthana Pravachan–I, pp.

('96', 10, 1, 2, 14865) 21. DISCUSSION WITH DR.
('96', 10, 1, 3, 14889) SUSHILA NAYAR AND ARUNA ASAF ALI
('96', 10, 2, 4, 14922) NEW DELHI, July 8, 1947 God has chastised me severely.
('96', 10, 2, 5, 14977) I have not known a test more severe than this.
('96', 10, 2, 6, 15024) What a high standard of morality we had when we were slaves.
('96', 10, 2, 7, 15085) We are about to suffer the greatest fall from that lofty height in the so called “priceless freedom” which is approaching.
('96', 10, 2, 8, 15208) What more is left to be witnessed now?
('96', 10, 2, 9, 15247) How can I give you any idea of what is going on in my mind?
('96', 10, 2, 10, 15307) At one time I feel that Bihar is calling me, at another time I hear the call from Noakhali where I succeed to some extent in establishing peace.
('96', 10, 2, 11, 15452) When I came here from Patna a month ago, I imagined that I would be back at my work in a week.
('96', 10, 2, 12, 15547) But in the course of this one month so many changes have taken place in the country that a family wouldn’t have seen as many in a generation.
('96', 10, 2, 13, 15689) I am rotting in Delhi.

('96', 18, 3, 19, 31081) Others quietly part with money.

('96', 23, 1, 2, 37873) 40. INTERVIEW TO ARTHUR MOORE 1
('96', 23, 2, 3, 37905) July 10, 1947
('96', 23, 3, 4, 37919) It does not look like success so far.
('96', 23, 3, 5, 37957) 2 But there must be some result.
('96', 23, 4, 6, 37990) GANDHIJI: I have no doubt about it.
('96', 23, 5, 7, 38026) It depends upon you, Gandhiji.
('96', 23, 5, 8, 38057) You are the biggest force.
('96', 23, 5, 9, 38084) I am a spent bullet.
('96', 23, 6, 10, 38105) Oh, no; you are not.
('96', 23, 6, 11, 38126) Whatever progress India has made is because of you.
('96', 23, 6, 12, 38178) 3 Now is the time.
('96', 23, 6, 13, 38197) What can be done?
('96', 23, 6, 14, 38215) That is the grace of God.
('96', 23, 6, 15, 38241) I am only an instrument.
('96', 23, 6, 16, 38266) Without His will not even a leaf will move.
('96', 23, 6, 17, 38310) Then who am I?
('96', 23, 6, 18, 38325) An insignificant being.
('96', 23, 6, 19, 38349) Pray that Indians may become wise.
('96', 23, 7, 20, 38384) Your word counts.
('96', 23, 7, 21, 38402) Just now Hindus are worked up .
('96', 23, 7, 22, 38434) It is that feeling that one wants to allay.
('96', 23, 7, 23, 38478) I am doing my utmost.
('96', 23, 7, 24, 38500) Personally I do not think this mood will stay.
('96', 23, 8, 25, 38547) Mr. Moore thought Sardar Patel’s attitude to be bellicose.
('96', 23, 8, 26, 38606) Gandhiji corrected him: You do not know the Sardar.
('96', 23, 8, 27, 38658) He is not vindictive or communal.
('96', 23, 8, 28, 38692) But he does not share my belief that non violence can conquer everything.
('96', 23, 8, 29, 38766) He used to be a whole hogger once.
('96', 23, 8, 30, 38801) He is so no more.
('96', 23, 9, 31, 38819) The Sardar is the most popular leader.
('96', 23, 9, 32, 38858) Perhaps that explains it.
('96', 23, 9, 33, 38884) No, the Sardar is the strong man.
('96', 23, 9, 34, 38918) He will not let any difficulty baffle him.
('96', 23, 9, 35, 38961) That is the explanation.
('96', 23, 10, 36, 38986) There is a growing feeling of retaliation in the people’s minds.
('96', 23, 10, 37, 39051) It is bad.
('96', 23, 10, 38, 39062) I do not think this feeling will stay.
('96', 23, 10, 39, 39101) If it does, it will mean good bye to freedom.
('96', 23, 10, 40, 39147) India will commit suicide.
('96', 23, 11, 41, 39174) The Sardar and some Congressmen feel that the area ceded to Pakistan has to be taken back.
('96', 23, 11, 42, 39265) It irritates the Muslims.
('96', 23, 11, 43, 39291) There you are greatly mistaken.
('96', 23, 11, 44, 39323) Personally I feel Pakistan has come to stay.
('96', 23, 11, 45, 39368) They realize it.

('96', 24, 6, 13, 40082) NEW DELHI, [July 10, 1947] 2
('96', 24, 7, 14, 40111) He said that he was a philosopher rather than a diplomat.
('96', 24, 7, 15, 40169) He was soon to leave for Singapore and another would take his place.

('96', 24, 9, 22, 40549) WINKLEMAN: You are a believer in God.
('96', 24, 9, 23, 40587) Your mind must be at rest if you feel that India is going in the right direction.
('96', 24, 9, 24, 40669) Europe is not.

('96', 24, 10, 29, 40877) It is beyond me.

('96', 24, 11, 40, 41426) It cannot be done.” I have held that opinion for a long time.

('96', 25, 1, 2, 41688) 42. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 25, 2, 3, 41717) NEW DELHI, July 10, 1947
('96', 25, 3, 4, 41742) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I am often asked, now that Pakistan has been conceded, what is the duty of those of us who are in the Indian Union?
('96', 25, 3, 5, 41880) I have spoken on this question many times but it comes up again and again.
('96', 25, 3, 6, 41955) One possibility is that India and Pakistan will be enemies.
('96', 25, 3, 7, 42015) The Muslim League often says that Hindus and especially the caste Hindus are its enemies.
('96', 25, 3, 8, 42105) Must then the Hindus also consider the Muslims their enemies?
('96', 25, 3, 9, 42167) At least that is not my way.
('96', 25, 3, 10, 42196) And in my old age I cannot give up my way.
('96', 25, 3, 11, 42239) My humanity tells me that the whole world is my friend.
('96', 25, 3, 12, 42295) Cutting each other’s throats will not bring good to anyone.
('96', 25, 3, 13, 42355) Friendship does not mean appeasement.
('96', 25, 3, 14, 42393) A friend does not seek to appease another friend.
('96', 25, 3, 15, 42443) If harsh words have to be said, they must be said.
('96', 25, 3, 16, 42494) I have been asked, if I am against appeasement, what else have I been doing?
('96', 25, 3, 17, 42571) When in 1944 I trudged my way in the sun on eighteen successive days to the Qaid e Azam’s house I was doing my duty.
('96', 25, 3, 18, 42688) I did not seek to appease the Qaid e Azam.
('96', 25, 3, 19, 42731) Had he accepted what I went to offer him all this blood that has now been shed would never have been shed.
('96', 25, 3, 20, 42838) And all this poison would not have been spread.
('96', 25, 3, 21, 42886) Also there would have been no third power in India and even after the formation of Pakistan, India would have been one.
('96', 25, 3, 22, 43006) My talks with Mr. Jinnah were friendly.
('96', 25, 3, 23, 43046) Appeasement today has a bad connotation.
('96', 25, 3, 24, 43087) When Germany and England were hostile to each other, Chamberlain, who was the Prime Minister at the time, had sought to appease Hitler.
('96', 25, 3, 25, 43223) It is not my view but that of many Englishmen that, had Chamberlain not chosen the path of appeasement, history would have been different.
('96', 25, 3, 26, 43362) But since I do not consider anyone my adversary why should I go out to appease anyone?
('96', 25, 3, 27, 43449) Will the temples and the Gurudwaras in Pakistan be destroyed?
('96', 25, 3, 28, 43511) My feeling is that they will not be.
('96', 25, 3, 29, 43548) Will they stop the Hindus from going to the temples?
('96', 25, 3, 30, 43601) I do not think that this is the meaning of Pakistan.
('96', 25, 3, 31, 43654) Has not Daulatana Saheb said only today that none but enemies of Islam would say that Hindus and Sikhs could not follow their faith in Pakistan.
('96', 25, 3, 32, 43799) If the Hindus and Sikhs in Pakistan really get the same justice as the Muslims then I have not the least doubt that Islamic democracy is a lofty thing.
('96', 25, 3, 33, 43951) If they consider all mankind as
('96', 26, 0, 1, 43983) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 27
('96', 26, 1, 2, 44028) having descended from Adam, how can they stop the followers of other religions from worshipping God in their own different ways.
('96', 26, 1, 3, 44157) I think that Daulatana Saheb means what he says.
('96', 26, 1, 4, 44206) I shall ask the Hindus of the Punjab and N. W. F. P. not to flee from their homes in fright.
('96', 26, 1, 5, 44299) The Golden Temple is in Amritsar but what will happen to Nankana Saheb 1 for which the Sikhs have made such sacrifices?
('96', 26, 1, 6, 44419) It has to remain in Pakistan.
('96', 26, 1, 7, 44449) There are so many Hindu temples in Hyderabad.
('96', 26, 1, 8, 44495) I do not say that Hyderabad will become a part of Pakistan.
('96', 26, 1, 9, 44555) Ninety five per cent of the population there is Hindu.
('96', 26, 1, 10, 44610) If all those Hindus are included in Pakistan, what will be the meaning of Pakistan?
('96', 26, 1, 11, 44694) The great Jama Masjid will be in the Union.
('96', 26, 1, 12, 44738) Shall we forbid the Muslims to say namaaz there?
('96', 26, 1, 13, 44787) Then there is the Taj Mahal in Agra.
('96', 26, 1, 14, 44824) And a Muslim University in Aligarh.
('96', 26, 1, 15, 44860) Will Muslim students be stopped from studying there?
('96', 26, 1, 16, 44913) Is there a place that does not have both mosques and temples?
('96', 26, 1, 17, 44975) I find both wherever I go.
('96', 26, 1, 18, 45002) Why then do the Hindus from the Punjab, Sind and N. W. F. P. want to flee to India?
('96', 26, 1, 19, 45086) They should be brave.
('96', 26, 1, 20, 45108) We have no use for the bravery that consists in burning down houses and killing innocent children.
('96', 26, 1, 21, 45207) It is not bravery.
('96', 26, 1, 22, 45226) It is devilry.
('96', 26, 1, 23, 45241) But if people do leave their houses in Sind and other places and come to India, must we drive them out?
('96', 26, 1, 24, 45345) If we do that, how can we call ourselves Indians?
('96', 26, 1, 25, 45395) With what face can we shout Jai Hind?
('96', 26, 1, 26, 45433) For what had Netaji fought?
('96', 26, 1, 27, 45461) We are all Indians whether living in Delhi or Gujarat.
('96', 26, 1, 28, 45516) They will be our guests.
('96', 26, 1, 29, 45541) We shall welcome them saying that India is their country as much as Pakistan.
('96', 26, 1, 30, 45619) If Nationalist Muslims also have to leave Pakistan we shall welcome them here.
('96', 26, 1, 31, 45698) As Indians we all have the same status.
('96', 26, 1, 32, 45738) There are still thirty five days to August 15. Let us cease to be beasts and become men.
('96', 26, 1, 33, 45827) We have all been put to the test and that includes the British.
('96', 26, 1, 34, 45891) I have just received a telegram from Noakhali saying that now that Pakistan has come into being the Hindus who had suffered there are not likely to get any compensation.
('96', 26, 1, 35, 46061) Why should they not get compensation?
('96', 26, 1, 36, 46099) With Pakistan established it is all the more the duty of the Government there to protect the Hindus.
('96', 26, 1, 37, 46200) The telegram also says that those who have committed murders and who are at present in prison are likely to be freed.
('96', 26, 1, 38, 46318) I hope this will not be.
('96', 26, 1, 39, 46343) The Pakistanis must demonstrate that the Hindus living in Pakistan will not be harmed in any way.
('96', 26, 1, 40, 46441) Then we shall have reason to celebrate 15th of
('96', 26, 2, 41, 46488) 1 Where on February 20, 1921, a number of Sikhs were killed; vide “Letter to C. F. Andrews”, 22 2 1921.

('96', 27, 1, 2, 46633) August as Independence Day.
('96', 27, 1, 3, 46661) But if this does not happen, this independence is not for me nor, I am sure will it be for you.
('96', 27, 1, 4, 46757) A lot can happen in these thirty five days.

('96', 30, 1, 2, 51410) 48. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 30, 2, 3, 51439) NEW DELHI, July 11, 1947
('96', 30, 3, 4, 51464) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, A co worker writes from Noakhali: “When you came to Noakhali you talked so much about doing or dying.
('96', 30, 3, 5, 51588) Now if you do not come here before the 15th of August, you will repent.” I admit that if I do not go to Noakhali before August 15, I shall repent.
('96', 30, 3, 6, 51735) Why am I in Delhi?
('96', 30, 3, 7, 51754) I ought to be either in Bihar or in Noakhali.
('96', 30, 3, 8, 51800) I am restless here.
('96', 30, 3, 9, 51820) I was not so in Noakhali.
('96', 30, 3, 10, 51846) I walked long distances every day, visited ever new villages and met an immense number of people both Hindus and Muslims.
('96', 30, 3, 11, 51968) I did some work in Noakhali, also in Bihar.
('96', 30, 3, 12, 52012) There is a fire raging inside me.
('96', 30, 3, 13, 52046) That fire will not rage after I go to Noakhali.
('96', 30, 3, 14, 52094) I ask you to pray that God may quickly send me to Noakhali.
('96', 30, 3, 15, 52154) I have not forgotten my pledge to do or die.
('96', 30, 3, 16, 52199) From Noakhali I went to Bihar, for whereas in Noakhali only a few hundred people had died, in Bihar thousands were killed.
('96', 30, 3, 17, 52322) So for me Noakhali and Bihar were alike.
('96', 30, 3, 18, 52363) From there Jawaharlal summoned me here.
('96', 30, 3, 19, 52403) Kripalani also sent me a wire calling me here, but what have I achieved here?
('96', 30, 3, 20, 52481) Of course many people retort, “What could I achieve in Noakhali?
('96', 30, 3, 21, 52546) If there is a settlement concerning the whole of India, there will automatically be a settlement concerning Noakhali.” But I proceed the other way.
('96', 30, 3, 22, 52694) I had learnt when still a child the formula, “As in the microcosm so in the macrocosm.” My untutored and rustic mother also taught me to begin with myself and not to bother about the world.
('96', 30, 3, 23, 52884) There is God to look after the world.
('96', 30, 3, 24, 52922) I must therefore keep the pledge I made in Noakhali.
('96', 30, 3, 25, 52975) [From Hindi]
('96', 30, 4, 26, 52988) Prarthana Pravachan–I, pp.

('96', 31, 1, 2, 53056) 49. STATEMENT ON RENTIA JAYANTI 1
('96', 31, 2, 3, 53090) NEW DELHI, July 12, 1947 Lovers of the charkha should show a hundred times more zeal for the coming Rentia Baras.
('96', 31, 2, 4, 53204) That does not mean that they should send a hundred times more yarn.
('96', 31, 2, 5, 53272) They may well send that much yarn.
('96', 31, 2, 6, 53307) But those who do not observe truth and non violence and those who do not pray should not send the yarn.
('96', 31, 2, 7, 53411) That is to say, those who spin for the sake of the yajna should adhere to truth and non violence, believe that God is their sole help and that real swaraj will come only with the help of yarn.
('96', 31, 2, 8, 53604) Those who do not believe in these should not participate in the yarn yajna.

('96', 31, 4, 11, 53721) 50. LETTER TO S. K. PATIL 2
('96', 31, 5, 12, 53749) July 12, 1947 You are enunciating the doctrine of an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.
('96', 31, 5, 13, 53842) Only you will wait till the 15th August.
('96', 31, 5, 14, 53883) Both these statements ill conform with the Congress policy.
('96', 31, 5, 15, 53943) Has the Congress policy changed?
('96', 31, 5, 16, 53976) Congressmen have changed I know but I am not aware of any change in the Congress constitution.
('96', 31, 5, 17, 54071) Secondly, if Congress policy or practice changed who compels you to wait till 15th August?
('96', 31, 5, 18, 54162) Who will be responsible for the incalculable harm that will have overtaken the people of India as well as Pakistan in the meantime?
('96', 31, 5, 19, 54294) Who can control the people if they go mad and launch on a course of retaliation?

('96', 32, 2, 3, 55106) July 12, 1947 He who is filled with a desire to serve does not have to go looking for an opportunity for it.

('96', 32, 4, 11, 55621) 52. A LETTER
('96', 32, 5, 12, 55634) July 12, 1947
('96', 32, 6, 13, 55648) He who has conquered anger has achieved a great victory in life.
('96', 32, 6, 14, 55713) I myself am not free from it.
('96', 32, 6, 15, 55743) But I am ceaselessly striving and have made progress.
('96', 32, 6, 16, 55797) The final result can be judged only after my death.
('96', 32, 6, 17, 55849) Manudi’s health is deteriorating from day to day.
('96', 32, 6, 18, 55899) Though I sometimes feel irritated by her carelessness in regard to it, I must admit that none from among the countless girls who came and worked with me acquitted herself as well as this girl of sixteen or seventeen did both physically and mentally in doing whatever work I assigned to her in Noakhali and Bihar.
('96', 32, 6, 19, 56212) And even at the age of thirteen, she had rendered similar service to Ba.
('96', 32, 6, 20, 56285) I have admired her ever since then.
('96', 32, 6, 21, 56321) All this has a bearing on my reply to the question whether I have conquered anger.
('96', 32, 6, 22, 56404) She has ruined her health in serving me, but if only she would give me co operation, take proper rest, be careful about her diet and remain cheerful, I could help her to regain her health in a month and she would feel better than she ever did.
('96', 32, 6, 23, 56648) But I have to remind her again and again.
('96', 32, 6, 24, 56690) Though running a temperature, she was rolling khakharas for me yesterday.
('96', 32, 6, 25, 56764) This made me angry.
('96', 32, 6, 26, 56784) If I had scolded her, she would have started crying and the temperature would have risen still higher, instead of coming down.
('96', 32, 6, 27, 56911) This anger bespeaks weakness both of body and mind.
('96', 32, 6, 28, 56963) When the mind is full of agony, what can we expect but physical weakness?
('96', 32, 6, 29, 57037) But I am confident that in the end I shall overcome this anger too.
('96', 32, 6, 30, 57105) [From Gujarati]
('96', 32, 7, 31, 57121) Bihar Pachhi Dilhi, pp.

('96', 33, 4, 13, 57666) 54. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 33, 5, 14, 57695) NEW DELHI, July 12, 1947
('96', 33, 6, 15, 57720) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Today I have received a letter from a friend which says: “What is happening in the country today is very bad.
('96', 33, 6, 16, 57852) People who went to jail during the satyagraha movement think they have done something very big which should entitle them to be Prime Minister or Minister or Parliamentary Secretary or Governor of some province.
('96', 33, 6, 17, 58063) They think they should have a motorcar.
('96', 33, 6, 18, 58103) I have also been to prison twice and once I was with you in Yeravda.
('96', 33, 6, 19, 58172) But I have remained a beggar and no one has ever bothered about me!” If someone has been to jail, has he done a favour to India?
('96', 33, 6, 20, 58301) If this sort of mentality persists, I fear the Congress will perish.
('96', 33, 6, 21, 58370) Those who are in the Congress should not even dream of such things.
('96', 33, 6, 22, 58438) Arguing thus a Congressman may say that, since he has been to jail, his son should be married to the best girl in India or that his daughter should be married to the best young man in India.
('96', 33, 6, 23, 58629) Jawaharlal has not become the Vice President or the Prime Minister because he has been to jail.
('96', 33, 6, 24, 58725) If he does not get his salary, he will not starve.
('96', 33, 6, 25, 58776) Rajendra Babu might have become the Chief Justice of Patna High Court but he voluntarily gave up practice and chose to live the life of a fakir.
('96', 33, 6, 26, 58921) Rajaji also has not become a minister by virtue of his jail going.
('96', 33, 6, 27, 58988) If is not my contention that they are all
('96', 34, 0, 1, 59030) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 35
('96', 34, 1, 2, 59075) angels.
('96', 34, 1, 3, 59083) They are men like us and all men make mistakes.
('96', 34, 1, 4, 59131) And how many of us can be absorbed in Government offices?
('96', 34, 1, 5, 59189) It is an unworthy thought and should be given up.
('96', 34, 1, 6, 59239) We must never think that we should get some reward for having gone to jail.
('96', 34, 1, 7, 59315) The reward of doing one’s duty lies in the duty done.
('96', 34, 1, 8, 59369) I have been asked: “Whereas in Pakistan Mr. Jinnah has been made Governor General, here in India it is the Viceroy who has been made Governor General.
('96', 34, 1, 9, 59520) Why should this be so?
('96', 34, 1, 10, 59543) The battle for India’s freedom was fought by the Congress.
('96', 34, 1, 11, 59602) The Muslim League has had no part in it.
('96', 34, 1, 12, 59643) Whenever the Congress resorted to civil disobedience or satyagraha the League refused to co operate.
('96', 34, 1, 13, 59744) Even so the Congress cannot get an Indian as Governor General.
('96', 34, 1, 14, 59807) This is not just.
('96', 34, 1, 15, 59825) This will mean that we shall be safe only if we kowtow to the British or we shall die.” I shall say that under the scheme that will come into effect on August 15, it does not matter whether the Governor General is an Englishman, a Frenchman or a Dutchman, whether he is a brown skinned Indian or a White or a Negro.
('96', 34, 1, 16, 60141) If I had my way a Harijan girl would be the Governor General.
('96', 34, 1, 17, 60203) So if Lord Mountbatten becomes the Governor General he will still be a servant of India.
('96', 34, 1, 18, 60292) You will say this is the kind of talk to pacify children.
('96', 34, 1, 19, 60350) Mountbatten, who is a scion of a Royal family, will not be anybody’s servant.
('96', 34, 1, 20, 60428) But I am not deceiving you.
('96', 34, 1, 21, 60456) I do not expect any reward from Lord Mountbatten.
('96', 34, 1, 22, 60506) So long I have been fighting against him.
('96', 34, 1, 23, 60548) Maybe you will say that the Congress leaders have been deceived by him.
('96', 34, 1, 24, 60620) Do you mean to say that Jawaharlal, Sardar and Rajaji are so softbrained as to be taken in?
('96', 34, 1, 25, 60712) True, as I have been saying what I had wanted has not come to pass.
('96', 34, 1, 26, 60780) But Mountbatten will be Governor General because we want him.
('96', 34, 1, 27, 60842) If we did not want him he would not hold that office.
('96', 34, 1, 28, 60896) But Mr. Jinnah may have chosen to be Governor General in order to show off.
('96', 34, 1, 29, 60972) We should not be jealous and we should not be angry.
('96', 34, 1, 30, 61025) He wants to show to the world what Islam is.
('96', 34, 1, 31, 61070) Let us see whether he makes of himself a master or a servant.
('96', 34, 1, 32, 61132) If even a single Sindhi flees, then the responsibility for it will rest on the Governor General of Pakistan.
('96', 34, 1, 33, 61241) He will have to be just to all, like Abubaker or Omar, or Ali.
('96', 34, 1, 34, 61304) I do not say they were all non violent.
('96', 34, 1, 35, 61344) But I have in mind their bravery and their chivalry.
('96', 34, 1, 36, 61397) I understand from the newspapers that originally the idea had been for India and Pakistan to have one Governor General in common.
('96', 34, 1, 37, 61527) But Mr. Jinnah later went back on his word.
('96', 34, 1, 38, 61571) Who was then to prevent him from becoming the Governor General of Pakistan?
('96', 35, 0, 1, 61647) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 35, 1, 2, 61688) my view he did not do the right thing.
('96', 35, 1, 3, 61727) When he had once agreed he should have accepted Lord Mountbatten as Governor General and later if something had gone wrong he could have removed him.
('96', 35, 1, 4, 61877) Now Islam is to be tested through Mr. Jinnah.
('96', 35, 1, 5, 61923) He is assuming the Governor Generalship of Pakistan with the whole world as witness.
('96', 35, 1, 6, 62008) The world will now wait to see what special virtues Pakistan displays under him.
('96', 35, 1, 7, 62089) The Congress has always been fighting against the British.
('96', 35, 1, 8, 62148) Jawaharlal is a simple hearted man.
('96', 35, 1, 9, 62184) But the Sardar is a fighter.
('96', 35, 1, 10, 62213) He used to quarrel with me because I trusted the British.
('96', 35, 1, 11, 62271) When he himself has been caught up in their wiles, what can you or I hope to do?
('96', 35, 1, 12, 62352) When he agrees that the Viceroy should be the first Governor General of India, why should we object?
('96', 35, 1, 13, 62453) We shall see whether he will serve India as Governor General or betray her.

('96', 35, 1, 19, 62810) When I went to see the Viceroy he confided in me that the young man to whom Princess Elizabeth had been betrothed was like a son to him and he hoped that I would write a few words of blessings to him.
('96', 35, 1, 20, 63011) So when the Viceroy’s daughter 1 came to see me two days ago I gave her a letter of congratulation addressed to the couple.
('96', 35, 1, 21, 63135) She is such a sweet girl.

('96', 35, 1, 25, 63455) Anyway if the Viceroy had been a bad man I wouldn’t have been so free with my blessings.
('96', 35, 1, 26, 63544) I do not consider him a bad man.
('96', 35, 1, 27, 63577) If Jawaharlal or Sardar Patel had become Governor General in his place it would have been a dangerous thing.
('96', 35, 1, 28, 63686) Besides, the Governor General wields no effective power.
('96', 35, 1, 29, 63743) He will have to act on the advice of Jawaharlal and his cabinet.
('96', 35, 1, 30, 63808) He will only be a figurehead.
('96', 35, 1, 31, 63838) But we have got into the way of thinking that Lord Mountbatten has great status and the English are capable only of devilry.
('96', 35, 1, 32, 63963) Lord Mountbatten therefore will have to prove his honesty and love of justice and I am sure that he has come to India to do only justice.

('96', 36, 0, 1, 64122) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 37
('96', 36, 1, 2, 64167) Many Muslims come to see me these days.
('96', 36, 1, 3, 64207) They too are nervous about Pakistan.
('96', 36, 1, 4, 64244) One can understand Christians, Parsis and other non Muslims feeling uneasy, but why Muslims?
('96', 36, 1, 5, 64337) They say they are treated as Quislings, that they will receive even worse treatment than the Hindus in Pakistan and after full power has been transferred to Pakistan their association with the Congress will be considered a crime according to the tenets of Shariyat.

('96', 36, 3, 15, 65131) 55. SOCIALISM 1
('96', 36, 4, 16, 65147) Truth and ahimsa must come alive in socialism.
('96', 36, 4, 17, 65194) This can only be possible when there is a living faith in God.
('96', 36, 4, 18, 65257) Mere mechanical adherence to truth and ahimsa is likely to break down at the critical moment.
('96', 36, 4, 19, 65351) Hence have I said that truth is God.
('96', 36, 4, 20, 65388) This God is a living Force.
('96', 36, 4, 21, 65416) Our life is of that Force.
('96', 36, 4, 22, 65443) That Force resides in the body, but is not the body.
('96', 36, 4, 23, 65496) He who denies the existence of that great Force denies to himself access to its inexhaustible power and thus remains impotent.
('96', 36, 4, 24, 65623) He is like a rudderless ship which, tossed about here and there, perishes without making any headway.
('96', 36, 4, 25, 65725) Many find themselves in this plight.
('96', 36, 4, 26, 65762) The socialism of such people does not reach anywhere, what to say of the millions.
('96', 36, 4, 27, 65845) If such be the case, why is there no socialist who believes in God?
('96', 36, 4, 28, 65913) If there are such socialists why have they not made any progress?
('96', 36, 4, 29, 65979) Also there have been many believing in God; why is it they have not succeeded in bringing socialism?
('96', 36, 4, 30, 66080) There is no effective answer to this.
('96', 36, 4, 31, 66118) Nevertheless, it is possible to say that it has perhaps never occurred to a believing socialist that there is any connection between his socialism and his belief in God.
('96', 36, 5, 32, 66288) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan, 20 7 1947.
('96', 37, 0, 1, 66354) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 37, 1, 2, 66395) Equally, men of God perhaps never felt any need for socialism.
('96', 37, 1, 3, 66458) Superstitions have flourished in the world in spite of godly men and women.
('96', 37, 1, 4, 66534) In Hinduism which believes in God, untouchability has, till of late, held undoubted sway.
('96', 37, 1, 5, 66624) The nature of this Divine Force and its inexhaustible power have been matters of incessant quest.

('96', 46, 1, 17, 84360) I have, therefore, to harden my heart in dealing with her.
('96', 46, 1, 18, 84419) She starts crying, but I pay no attention to it.

('96', 47, 5, 7, 85348) NEW DELHI, July 14, 1947
('96', 47, 6, 8, 85373) India has been partitioned.
('96', 47, 6, 9, 85401) But the division of the army has greatly affected me.
('96', 47, 6, 10, 85455) Do not these people realize that if either India or Pakistan is invaded by a foreign power, it is equally the duty of both to resist the aggression?
('96', 47, 6, 11, 85604) How humiliating will it be for us if Pakistan and India cannot remain united even in such a crisis?
('96', 47, 6, 12, 85704) If the army is divided, a situation will arise when both the armies will start fighting one another, and that situation will be very difficult to control.
('96', 47, 6, 13, 85859) On the whole it is harmful to both the countries.
('96', 47, 6, 14, 85909) And that is why I am requesting… 1 to give a serious thought to this question.
('96', 47, 6, 15, 85988) Even if we have not learnt non violence in the last thirty years, we certainly will have realized that we will not be slaves to any third power, let alone the British.
('96', 47, 6, 16, 86156) But I feel that… anything I say is not acceptable to people today.
('96', 47, 6, 17, 86223) That is why I do not think too deeply over anything.
('96', 47, 6, 18, 86276) I request these people to allow me to return to Bihar and then Noakhali.
('96', 47, 6, 19, 86349) But the Viceroy and Jawaharal do not agree.

('96', 48, 1, 2, 86558) 70. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 48, 2, 3, 86587) NEW DELHI, July 14, 1947
('96', 48, 3, 4, 86612) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, It is said that my speeches these days are such as to generate a feeling of pessimism.
('96', 48, 3, 5, 86721) Indeed I am advised by some not to speak at all.
('96', 48, 3, 6, 86770) It reminds me of a story about a painter.
('96', 48, 3, 7, 86812) He placed a paint ing on display with a notice that critics might mark the sport where they found the painting faulty.
('96', 48, 3, 8, 86931) The result was that the painting was soon reduced to a blur of colours.
('96', 48, 3, 9, 87003) The painter had wanted to show that it was not possible to please everyone and he was satisfied that he had created a good painting.
('96', 48, 3, 10, 87136) I am in a similar situation.
('96', 48, 3, 11, 87165) I never speak merely for the sake of speaking.
('96', 48, 3, 12, 87212) I speak because I feel that I have a message to deliver.
('96', 48, 3, 13, 87269) It is true that today there are differences between me and my closest colleagues.
('96', 48, 3, 14, 87351) I do not approve of certain things that they have done or are doing.
('96', 48, 3, 15, 87420) But it is not possible for me while I am in Delhi not to express my views on the present situation.
('96', 48, 3, 16, 87520) What is at the root of these differences?
('96', 48, 3, 17, 87562) If you go into it you will find that there is only one thing at the root of it.
('96', 48, 3, 18, 87642) Non violence is a creed with me while it has never been so with the Congress.
('96', 48, 3, 19, 87720) The Congress accepted non violence only as a policy—a policy has the status of a creed only so long as it is pursued.
('96', 48, 3, 20, 87838) The congress has a perfect right to change its policy the moment it feels that it is no longer necessary to pursue it.
('96', 48, 3, 21, 87957) But it is different with a creed.
('96', 48, 3, 22, 87991) It remains for ever and it cannot be changed.
('96', 48, 3, 23, 88037) In the Congress constitution non violence is still the policy but in practice Congressmen have changed it.
('96', 48, 3, 24, 88144) Legal pundits may well comment on it but you and I cannot do so nor should we.
('96', 48, 3, 25, 88223) Why should Congressmen not change their policy?
('96', 48, 3, 26, 88271) Besides, the constitution of the Congress says ‘peaceful’ and not ‘non violence’.
('96', 48, 3, 27, 88353) In 1934, at the Bombay Congress, I tried my best to have the term ‘peaceful’ replaced by the term ‘non violence’.
('96', 48, 3, 28, 88467) But I was unsuccessful.
('96', 48, 3, 29, 88491) Therefore anyone can, it he chooses, say that ‘peaceful’ means ‘something little less than non violent’.
('96', 48, 3, 30, 88596) In my view there is no difference between the two.
('96', 48, 3, 31, 88647) But my view is neither here nor there.
('96', 48, 3, 32, 88686) It is the experts who must decide.
('96', 48, 3, 33, 88721) You and I must only understand that the practice of Congress today is not in the least non violent.
('96', 48, 3, 34, 88821) If non 
('96', 49, 0, 1, 88829) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 50
('96', 49, 1, 2, 88870) violence had been the creed of the Congress, how would it be possible for it to support the army as it is doing today?
('96', 49, 1, 3, 88989) If the army is so disposed it can crush the people and establish a militray regime.
('96', 49, 1, 4, 89073) Shall I give up the hope altoge ther that people will ever listen to me?
('96', 49, 1, 5, 89146) And if they will not listen to me, what harm does it do if I speak out?
('96', 49, 1, 6, 89218) Why should they seek to stop me?
('96', 49, 1, 7, 89251) I have repeatedly made it clear that the struggle that has been waged over the last thirty years was not a non violent struggle.
('96', 49, 1, 8, 89380) It was only passive resistance and such resistance is a weapon of the weak.
('96', 49, 1, 9, 89456) It is not that people who use this weapon do not want to use the weapon of non violence.
('96', 49, 1, 10, 89545) It is simply that they do not know how to use it.
('96', 49, 1, 11, 89595) If we had the courage for the battle of non violence we would today be presenting to the world an entierely different picture of free India.
('96', 49, 1, 12, 89736) But today we can show only a dismembered country where brother fights brother and no one can trust another.
('96', 49, 1, 13, 89844) We are not able to attend to feeding and clothing the people and have nothing to offer those impoverished millions who can see God only in the form of bread and who have no interest in this unending violence.
('96', 49, 1, 14, 90053) [From Hindi]
('96', 49, 2, 15, 90066) Prarthana Pravachan–I, pp.

('96', 54, 7, 19, 97699) 83. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 54, 8, 20, 97728) NEW DELHI, July 15, 1947
('96', 54, 9, 21, 97753) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, The other day I spoke of the temples in Tamil Nadu and Malabar that had been thrown open to Harijan and I especially mentioned the Rameswaram temple.
('96', 54, 9, 22, 97925) It is a huge temple and there is a lot of superstition concerning it.
('96', 54, 9, 23, 97995) Some thought that the entry of Harijans would pollute the temple.
('96', 54, 9, 24, 98061) I have received a letter today complaining that I had not mentioned the Tirupati temple in Andhra
('96', 54, 10, 25, 98159) 1President, All India Kisan Sabha and Andhra Provincial Congress Committee; Member, Congress Parliamentary at the Centre
('96', 55, 0, 1, 98280) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 56
('96', 55, 1, 2, 98321) Desh which is also a great and acient temple.
('96', 55, 1, 3, 98367) The correspondent asks me to rectify the omission and thus give satisfaction to the people of Andhra.
('96', 55, 1, 4, 98469) I know the glory of this temple but I make no difference between Tamil Nadu and Andhra.
('96', 55, 1, 5, 98557) Today the atmosphere is such that everyone wants separation.
('96', 55, 1, 6, 98618) Some friends from Bengal have been to see me.
('96', 55, 1, 7, 98664) They say that with the division of Bengal Hindus in East Bengal are haunted by the fear that the Hindus of West Bengal will forget them.
('96', 55, 1, 8, 98801) It that happens I shall be pained.
('96', 55, 1, 9, 98836) It will be very bad if Hindus thus forget Hindus and Muslims forget Muslims.
('96', 55, 1, 10, 98913) Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, Christians all are Indians.
('96', 55, 1, 11, 98966) Religion is a private matter.
('96', 55, 1, 12, 98996) If I wish to worship God, what power on earth can stop me from doing so?
('96', 55, 1, 13, 99069) But If Mussalmans, Parsis, Hindus and Christians all consider themselves separate, what is left of India?
('96', 55, 1, 14, 99175) I admit that is was hardly necessary to divide Bengal.
('96', 55, 1, 15, 99230) I have lived among Bengali Muslims.
('96', 55, 1, 16, 99266) I have walked with them in Noakhali.
('96', 55, 1, 17, 99303) I found only love in their hearts.
('96', 55, 1, 18, 99338) Why should Hindus have harboured fear of Muslims?
('96', 55, 1, 19, 99388) The madness that had seized them would not have lasted for ever.
('96', 55, 1, 20, 99453) In my view no harm will come to the Hindus of East Bengal.
('96', 55, 1, 21, 99512) But many things have happened which we did not want to happen.
('96', 55, 1, 22, 99575) Bengal has been partitioned.
('96', 55, 1, 23, 99604) And India and Pakistan are separate countries.
('96', 55, 1, 24, 99651) But we should proceed forward from what has happened and later put it right.
('96', 55, 1, 25, 99728) Hindus and Muslims of East and West Bengal have always lived together and speak the same language.
('96', 55, 1, 26, 99827) It the Hindus of East Bengal treat the Muslims there as friends, would the Muslims still want to kill them?
('96', 55, 1, 27, 99935) When not a single Hindu considers Muslims his enemies, all will be friends.
('96', 55, 1, 28, 100011) They also asked me if the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee will be dissolved since it too has been divided into two.
('96', 55, 1, 29, 100132) In my view the division of Bengal does not apply to the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee.
('96', 55, 1, 30, 100226) It should continue in its present form.
('96', 55, 1, 31, 100266) It is outside Government laws.
('96', 55, 1, 32, 100297) If it divides itself, then I will say that West Bengal has broken faith.
('96', 55, 1, 33, 100370) The structure of the Congress today is such that at the very bottom there are village Congress Committees, Mandal Congress Committees, District Congress Committees, then Provincial and at the very top the All India Congress Committee.
('96', 55, 1, 34, 100605) Thus there will be Congress Committees in East Bengal as well as in West Bengal.
('96', 55, 1, 35, 100686) Both will then constitute the B.P.C.C. The Congress belongs to all, to Muslims, Christians, Parsis and others.

('96', 61, 1, 2, 109706) 92. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 61, 2, 3, 109735) NEW DELHI, July 16, 1947
('96', 61, 3, 4, 109760) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, The bhajan that was sung today has been known to me ever since I was a boy just entering high school.
('96', 61, 3, 5, 109884) It appeared as a prayer in a little book for children called Bal Mitra.
('96', 61, 3, 6, 109956) It is a good and sweet bhajan and it teaches the truth that we should not be too concerned with the body.
('96', 61, 3, 7, 110062) They body is there today and will be gone tomorrow.
('96', 61, 3, 8, 110114) It will either be hurnt up and become ashes or go to the grave and become mixed with the soil.
('96', 61, 3, 9, 110209) If it is cast into water it will be eaten up by marine life.
('96', 61, 3, 10, 110270) In the end it is all the same.
('96', 61, 3, 11, 110301) What does not sound so good in the bhajan is the words ‘‘after me the deluge’’.
('96', 61, 3, 12, 110381) True it has been composed by Kabir, but what of it?
('96', 61, 3, 13, 110433) I do not like it.
('96', 61, 3, 14, 110451) In my humble opinion it shows selfishness.
('96', 61, 3, 15, 110494) Why should the deluge overtake the world after I am dead?
('96', 61, 3, 16, 110552) In the first place we do not really die.
('96', 61, 3, 17, 110593) For the self is immortal.
('96', 61, 3, 18, 110619) As for the world it is ever changing.
('96', 61, 3, 19, 110657) It is God’s play.
('96', 61, 3, 20, 110675) But we do not go wholly by what the bhanan says.
('96', 61, 3, 21, 110724) If we did, where was the need of a Constituent Assembly?
('96', 61, 3, 22, 110781) Where was the need of all the laws that our leaders are busy enacting.
('96', 61, 3, 23, 110852) If they had all taken up the attitude of ‘‘after me the deluge’’, no one would have been doing anything for anyone.
('96', 61, 3, 24, 110968) This sentiment, therefore, is an expression of extreme selfishness.
('96', 61, 3, 25, 111036) Some newspapermen had been to see me.
('96', 61, 3, 26, 111074) In the course of the talk Dravidastan was mentioned.
('96', 61, 3, 27, 111127) Dravidastan comprises the Southern part of India beyond the Vindhyas.
('96', 61, 3, 28, 111197) The languages spoken are Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam and Kannada.
('96', 61, 3, 29, 111260) I have acquainted myself a little bit with each of these languages and I can say that the are all rooted in Sanskrit.
('96', 61, 3, 30, 111378) If you hear Telugu spoken you will find that it is full of Sanskrit words.
('96', 61, 3, 31, 111453) Tamil too has Sanskrit words in abundance.
('96', 61, 3, 32, 111496) Only they have been given Dravidian dress.
('96', 61, 3, 33, 111539) Malayalam too resembless Sanskrit.
('96', 61, 3, 34, 111574) And the same is true of Kannada.
('96', 61, 3, 35, 111607) I do not treat Dravidastan as something apart from India.
('96', 61, 3, 36, 111665) The British have made us all one.
('96', 61, 3, 37, 111699) Everyone living between Kashmir and Kanaya kumari is an Indian.
('96', 61, 3, 38, 111763) To make distinctions such as Aryans or non Aryans or the Aryavrata and Dravidastan is foolish.
('96', 61, 3, 39, 111858) I am quite certain about this.
('96', 61, 3, 40, 111889) That leads to the question of language.
('96', 61, 3, 41, 111929) We have here two
('96', 62, 0, 1, 111946) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 63
('96', 62, 1, 2, 111991) languages, Hindi and Urdu, which were developed in India by Indians.
('96', 62, 1, 3, 112060) Their grammar is the same.
('96', 62, 1, 4, 112087) I have combined these two to form Hindustani.
('96', 62, 1, 5, 112133) This is spoken by many crores of people.
('96', 62, 1, 6, 112174) It is the common language of Hindus and Muslims.

('96', 67, 1, 2, 120871) 101. DISCUSSION WITH VISITORS
('96', 67, 2, 3, 120901) NEW DELHI, July 17, 1947
('96', 67, 3, 4, 120926) That is what you think.
('96', 67, 3, 5, 120950) 1 I tell you that I can show you the miracle today if Hindus maintain peace and show courage.
('96', 67, 3, 6, 121044) But with what face can I tell the League not to indulge in atrocities?
('96', 67, 3, 7, 121115) You say that if I give you the lead you will follow me.
('96', 67, 3, 8, 121171) Have you ever thought against whom and to whom I can give the lead?
('96', 67, 3, 9, 121239) The British have not partitioned the country.
('96', 67, 3, 10, 121285) It has been done with the consent of the Mulsim League and the Congress.
('96', 67, 3, 11, 121358) Isn’t that so?
('96', 67, 3, 12, 121373) The leaders had no other alternative.
('96', 67, 3, 13, 121411) They thought it was better to partition the country so that both the parts could live happily and peacefully rather than let the whole country go to pieces.
('96', 67, 3, 14, 121568) About this I did hold a different view.
('96', 67, 3, 15, 121608) My view was that no one could take an inch of land by resorting to violence and murder.
('96', 67, 3, 16, 121696) Let the whole country be reduced to ashes.
('96', 67, 3, 17, 121739) They could take the whole country by friendly negotiations and peaceful methods.
('96', 67, 3, 18, 121820) But though non violence is a creed with me, it is not so with the Congress.
('96', 67, 3, 19, 121896) There is only one other person in the country who has accepted non violence as a creed and he is Badshah Khan.
('96', 67, 3, 20, 122007) It is true that I had believed that our satyagraha struggles were based on non violence.
('96', 67, 3, 21, 122096) Only lately I realized that it was not true.
('96', 67, 3, 22, 122141) I admit my mistake.
('96', 67, 3, 23, 122161) I first started the satyagraha struggle in Sought Africa.
('96', 67, 3, 24, 122219) At one of the meetings Mr. Hosken 2 said that Gandhi was fighting a weak man’s battle.
('96', 67, 3, 25, 122306) I strongly contradicted him and produly said that what was needed for satyagraha was spiritual strength and not physical strength, and that we were fighting with soul force.
('96', 67, 3, 26, 122480) As you know we were quite successful in that struggle.
('96', 67, 3, 27, 122535) Immediately after that I came away to India.
('96', 67, 3, 28, 122580) I employed the same method here.
('96', 67, 3, 29, 122613) At the time I did believe that people were fighting with genuine spiritual strength.
('96', 67, 3, 30, 122698) I would not have launched the struggle if I had then realized that it was only ‘‘passive resistance’’.
('96', 67, 3, 31, 122801) But God had willed to use me for this mission and so he blurred my vision.
('96', 67, 3, 32, 122876) And because our fight was not one of non violence we see the result today.
('96', 67, 3, 33, 122951) There is arson,
('96', 67, 4, 34, 122967) 1 The visitors, who were from the Punjab, had told Gandhiji that his belief that he was a spent bullet or that the country was not behind him was not true.
('96', 67, 4, 35, 123123) 2 William Hosken, who was the leader of a committee of European sympa thizers of the Indian cause during Gandhiji’s South African struggle

('96', 68, 1, 2, 123307) murder, loot and chaos all around.
('96', 68, 1, 3, 123342) Non violence and weakness are contradictory terms.
('96', 68, 1, 4, 123393) I have been in public life for the last sixty years and I have never felt so much despair as I do now.
('96', 68, 1, 5, 123496) I learnt from my childhood not to admit such a thing as failure.
('96', 68, 1, 6, 123561) Nevertheless today I am struggling against this all pervading darkness to find some light somewhere.
('96', 68, 1, 7, 123662) Bear in mind that India will be wiped out from the face of the earth if she rejects the path of non violence.

('96', 68, 1, 10, 123886) But if now we again lose that freedom, the word itself will be forgotten and its is quite possible that a military regime will take over.

('96', 68, 1, 12, 124092) How wonderful is non violence of the brave!

('96', 68, 1, 17, 124440) I shall be content if, when someone comes to kill me, I can remain composed, let myself be killed and pray to God that He may grant good sense to the killer—as these girls sing every day.
('96', 68, 1, 18, 124628) I had said in the Asian Conference which was held here about four months ago that the man who made the atom bomb would have to come to India to study non violence and the fragrance of the non violence of India would permeate the whole world.
('96', 68, 1, 19, 124870) Let us see when my hope materializes.

('96', 69, 1, 2, 124988) 102. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 69, 2, 3, 125018) NEW DELHI, July 17, 1947
('96', 69, 3, 4, 125043) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, We learn from newspapers 1 that the Indians in South Africa are being subjected to goondaism.
('96', 69, 3, 5, 125159) They are being killed.
('96', 69, 3, 6, 125182) I was in South Africa for twenty years and I know how Indians are treated in that country.
('96', 69, 3, 7, 125273) There is a large number of Muslims there but they all call themselves Indians.
('96', 69, 3, 8, 125352) May God give us all the sense at least to call ourselves Indians when we are in a foreign country.
('96', 69, 3, 9, 125451) Recentlly Sarup 2 had been to the United Nations along with Justice Chagla and other to present before the world body the case of the South African Indians.
('96', 69, 3, 10, 125608) Since then harassment of Indian in south Aftrica has taken a new form.
('96', 69, 3, 11, 125679) It is not the law that has been unleashed against them but goondaism.
('96', 69, 3, 12, 125749) If this goes on, how will the handful of Indians be able to live there?
('96', 69, 3, 13, 125821) Once I marched into the Transvaal with two thousand people.
('96', 69, 3, 14, 125881) Not a single Boer so much as touched us.
('96', 69, 3, 15, 125922) Some of them ever gave us water to drink.
('96', 69, 3, 16, 125964) We have plenty of water here.
('96', 69, 3, 17, 125994) But it is not in such abundance there.
('96', 69, 3, 18, 126033) People collect water when it rains and keep it stored in tanks.
('96', 69, 3, 19, 126097) The Boers were friendly and we went wherever we wanted.
('96', 69, 3, 20, 126153) But I see a different picture today.
('96', 69, 3, 21, 126190) Now that we have two Governments here, I shall ask Mr. Jinnah and Jawaharalal to send a joint telegram to Smuts 3. Mr. Smuts considers me his friend.
('96', 69, 3, 22, 126340) As a friend I must entreat him to tell the Whites not to do physical violence to even one single Indian.
('96', 69, 3, 23, 126445) And if he cannot make himself obeyed, he must resign.
('96', 69, 3, 24, 126499) Lord Mountbatten too should not helplessly watch.
('96', 69, 3, 25, 126549) He is an Admiral of the Fleet and is of Royal family.
('96', 69, 3, 26, 126603) Philip Mountbatten, who is going to marry Princess Elizabeth, is like a son to him.
('96', 69, 3, 27, 126687) Besides, up to the 15th of August he will be the Viceroy and afterwards the Governor General.
('96', 69, 3, 28, 126781) He should therefore make use of
('96', 69, 4, 29, 126813) 1 According to The Hindustan Times, 18 7 1947, the latest campaign against Indians in South Africa was the boycott of India traders by the European community with threats of violence.
('96', 69, 4, 30, 126997) 2 Vijayalakshmi Pandit, who headed the Indian delegation to U. N. O. during October December, 1946. 3 Jan Christiaan Smuts (1870 1950); Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa, 1919 24 and 1938 48
('96', 70, 0, 1, 127198) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 71
('96', 70, 1, 2, 127243) these advantages and tell Smuth that India is now a Dominion even as South Africa is, that it is now a member of the vast family that is the British Commonwealth and that the ill treatment of Indians in South Africa should forthwith stop.
('96', 70, 1, 3, 127482) It has been said that Dominion Status is even better than full independence.
('96', 70, 1, 4, 127559) But till I have tasted this fruit I cannot say whether it is nectar or poison.
('96', 70, 1, 5, 127638) Maybe it is nectar.
('96', 70, 1, 6, 127658) But let us first taste it.
('96', 70, 1, 7, 127685) My advice to South African Indians is that they should live there as good citizens.
('96', 70, 1, 8, 127769) Those of them who are wealthy should not neglect their Muslim brethren who are like untouchables there.
('96', 70, 1, 9, 127873) I had been asked, now that temples in Tamil Nad and Andhra have been opened to Harijans, what is the situation with regard to temples in the U. P.?
('96', 70, 1, 10, 128021) There are the temples in Hardwar for instance.
('96', 70, 1, 11, 128068) Can Harijans visit these temples?
('96', 70, 1, 12, 128102) In Travancore this was acheived long ago.

('96', 70, 1, 15, 128350) Can Harijans visit the temples there?
('96', 70, 1, 16, 128388) If the Harajans cannot visit those temples, them I shall consider those temples impure.
('96', 70, 1, 17, 128476) All the religions of the world are today faced with a severe test.
('96', 70, 1, 18, 128543) Hindusim should in not 99 per cent but 100 per cent marks.

('96', 90, 6, 12, 160170) 138. SPEECH AT PRAYER METTING
('96', 90, 7, 13, 160200) NEW DELHI, July 20, 1947
('96', 90, 8, 14, 160225) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Some people tell me—as they have a right to tell me—that what I say these days is not calculated to enthuse the people.
('96', 90, 8, 15, 160367) They remind me that the political freedom for which we had been fighting, we have at last secured and by and by economic freedom will also come.
('96', 90, 8, 16, 160512) All that may be true.
('96', 90, 8, 17, 160534) Nevertheless I cannot rejoice on August 15. I do not want to deceive you.
('96', 90, 8, 18, 160608) But at the same time I shall not ask you not to rejoice.
('96', 90, 8, 19, 160665) After all I cannot expect everything to be ordered according to my wish.
('96', 90, 8, 20, 160738) I did not want India to be partitioned but it has been partitioned.
('96', 90, 8, 21, 160806) What good can come of crying over it?
('96', 90, 8, 22, 160844) Even if something worse had happened, I would have had to put up with it.
('96', 90, 8, 23, 160918) India’s partition has grieved me more than it could grieve you.
('96', 90, 8, 24, 160982) I have been a rebel all my life.
('96', 90, 8, 25, 161015) How can a rebel cry?
('96', 90, 8, 26, 161036) When I went to Noakhali I found people crying and I wiped their tears.
('96', 90, 8, 27, 161107) I told them nothing was to be gained by weeping fort the dead.
('96', 90, 8, 28, 161170) But the people in whose hands we have entrusted the reins of power are big poeple.
('96', 90, 8, 29, 161253) If they say that we should have celebrations on Independence Day, then you should do so.
('96', 90, 8, 30, 161342) You should no worry why Gandhi does not join in the
('96', 91, 0, 1, 161394) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 92
('96', 91, 1, 2, 161435) celebration.
('96', 91, 1, 3, 161448) The Congress does not force anyone to celebrate.
('96', 91, 1, 4, 161497) That I shall not celebrate does not mean that the British will not be leaving.
('96', 91, 1, 5, 161576) By August 15, a number of British officers will have already left the country.
('96', 91, 1, 6, 161655) Those who remain will stay under our authority.
('96', 91, 1, 7, 161703) They will be appointed not from London but by us.
('96', 91, 1, 8, 161753) Unfortunately the kind of freedom we have got today contains also the seeds of future conflict between India and Pakistan.
('96', 91, 1, 9, 161876) How can we therefore light the lamps?
('96', 91, 1, 10, 161914) I shall consider freedom to have been secured only on the day Hindus and Muslims have cleansed their hearts.
('96', 91, 1, 11, 162023) Only lately some Muslim League friends from the Punjab have held out the threat that if the Boundary Commission does not decide in their favour they will get what they want by fighting.
('96', 91, 1, 12, 162209) The Sikhs also are holding out similar threats.
('96', 91, 1, 13, 162257) But when we accept the principle of arbitration we must go by the award.
('96', 91, 1, 14, 162330) We should not talk of fighting.

('96', 91, 1, 16, 162419) It purifies the soul.
('96', 91, 1, 17, 162441) If that kind of fighting went on all the time in the world it would be very good for the world.
('96', 91, 1, 18, 162537) I shall appeal to my Hindu, Sikh and Muslim brethren that once having accepted the Boundary Commission as the arbitrator they should accepts its award.
('96', 91, 1, 19, 162689) Burma too will soon be a free country like India.
('96', 91, 1, 20, 162739) The Burmese leader General U Aung San, has brought Burma to the gates of freedom.
('96', 91, 1, 21, 162821) What does it matter that he was not a satyagrahi?
('96', 91, 1, 22, 162871) He was a brave warrior and it is largely thanks to his efforts that Burma is about to get its freedom.
('96', 91, 1, 23, 162974) It is a great tragedy that an armed gang of assassins killed him and his four comrades.
('96', 91, 1, 24, 163062) 1 However far we may be from him, his sudden death is a matter of grief to us.
('96', 91, 1, 25, 163141) If such things are to continue, then the world has come to a sorry pass.
('96', 91, 1, 26, 163214) I cannot believe that the assassins were dacoits.
('96', 91, 1, 27, 163264) I had spent a long time in Burma.
('96', 91, 1, 28, 163298) I am acquainted with Rangoon, Mandalay and other palces.
('96', 91, 1, 29, 163355) Buddhism is the religion there as it is in the rest of Burma.
('96', 91, 1, 30, 163417) Why should there be so much blod shed in a country where Buddhism is the religion?
('96', 91, 1, 31, 163500) I am sure behind these murders there is factional politiics.
('96', 91, 1, 32, 163561) It is sad that this has happened when Burma is about to gain its freedom.
('96', 91, 1, 33, 163635) I hope India will take a lesson from this tragedy.
('96', 91, 1, 34, 163686) Let us pray that in this time of sorrow God may grant comfort to the people of Burma who like us have been fighting for their freedom and grant strength to the relatives of the dead to bear the grief.
('96', 91, 1, 35, 163887) Let us also pray that the hearts of the murderers may change.

('96', 94, 1, 2, 167748) 141. A LETTER
('96', 94, 2, 3, 167762) BHANGI COLONY, NEW DELHI, July 21, 1947 I had a letter from.
('96', 94, 2, 4, 167823) 1 She says that I waste my time on Manu.
('96', 94, 2, 5, 167864) Poor woman, how can she know that in my eyes that time is most valuably spent?
('96', 94, 2, 6, 167943) For I have undertaken to be a mother to that girl, and by devoting time to achievement of that aim I wish to uncover to the world a great spiritual mystery similar to that which I have demonstrated concerning truth and ahimsa.
('96', 94, 2, 7, 168170) I am no doubt a father to so many other girls, but why am I a mother to Manu alone?
('96', 94, 2, 8, 168254) That, however, is a long story.
('96', 94, 2, 9, 168286) Here I will say only this, that I saw in her the necessary readiness to look upon me as a mother.
('96', 94, 2, 10, 168384) She is devoted to me as a daughter to her mother, is eager to serve me and is as innocent as a child.
('96', 94, 2, 11, 168486) I have not seen in any other girl the virtues I have seen in her.
('96', 94, 2, 12, 168552) God has, therefore, given me a means at the right time whereby I can prove to the world that if men could develop the attitudes of mothers, humanity would be saved.
('96', 94, 2, 13, 168717) In India and in Pakistan, women are being wickedly dishonoured.
('96', 94, 2, 14, 168781) If that is to be ended, I think men will have to learn to be not father but mothers.
('96', 94, 2, 15, 168866) But I shall not dwell further on this subject.
('96', 94, 2, 16, 168913) I am short of time.
('96', 94, 2, 17, 168933) I am not at all happy that your health has again taken a turn for the worse.
('96', 94, 2, 18, 169010) I don’t see your articles in Harijan these days.
('96', 94, 2, 19, 169059) I should like you to go on writing something, if necessary, with somebody’s help.
('96', 94, 2, 20, 169141) For my part, I can barely cope with my work.
('96', 94, 2, 21, 169186) I have Sushila and Rajkumari with me now and hope, therefore, that I shall get their help.
('96', 94, 2, 22, 169277) Thingking over the matter, I even feel that I should stop the Harijan.
('96', 94, 2, 23, 169348) Manudi is improving gradually.
('96', 94, 2, 24, 169379) But as soon as she feels better, she starts running about and falls ill again.
('96', 94, 2, 25, 169458) As a result, I have to pay more attention to her when she is well than when she is ill.
('96', 94, 2, 26, 169546) But I see that even she is being carefull now.
('96', 94, 2, 27, 169593) Probably I shall have to go to Kashmir towards the end of this month… also is here.
('96', 94, 2, 28, 169677) She has returned ill from Noakhali.
('96', 94, 2, 29, 169713) I will see what I can do for her.
('96', 94, 2, 30, 169747) [From Gujarati]
('96', 94, 3, 31, 169763) Bihar Pachhi Dilhi, pp.

('96', 95, 1, 2, 169857) 142. A LETTER July 21, 1947 A meeting of the Working Committee is going on these days.

('96', 95, 1, 4, 170001) If there should.
('96', 95, 1, 5, 170018) be attempts going on to include Junagadh and Manavdar in Pakistan it would be nothing new, 1 though Mountbatten has said nothing so far, Much will depend on what the Kathiawar Pridnces are about.
('96', 95, 1, 6, 170214) That is why I am trying to get Balwantrai Mehta included in the Working Committee.
('96', 95, 1, 7, 170297) I have formed an impression about him that he will be a very useful man.
('96', 95, 1, 8, 170370) I see Bhai Anantrai from time to time.
('96', 95, 1, 9, 170409) He also is a very energetic man.
('96', 95, 1, 10, 170442) But one must know how to make use of the energy.
('96', 95, 1, 11, 170491) We shall have to be vigilant about Hyderabad.
('96', 95, 1, 12, 170537) Then there is Kashmir of course.
('96', 95, 1, 13, 170570) How many problems shall we be able to cope with?
('96', 95, 1, 14, 170619) The heat here has not yer come down, though there are clouds.
('96', 95, 1, 15, 170681) Let us hope the rain god will be kind now.
('96', 95, 1, 16, 170724) This heat has affected my digestion, so I have had to make drastic changes in my diet.
('96', 95, 1, 17, 170811) I don’t feel much physical weakness but towards the evening I feel mentally exhausted….
('96', 95, 1, 18, 170899) 2 How are your affairs?

('96', 96, 3, 5, 171887) 144. LETTER TO KISHORELAL G. MASHRUWALA
('96', 96, 4, 6, 171927) NEW DELHI, July 21, 1947
('96', 96, 5, 7, 171952) KISHORELAL, I have your letter.
('96', 96, 5, 8, 171984) Whether you call it my despondency or grief the cause of it is the same.
('96', 96, 5, 9, 172057) How can non violence overcome the prevailing violence?
('96', 96, 5, 10, 172112) Passing through the turmoil, I have realized that although our 30 years’ struggle could be called non violent, it was not firmly founded on non violence and so it ought not to have been so called.
('96', 96, 5, 11, 172309) If it were not regarded as non violent, my energy would not have been spent over it.
('96', 96, 5, 12, 172394) That is why God made me blind and allowed me to be used.
('96', 96, 5, 13, 172451) How can we create non violence out of what was mistakenly called non violence but which was really violence?
('96', 96, 5, 14, 172560) Isn’t it all wrong training?
('96', 96, 5, 15, 172589) How can one have the right training now, i.
('96', 96, 5, 16, 172633) e., in true non violence, after having had 30 years of wrong training?
('96', 96, 5, 17, 172704) We may name this churning of the heart anguish or anything else you like.
('96', 96, 5, 18, 172778) Is your analysis correct?
('96', 96, 5, 19, 172804) If we are cautious and take the right steps we can undo our earlier lapses.
('96', 96, 5, 20, 172880) But who will do it and how?
('96', 96, 5, 21, 172908) There is a barrier everywhere which we must cross.
('96', 96, 5, 22, 172959) So being far away don’t magnify my anguish.
('96', 96, 5, 23, 173003) I am happy.
('96', 96, 5, 24, 173015) One thing is true; the heat here does not agree with me but I don’t feel like going to the hills either.
('96', 96, 5, 25, 173120) There is nothing to worry about.
('96', 96, 6, 26, 173153) Blessings to you all from BAPU
('96', 96, 7, 27, 173184) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('96', 96, 7, 28, 173230) Courtsy: Pyarelal

('96', 97, 2, 3, 173313) NEW DELHI, July 21, 1947
('96', 97, 3, 4, 173338) SANKARAN, I like your programme of work.
('96', 97, 3, 5, 173379) If you have there all the facilities and if it benefits all, you may prolong your stay.
('96', 97, 3, 6, 173467) Of course some harm has been done by allopathy but the benefits are obvious.
('96', 97, 3, 7, 173544) Otherwise there could never have been so many hospitals.
('96', 97, 3, 8, 173601) Allopathy suits well the present atmosphere.
('96', 97, 3, 9, 173646) If you read the lives of the doctors of former times, you will know about sacrifices they made.
('96', 97, 3, 10, 173742) It is one’s duty to see the good points of the other side.
('96', 97, 3, 11, 173801) What sacrifices have the naturopaths made?
('96', 97, 3, 12, 173844) And what pretensions they have!
('96', 97, 3, 13, 173876) But the beauty is that nature cure flourishes in spite of the pretensions, the reason being that it is the natural thing.

('96', 97, 8, 18, 174101) NEW DELHI, July 21, 1947
('96', 97, 9, 19, 174126) KRISHNADAS, I have your letter.
('96', 97, 9, 20, 174158) Jinnah Saheb has himself said that non Muslims will have the same place in Pakistan as the Muslims.
('96', 97, 9, 21, 174258) But it remains to be seen whether or not such a policy is implemented.
('96', 97, 9, 22, 174329) The poor Hindus who will migrate owing to oppression will certainly be accommodated in India.
('96', 97, 9, 23, 174423) But this much is certain that they will have to labour for their bread.
('96', 97, 9, 24, 174495) I did say that those leaving behind property ought to be paid its value but I could not have said that they would be paid.
('96', 97, 9, 25, 174618) Show me if I have written anything to this effect.
('96', 97, 9, 26, 174669) I have spoken on this matter frequently enough in the course of me Noakhali speeches.

('96', 98, 1, 7, 175060) e., the Panchayat?

('96', 98, 1, 11, 175235) People raise such questions.
('96', 98, 1, 12, 175264) It is not easy to answer the second point.
('96', 98, 1, 13, 175307) An exchange of population cannot be carried out so easily.

('96', 99, 4, 9, 176631) 149. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 99, 5, 10, 176661) NEW DELHI, July 21, 1947
('96', 99, 6, 11, 176686) A friend from Pakistan writes : 1 “You in India are talking about celebrating August 15. Have you ever considered how we, the Hindus in Pakistan are going to celebrate it?
('96', 99, 6, 12, 176858) Our hearts are full of forebodings for that day, Will you say some thing about this?
('96', 99, 6, 13, 176943) For us the day will be one for confronthing troubles, not at all for celebration.
('96', 99, 6, 14, 177025) The Muslims here have already begun to frighten us.
('96', 99, 6, 15, 177077) We do not know what the Muslims in India think.
('96', 99, 6, 16, 177125) Will they also not be frightened?
('96', 99, 6, 17, 177159) We are even scared that attempts may be made to convert us on a large scale.
('96', 99, 6, 18, 177236) You will say that we must ourselves safeguard our faith.
('96', 99, 6, 19, 177293) This may be possible for an ascetic.
('96', 99, 6, 20, 177330) It is not so for a householder.” Mr. Jinnah is now going to be the Governor General of Pakistan.
('96', 99, 6, 21, 177427) He has said that non Muslims will be treated exactly as the Muslims.
('96', 99, 6, 22, 177496) My advice is that we should trust him and hope that non Muslims in Pakistan will not be ill treated.
('96', 99, 6, 23, 177597) And also the Muslims in India will not be ill treated.
('96', 99, 6, 24, 177652) My feeling is that now that there are two States, India can ask for guarantees from Pakistan.
('96', 99, 6, 25, 177746) I nevertheless feel that August 15 is not day for celebration 2
('96', 99, 7, 26, 177810) whilst the minorities contemplate the day with a heavy heart.
('96', 99, 7, 27, 177872) It will be a day for prayer and introspection.
('96', 99, 7, 28, 177919) Only, if the two countries are to be true to themselves they should start being friends right now.
('96', 99, 7, 29, 178018) Either all
('96', 99, 8, 30, 178029) 1 Vide “Letter to Krishnadas”, 21 7 1947. 2 The rest of the sentence is from The Hindustan Times.
('96', 100, 0, 1, 178127) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 101
('96', 100, 1, 2, 178173) should together celebrate August 15 as brothers or it should not be celebrated at all.
('96', 100, 1, 3, 178260) The day for rejoicing over freedom will be when we feel sincere friendship for each other.
('96', 100, 1, 4, 178351) But this is my own individual opinion and nobody seems to share it.
('96', 100, 1, 5, 178419) The same friend from Pakistan then asks me: ‘If all the Hindus of Pakistan or a very large number of them come away from Pakistan, will India give them shelter ?’ I think that such people should certainly be given shelter.
('96', 100, 1, 6, 178642) However, if the well to do among them want to live in their old style, that will be difficult.
('96', 100, 1, 7, 178737) In any case, they should certainly be given a place to live and they should be paid for their work.
('96', 100, 1, 8, 178837) But I shall continue to hope that no non Muslim will be forced to flee Pakistan out of fear and no Indian Muslim will flee his motherland.
('96', 100, 1, 9, 178976) The correspondent further asks: “What will happen to houses and landed property left behing in Pakistan ?” I have already said that the Government of Pakistan should pay the market price of the land and houses.
('96', 100, 1, 10, 179187) The practice in such matters is that the other Government also has a say.
('96', 100, 1, 11, 179261) In this case it will be the Government of India.
('96', 100, 1, 12, 179310) But why should I assume that the matter will go so far?
('96', 100, 1, 13, 179366) It will be the duty of the Government of Pakistan to pay the price of such land and houses to the owners.
('96', 100, 1, 14, 179472) The correspondent reminds me that I consider myself a practical idealist.
('96', 100, 1, 15, 179546) But what is going on in the country is in human.
('96', 100, 1, 16, 179595) Can non violence be practised towards the criminal, and if so, how?
('96', 100, 1, 17, 179663) My endeavour always has been so to practise my ideal that it should produce results even though I May not always succeed.
('96', 100, 1, 18, 179785) Whom shall I call criminal?
('96', 100, 1, 19, 179813) All those described as criminal by Manu cannot be put to death today.
('96', 100, 1, 20, 179883) Today attempts are being made to abolish capital Punishment and reformers even go so far as to advocate abolition of all corporal punishment.
('96', 100, 1, 21, 180025) They say that evil doers should be considered as sick and hospitals should be set up for them as for those suffering from other diseases.
('96', 100, 1, 22, 180163) What I mean to say is that everything that goes by the name of scripture should not be accepted as scriputure.
('96', 100, 1, 23, 180274) Only that should be accepted as scripture which takes into consideration the various changes that are continually taking place.
('96', 100, 1, 24, 180402) Attitudes keep changing from age to age.
('96', 100, 1, 25, 180443) There are few laws which remain unchanged for ever.
('96', 100, 1, 26, 180495) And then it is not everyone’s province to punish criminals.
('96', 100, 1, 27, 180555) This right belongs to the elected body or the government.
('96', 100, 1, 28, 180613) The government makes laws and then courts are set up to
('96', 101, 0, 1, 180669) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 102
('96', 101, 1, 2, 180711) dispense justic according to those laws.
('96', 101, 1, 3, 180752) If that were not so there would be the risk of all of us becoming criminals.
('96', 101, 1, 4, 180829) The murders that were committed in Burma were brutal.
('96', 101, 1, 5, 180883) Now we understand that they were political murders.
('96', 101, 1, 6, 180935) 1 I am sure that the murderers regarded their victims as criminals.
('96', 101, 1, 7, 181003) Our terrorists did not accept my advice.
('96', 101, 1, 8, 181044) They sincerely told me that those whom them murdered were criminals.
('96', 101, 1, 9, 181113) They never regarded themselves as criminals.
('96', 101, 1, 10, 181158) That is why I say that he who takes the law into his own hands commits an offence.
('96', 101, 1, 11, 181241) He commits violence against the people.
('96', 101, 1, 12, 181281) Only an elected Assembly can dispense with the obligation to be non violent.
('96', 101, 1, 13, 181358) What is happening in the world today is brutality.

('96', 102, 2, 4, 183134) 151. REALIZATION OF DIFFICULTY
('96', 102, 3, 5, 183165) An English sister reading my recent speeches giving a glimpse of my grief over the happenings in India writes :
('96', 102, 4, 6, 183277) Does not this deep agony, this descent into hell, this feeling of something near despair, mean that you ought to extend your life span even further than 125 years?
('96', 102, 4, 7, 183441) How very much easier it would be to die!.
('96', 102, 4, 8, 183483) Day and night one feels the narrow of hell.
('96', 102, 4, 9, 183527) I know that she is not joking when she expects me to extend my life span even further than 125 years.
('96', 102, 4, 10, 183629) She is a brave woman of great faith.
('96', 102, 4, 11, 183666) With me there is no question of extending my life span even to one day longer than the allotted time.
('96', 102, 4, 12, 183768) I am fatalist enough to believe that not a blade of grass moves but by His will.
('96', 102, 4, 13, 183849) What I have done and still would wish to do is to aspire after a life of 125 years, provided that it is a life of uttermost service of humanity.
('96', 102, 4, 14, 183994) But such a wish becomes quite empty if it is not accompanied by the requisite correctness of conduct.
('96', 102, 4, 15, 184096) Answering the description of a steadfast man of the Gita, such are the lines according to Sir Edwin Arnold’s rendering : 1
('96', 102, 5, 16, 184219) I confess that in spite of my trying to reach the state, I am far away from the condition of equipoise.
('96', 102, 5, 17, 184323) I realize how difficult it is in the face of the storm raging round us.
('96', 102, 5, 18, 184395) She says in the same letter :
('96', 102, 6, 19, 184425) The only comfort is that mankind, some of it, has discovered its innate impotence apart from God.
('96', 102, 6, 20, 184523) The motto in her letter head is:
('96', 102, 7, 21, 184556) In hearts too young for enmity
('96', 102, 8, 22, 184587) There lies the way to make men free.
('96', 102, 8, 23, 184624) How true and yet how difficult!
('96', 102, 8, 24, 184656) NEW DELHI, July 22, 1947 Harijan, 10 8 1947
('96', 102, 9, 25, 184700) 1 The quotation from Edwin Arnold’s Song Celestial is not reproduced here.
