('96', 107, 12, 22, 190964) 163. TALK TO REFUGEE STUDENTS
('96', 107, 13, 23, 190994) NEW DELHI, July 22, 1947
('96', 107, 14, 24, 191019) If you ask me, my advice can appeal to you only if you have no love for degrees.
('96', 107, 14, 25, 191100) Only then can I give you time.
('96', 107, 14, 26, 191131) If you want degrees you can work for them without giving thought to anything else.
('96', 107, 15, 27, 191214) 1 A khadi worker; Secretary, Gandhi Smarak Nidhi, Bihar 2 According to the source, this was addressed to a Socialist leader.
('96', 108, 0, 1, 191339) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 109
('96', 108, 1, 2, 191385) will think it natural in me, an old man from your point of view, to advise students not to run after degrees.
('96', 108, 1, 3, 191495) However it is not so.
('96', 108, 1, 4, 191517) I say what I do with the fullest sense of responsibility.
('96', 108, 1, 5, 191575) All that you learn is not real learning.
('96', 108, 1, 6, 191616) It is no more than stuffing you merely with a knowledge of the letters.
('96', 108, 1, 7, 191688) Ture education is that which proves useful in life and makes you industrious.
('96', 108, 1, 8, 191766) Students have played a big role in helping the country win its freedom.
('96', 108, 1, 9, 191838) If students forget communalism and learn humanism they can easily bring about the unity which neither the laws nor the Viceroy, nor Jawaharlal Nehru and other leaders can bring about.
('96', 108, 1, 10, 192022) Let them persuade their school fellows, their parents, their sisters and purify the atmosphere in their schools, their homes and their neighbourhood.
('96', 108, 1, 11, 192172) Student life is the foundation of life.
('96', 108, 1, 12, 192212) It is a prepara tion for adult life.
('96', 108, 1, 13, 192249) The building can be strong only if the foundation is strong.
('96', 108, 1, 14, 192310) Therefore, instead of wasting time in memorizing false history, devote yourself to true knowledge.
('96', 108, 1, 15, 192409) Certainly history will give you a sort of knowledge but you should acquire the knowledge which will provide you with food for life.
('96', 108, 1, 16, 192541) Teach sanitation in your camp, learn to look after the sick, take lessons in nursing, organize bhajans and games for recreation in the evening so that those who are unhappy may forget their sorrow for a while and be comforted, the children get some knowledge of the letters and physical exercise and learn to keep their bodies and minds clean.
('96', 108, 1, 17, 192885) The rainy season is approaching.
('96', 108, 1, 18, 192918) Make arrangements through collective labour to protect yourselves from the rains.
('96', 108, 1, 19, 193000) You can do so many such things.
('96', 108, 1, 20, 193032) If you do that you will certainly learn so many things which you will never learn in your colleges.
('96', 108, 1, 21, 193132) Knowledge gained through experience is far superior and many times more useful than bookish knowledge.
('96', 108, 1, 22, 193235) I have no doubt about that.
('96', 108, 1, 23, 193263) [From Gujarati]

('96', 109, 1, 2, 193345) 164. TALK WITH VISITORS
('96', 109, 2, 3, 193369) NEW DELHI, July 22, 1947
('96', 109, 3, 4, 193394) I do not consider myself a mahatma 1 I am, like you, an ordinary human being and want to serve the people as long as God gives me the strength to do so.
('96', 109, 3, 5, 193547) Moreover, anyone who is not distressed or ashamed by the carnage that is going on in the country must either be God or a hard hearted man.
('96', 109, 3, 6, 193686) I am neither.
('96', 109, 3, 7, 193700) I feel unhappy that every day innocent men, women and children are being murdered.
('96', 109, 3, 8, 193783) The reason for all this is that what I had believed to be non violence was not pure non violence.
('96', 109, 3, 9, 193881) I have now realized it but it is too late.
('96', 109, 3, 10, 193924) Even so I am certain that if we want to bring about peace in the world there is no other way except that of non violence.
('96', 109, 4, 11, 194046) Q. Now perhaps you will honour the British since they have willingly agreed to your terms.
('96', 109, 5, 12, 194137) G. Personally I never had any complaint against the British.
('96', 109, 5, 13, 194198) I have no likes or dislikes for persons, for I consider every individual a friend and I have benefited from this.
('96', 109, 5, 14, 194312) Let me make one thing clear.
('96', 109, 5, 15, 194341) The British are not doing us a favour in leaving the country.
('96', 109, 5, 16, 194403) They are going because circumstances have rendered their going inevitable.
('96', 109, 5, 17, 194478) They ruined India during their 150 years of rule.
('96', 109, 5, 18, 194528) They could have atoned for it if they had gone leaving the country whole.
('96', 109, 5, 19, 194602) I must say that they have taken advantage of our weakness of will to create dissensions among us, whether knowingly or unknowingly.
('96', 109, 5, 20, 194734) The fault no doubt is ours.
('96', 109, 5, 21, 194762) We were so stupid as to go to them for justice.
('96', 109, 5, 22, 194810) We should have told them, “Hand over the country to us.
('96', 109, 5, 23, 194866) We shall settle our own affairs.” It was our mis fortune that a third party had to meddle in our domestic affairs.
('96', 109, 5, 24, 194981) For this state of affairs we have to thank the power that kept us in slavery for so long.
('96', 109, 5, 25, 195071) All the same the English are my friends.
('96', 109, 5, 26, 195112) Many Englishwomen are staying with me as my daughters.
('96', 109, 5, 27, 195167) They have so many things to teach us.
('96', 109, 5, 28, 195205) I am sure if they can remain on terms of friendship with India, both the countries will benefit.
('96', 109, 5, 29, 195302) England and America have gained nothing from their advance in technology and by manufacturing atom bombs.
('96', 109, 5, 30, 195408) But I have
('96', 109, 6, 31, 195419) 1 The visitors, foreign nationals, had asked why Gandhiji, who was a maha tma, let himself be distressed by the communal carnage.
('96', 110, 0, 1, 195549) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 111
('96', 110, 1, 2, 195595) no doubt that if our so called backward country pursues the path of non violence it will have a place of glory in the world.
('96', 110, 1, 3, 195720) I may not live to see that.
('96', 110, 1, 4, 195748) My co worker Jawahar, who is like a son to me, is working hard to make my dream come true.
('96', 110, 1, 5, 195839) He will show light to the whole world.
('96', 110, 1, 6, 195878) Jawahar and his colleagues appear old.
('96', 110, 1, 7, 195917) The struggles of satyagraha and frequent incarcerations have reduced their expectation of life by twenty to twenty five years.
('96', 110, 1, 8, 196044) But I believe that not a blade of grass moves except by His will and I am, therefore, confident that though they are old their contribution in bringing stability to a totter ing world will be very significant.
('96', 110, 1, 9, 196254) [From Gujarati]
('96', 110, 2, 10, 196270) Bihar Pachhi Dilhi, pp.
('96', 110, 3, 11, 196294) 165. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 110, 4, 12, 196324) NEW DELHI, July 22, 1947
('96', 110, 5, 13, 196349) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('96', 110, 6, 14, 196371) I have received a letter today.
('96', 110, 6, 15, 196403) It says: ‘You have given Lord Miuntbatten too much of a build up.
('96', 110, 6, 16, 196469) You seem to imply that Lord Mountbatten can do no wrong.
('96', 110, 6, 17, 196526) But if you will remember at the Second Round Table Conference 1 you had said that when freedom was achieved the Viceroy’s house would be turned into a home for Harijan children or a hospital.
('96', 110, 6, 18, 196718) Your present attitude is not in conformity with this.’ I do not give anyone any kind of build up.
('96', 110, 6, 19, 196816) I want nothing from Lord Mountbatten.
('96', 110, 6, 20, 196854) And be wants nothing from me.
('96', 110, 6, 21, 196884) I do not want even titles and he has nothing else to give.
('96', 110, 6, 22, 196943) It is said that I am always rebuking my own people and never can find anything good to say of them.
('96', 110, 6, 23, 197043) So far as Lord Mountbatten is concerned he must for the moment continue to live in the Viceroy’s house.
('96', 110, 6, 24, 197147) If I could drag him out of it I would keep him with me.
('96', 110, 6, 25, 197203) But he has to meet the Princes there and rectify the mistakes of the past.
('96', 110, 6, 26, 197278) He has to undo the harm those mistakes have done.
('96', 110, 6, 27, 197328) And he has been made Governor General precisely because he can work with speed.
('96', 110, 6, 28, 197408) Giving him this office does
('96', 110, 7, 29, 197436) 1 In 1931.
('96', 111, 0, 1, 197447) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 112
('96', 111, 1, 2, 197489) not imply any flattery of him.
('96', 111, 1, 3, 197520) And do you think Jawaharlal and Sardar Patel are the kind of people to flatter anyone?
('96', 111, 1, 4, 197607) But if the Viceroy has deceit in his heart only he will be the loser.
('96', 111, 1, 5, 197677) My sixty years’ experience tells me that he who seeks to deceive other deceives only himself.
('96', 111, 1, 6, 197771) But I do not really know whether Lork Mountbatten will remain permanently in the Viceroy’s house or whether it will be made into a hospital.
('96', 111, 1, 7, 197912) Only Jawaharlal and Sardar will know about it.
('96', 111, 1, 8, 197959) Another correspondent wants to know if the proposal to retain British officers in the army and the partition of the army has my approval.
('96', 111, 1, 9, 198097) The correspondent should rather ask me if I approve of the retention of the army itself.
('96', 111, 1, 10, 198186) Keeping an army, whatever its nature or size, can have no support from me.
('96', 111, 1, 11, 198261) But times have changed.
('96', 111, 1, 12, 198285) I had fondly assumed that we were all or almost all non violent.
('96', 111, 1, 13, 198350) But my eyes have now been opened.
('96', 111, 1, 14, 198384) What I had taken to be non violence, I now see, was only passive resistance.
('96', 111, 1, 15, 198461) Passive resistance is resorted to by a person who does not have arms.
('96', 111, 1, 16, 198531) We were simply obliged to be non violent while we had violence in our hearts.
('96', 111, 1, 17, 198609) And now with the British withdrawing from India we are spending that violence in fighting against each other.
('96', 111, 1, 18, 198719) I am certain that I never had any violence in my heart.
('96', 111, 1, 19, 198775) But what am I to do about others?
('96', 111, 1, 20, 198809) They argue that the fact they were non violent in the fight against the British does not necessarily mean that they should be non violent now.
('96', 111, 1, 21, 198952) The fault is mine.
('96', 111, 1, 22, 198971) My teaching during the last thirty two years was imperfect.
('96', 111, 1, 23, 199031) If I am asked I will still say that I am not for maintaining an army.
('96', 111, 1, 24, 199101) Is India going to be a military State?
('96', 111, 1, 25, 199140) From Bengal, the Punjab and Bihar there are demands for the army to be sent.
('96', 111, 1, 26, 199217) If at one place it is Hindus who want the army to protect them, at another it is Muslims.
('96', 111, 1, 27, 199307) I therefore have no knowledge about how the army is going to be divided and I do not care to waste my time over things which do not interest me.
('96', 111, 1, 28, 199452) Four sisters came to congratulate me today because the tricolour with the weel has been adopted as the national flag of India.
('96', 111, 1, 29, 199579) I see nothing in it for congratulations.
('96', 111, 1, 30, 199620) I am told that instead of the charkha there is only a wheel on the flag.
('96', 111, 1, 31, 199693) But it is all the same to me whether they keep or do not keep the charkha.
('96', 111, 1, 32, 199768) Even if they cast it away I will still have it in my hand and in my heart.
('96', 111, 1, 33, 199843) A friend tells me that the charkha is still there on the flag.
('96', 111, 1, 34, 199906) Another friend tells me that it is not there, that it has been discarded
('96', 112, 0, 1, 199979) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 113
('96', 112, 1, 2, 200025) even while I am still alive.
('96', 112, 1, 3, 200054) I do not know.
('96', 112, 1, 4, 200069) What I do know is that even if the charkha wass shown on the flag but was not in people’s hearts, both the flag and the charkha would be fit only to be burnt.
('96', 112, 1, 5, 200228) But if the charkha had a place in the hearts of the people, then it would not matter whether it was placed on the flag or not.
('96', 112, 1, 6, 200355) I only want that the country should have only one flag and everyone shold salute it.
('96', 112, 1, 7, 200440) It made me very happy to hear that in the Constituent Assembly both Chowdhary Khaliq uz Zaman and Mohammed Sadullah, saluted the flag and declared that they would be loyal to the Nationla Flag.
('96', 112, 1, 8, 200634) If they mean it, it is a good sign.
('96', 112, 1, 9, 200670) But a telegram received from Sylhet is very disturbing.
('96', 112, 1, 10, 200726) The referendum there is over but harassment of the people continues.
('96', 112, 1, 11, 200795) Why have the Muslims there gone crazy?
('96', 112, 1, 12, 200834) Nationalist Muslims are being killed and the telegram says that someone should be sent there as an observer.
('96', 112, 1, 13, 200943) Whom can I send?
('96', 112, 1, 14, 200960) It is only for Kripalani or Jawaharlal to find someone.
('96', 112, 1, 15, 201016) I feel I ought to go to Noakhali now.
('96', 112, 1, 16, 201054) Sylhet is close to Noakhali.
('96', 112, 1, 17, 201083) But how can I go?
('96', 112, 1, 18, 201101) I am imprisoned here.
('96', 112, 1, 19, 201123) I am convinced that there is not a word of untruth in the telegram.
('96', 112, 1, 20, 201191) The sender has signed his name too.
('96', 112, 1, 21, 201227) It is reported that after the referendum Muslims burnt down a Harijan colony.
('96', 112, 1, 22, 201305) It is a matter of shame.
('96', 112, 1, 23, 201330) On one side we have Khaliq Saheb and Sadullah Saheb saluting the National Flag, on the other side in Pakistan such grisly things go on.
('96', 112, 1, 24, 201466) From Karachi comes a letter.
('96', 112, 1, 25, 201495) It is from a rich man who says that the Pakistan Government has taken over his house.
('96', 112, 1, 26, 201581) He is in a quandary, for he has nowhere to live.

('96', 115, 6, 12, 205000) You suggest that the Government should promote education by spending crores of rupees and setting up universities.

('96', 115, 6, 14, 205148) There is no dearth in our country of people who have an interest in education.
('96', 115, 6, 15, 205227) There are thousands and hundreds of thousands of them.
('96', 115, 6, 16, 205282) They should form an organization and take up this work.
('96', 115, 6, 17, 205338) A cultivator who wishes to grow corn ploughs and sows the field at the right time.
('96', 115, 6, 18, 205421) If educationists, similarly, utilize this opportunity and work along the right lines in this field, their institutions will overflow with money.
('96', 115, 6, 19, 205566) The university will be able to maintain itself through the labour of the students who join it.
('96', 115, 6, 20, 205661) And if it becomes a people’s institution, the public also will help of their own accord.
('96', 115, 6, 21, 205750) True, it will also need some Government help, which it will certainly get.
('96', 115, 6, 22, 205825) If, however, the university is run along the lines I have indicated, it will become self supporting.

('96', 118, 5, 10, 209074) 177. TALK TO MAHARANI OF NABHA
('96', 118, 6, 11, 209105) NEW DELHI, July 23, 1947 You have willingly divested yourself of these things.
('96', 118, 6, 12, 209184) 1 Similarly the State treasury does not belong to you.
('96', 118, 6, 13, 209239) It belongs to the people.
('96', 118, 6, 14, 209265) You have been appointed by them a trustee.
('96', 118, 6, 15, 209308) I wish you would keep an account of every pie as a trustee does of the public trust.
('96', 118, 6, 16, 209393) Keep your personal needs within bounds.
('96', 118, 6, 17, 209433) You will render a great service to middle class women and make an impression on the State if like other women you manage your household yourself and do all the domestic chores of the palace.
('96', 118, 6, 18, 209624) How can you have any idea of the plight of middle class women?
('96', 118, 6, 19, 209687) I know their plight because I take an interest in their lives.
('96', 118, 6, 20, 209750) They hesitate to do any work from a false sense of shame.
('96', 118, 6, 21, 209808) If they have not enough to eat in the house they will put up with it.
('96', 118, 6, 22, 209878) Let alone doing any work themselves, in order to keep up the prestige of the house they think it necessary to have a servant to clean the house, fetch water and do the grinding.
('96', 118, 6, 23, 210056) This is sin.
('96', 118, 6, 24, 210069) For this, the rich are to blame.
('96', 118, 6, 25, 210102) Their women live in affluence and not only do no work themselves but pass remarks on those who do.
('96', 118, 6, 26, 210201) In Europe even men lend a hand in domestic chores.
('96', 118, 6, 27, 210252) As a result women have too much free time, they become lazy and lose self confidence.
('96', 118, 6, 28, 210338) That is why I say the times have changed.
('96', 118, 6, 29, 210380) Ladies of ruling families and rich classes should not miss this opportunity they have got of doing service.
('96', 118, 7, 30, 210488) 1 The Maharani had presented to Gandhiji her gold bangles.
('96', 119, 0, 1, 210547) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 119, 1, 2, 210589) they take to doing household work they will create an atmosphere in which doing such work will no longer be regarded dishonourable but on the contrary will be respected.
('96', 119, 1, 3, 210759) As a result the financial condition of the downtrodden middle class will improve and with it the education of their children, their health and their living condition also will improve.
('96', 119, 1, 4, 210944) We can then feel proud of our country.
('96', 119, 1, 5, 210983) [From Gujarati]

('96', 119, 3, 7, 211023) 178. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 119, 4, 8, 211053) NEW DELHI, July 23, 1947
('96', 119, 5, 9, 211078) Before the prayers started someone passed a note to Gandhiji.
('96', 119, 5, 10, 211140) In it the writer had asked him whether he had seen God face to face.
('96', 119, 5, 11, 211209) Answering the question after prayers, Gandhiji said that he had not seen God face to face.
('96', 119, 5, 12, 211300) If he had, he would have no need to be speaking to them.
('96', 119, 5, 13, 211357) His thought would be potent enough to render speech and action on his part unnecessary.
('96', 119, 5, 14, 211445) But he had an undying faith in the existence of God.
('96', 119, 5, 15, 211498) Millions all over the world shared that faith with him.
('96', 119, 5, 16, 211554) The most learned could not shake the faith of illiterate millions.
('96', 119, 5, 17, 211621) The bhajan sung during the prayers described the way to see God face to face.
('96', 119, 5, 18, 211699) The poet asked the aspirant to shed anger and desire and to be indifferent to praise or blame if he expected to reach the blessed state.
('96', 119, 5, 19, 211836) Gandhiji compared nirvana to Ramarajya or the Kingdom of Heaven on earth.
('96', 119, 5, 20, 211910) The dream of Ramarajya was far from realization.
('96', 119, 5, 21, 211959) How could it happen when they had all along been nursing violence in their hearts under the garb of non violence?
('96', 119, 6, 22, 212073) Today I wish to say something about salt.
('96', 119, 6, 23, 212115) People say there was a time when I had marched to Dandi for salt but today there is no salt to be had or, if there is, an exorbitant price has to be paid for it.
('96', 119, 6, 24, 212277) I can only bow down my head in shame.
('96', 119, 6, 25, 212315) People say that although salt tax has been abolished it has not affected the price.
('96', 119, 6, 26, 212399) Salt is not rationed but there is black marketing in it.
('96', 119, 6, 27, 212456) Traders are so mean that they derive huge profits even from salt.
('96', 119, 6, 28, 212522) But we have become lazy.
('96', 119, 6, 29, 212547) There are many places in the countryside where people can make salt for themselves at no cost.
('96', 119, 6, 30, 212642) This concession had been got even at the time of my agreement 2 with Lord Irwin.
('96', 119, 6, 31, 212723) If we were not lazy we would be getting salt not only cheap but also clean.
('96', 119, 6, 32, 212799) The salt available
('96', 119, 7, 33, 212818) 1 This paragraph is from The Hindustan Times, 24 7 1947 2 Vide “Provisional Settlement”, 12 3 1913.
('96', 120, 0, 1, 212918) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 121
('96', 120, 1, 2, 212964) in the market is very dirty.
('96', 120, 1, 3, 212993) The reason is that people do not take pains.
('96', 120, 1, 4, 213038) The salt that was given to me in jail I used to clean myself.
('96', 120, 1, 5, 213100) We have become so selfish today that we cannot even let people have salt at a low price.
('96', 120, 1, 6, 213189) How can we call a regime Ramarajya where even salt is denied to the people?
('96', 120, 1, 7, 213265) Salt is needed not only for human beings but also for animals.
('96', 120, 1, 8, 213328) What I fear is that now as a consequence of partition both the countries will need to increase their revenues and they may impose tax on salt.
('96', 120, 1, 9, 213471) But will they be so lacking in sense as to deprive people even of salt?
('96', 120, 1, 10, 213543) If that happens, too great a price will have been paid for freedom.
('96', 120, 1, 11, 213611) [From Hindi]
('96', 120, 2, 12, 213624) Prarthana Pravachan–I, pp.

('96', 127, 4, 13, 223491) 191. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 127, 5, 14, 223521) NEW DELHI, July 24, 1947
('96', 127, 6, 15, 223546) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, As I have said/repeatedly, when one is at prayer or engaged in similar sacred activity one does not smoke.
('96', 127, 6, 16, 223675) Christians drink and smoke a good deal but I have never yet seen a Christian drinking or smoking when in a church.
('96', 127, 6, 17, 223790) The same rule applies to mosques and gurudwaras.
('96', 127, 6, 18, 223839) This place of course can be called a temple, a church or a mosque, since our prayer consists of texts taken from every religion.
('96', 127, 6, 19, 223968) It would be good if you gave up smoking.
('96', 127, 6, 20, 224009) Though I know that you are not going to do so on my asking you, still those who want to smoke can go out of the congregation and do so.
('96', 127, 6, 21, 224145) Then some people get up and walk away while the prayer is still going on.
('96', 127, 6, 22, 224219) It may be they do not find it interesting.
('96', 127, 6, 23, 224262) But interesting or not, our purpose after all is to utter the name of God.
('96', 127, 6, 24, 224337) The rule is that till the prayer is ended—and it is I who end it—no one should leave.
('96', 127, 6, 25, 224423) The Charkha Sangh has a stock of old tri colour flags valued at Rs. 2 lakhs.
('96', 127, 6, 26, 224500) The Charkha Sangh is an organization of very poor
('96', 127, 7, 27, 224550) 1 Omissions as in the source 2 The reference, presumably, is to ‘‘Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel’’; vide 24 7 1947.
('96', 128, 0, 1, 224663) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 129
('96', 128, 1, 2, 224709) people.
('96', 128, 1, 3, 224717) I am its President.
('96', 128, 1, 4, 224737) The people working in that organization are paid very little.
('96', 128, 1, 5, 224799) They want to know what they are to do with the flags.
('96', 128, 1, 6, 224853) There is not much difference between the new and the old flag except that the old one was a little more elegant.
('96', 128, 1, 7, 224966) The old flag had the charkha.
('96', 128, 1, 8, 224996) The new one has the wheel but not the spindle and the mal.
('96', 128, 1, 9, 225055) The new flag does not render the old flag redundant.
('96', 128, 1, 10, 225108) Even after the king is dead, the kingdom remains and old coins are not discarded for the new ones.
('96', 128, 1, 11, 225207) When the new coins are issued old coins do not suffer any depreciation of value.
('96', 128, 1, 12, 225288) Therefore, so long as there is even one old flag in stock at the Gandhi Ashram the two flags will have the same value.
('96', 128, 1, 13, 225407) People who have old flags should not tear them up and if they want to buy more flags they should buy the same flags from the Gandhi Ashram so that Rs. 2 lakhs worth of goods are not wasted.
('96', 128, 1, 14, 225597) Of course in future the Charkha Sangh will make flags only of the new design.
('96', 128, 1, 15, 225675) I have two questions before me today.
('96', 128, 1, 16, 225713) A correspondent wants to know what will happen to the Congress after August 15 and what its programme will be.
('96', 128, 1, 17, 225824) He says that till now anyone wishing to join the Congress had to swear an oath that he would fight for the freedom of India through truthful and non violent means.
('96', 128, 1, 18, 225988) Now that freedom of India has been won he wants to know what the position will be.
('96', 128, 1, 19, 226071) The Congress alone can tell what its programme will be.
('96', 128, 1, 20, 226127) As a humble servant of the Congress I know that so long the task before us had been to fight foreign rule.
('96', 128, 1, 21, 226234) We became rebels and we dislodged that rule.
('96', 128, 1, 22, 226279) Outwardly we followed truth and non violence.
('96', 128, 1, 23, 226325) But inwardly there was violence in us.
('96', 128, 1, 24, 226364) We practised hypocrisy and as a result we have to suffer the pain of mutual strife.
('96', 128, 1, 25, 226448) Even today we are nurturing attitudes that will result in war and if this drift is not stopped we shall find ourselves in a conflict much more sanguinary than the Mutiny of 1857. India then did not have enough awakening and the mutiny was confined only to the sepoys.
('96', 128, 1, 26, 226716) All that we did was to cut down Englishmen.
('96', 128, 1, 27, 226760) In the end the British army overcame the mutineers.
('96', 128, 1, 28, 226812) God forbid that the present strife should ever assume such dimensions.
('96', 128, 1, 29, 226883) Therefore not only out of regard for truth and non violence but also in the interest of the country, for which hundreds of thousands faced imprisonment and suffered hardships, I shall appeal to you not to prepare for warfare.
('96', 128, 1, 30, 227109) For by so doing you will not only lose the country’s freedom but you will send it back into slavery.
('96', 128, 1, 31, 227210) England,
('96', 129, 0, 1, 227219) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 129, 1, 2, 227261) Russia, America or China—any of these countries may attack and enslave us.
('96', 129, 1, 3, 227336) Do you, on the fifteenth of August, went to witness the spectacle of Hindus fighting Muslims and the Sikhs being crushed between the belligerents?
('96', 129, 1, 4, 227483) I would rather that there was an earthquake and we all were crushed to death.
('96', 129, 1, 5, 227561) Therefore since the Congress belongs to all India it should see to it that Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, and all the other communities are kept happy.
('96', 129, 1, 6, 227707) I do not suggest that you should try to appease the Muslims or become cowards.
('96', 129, 1, 7, 227786) I have never advocated cowardice.
('96', 129, 1, 8, 227820) We should bravely pacify the people.
('96', 129, 1, 9, 227857) This should be the chief programme of the Congress.
('96', 129, 1, 10, 227909) Although I have been President of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan twice it is my firm opinion that Hindi in Devanagari script can never become the national language of India.
('96', 129, 1, 11, 228079) Today many of our leaders say that Gandhi talks nonsense.
('96', 129, 1, 12, 228137) He is always out to appease the Muslims.
('96', 129, 1, 13, 228178) Jinnah Saheb, however, while talking of two nations had accused me of wiping out Urdu.
('96', 129, 1, 14, 228265) Thus today I am regarded as an enemy of both the languages.
('96', 129, 1, 15, 228325) But I want to remain a friend of both.
('96', 129, 1, 16, 228364) My claim that if there is any true friend of India, it is Gandhi, will be vindicated in the eyes of God.
('96', 129, 1, 17, 228469) I can even today point out so many Hindus who neither know Hindi nor can write In Devanagari.
('96', 129, 1, 18, 228563) We will have to adopt a language which is a mixture of Hindi and Urdu as the national language if Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsis and Sikhs are to live here.
('96', 129, 1, 19, 228725) I have no doubt that the language you speak can become a great language.
('96', 129, 1, 20, 228798) An Indonesian leader Sjahrir is on a visit here.
('96', 129, 1, 21, 228847) He will meet Jawaharlal Nehru and Mr. Jinnah.
('96', 129, 1, 22, 228893) India can give Indonesia its moral support which will be more effective than any military aid.
('96', 129, 1, 23, 228988) An Englishman says in a letter that now that India has been partitioned it will no longer have the status of a great nation.
('96', 129, 1, 24, 229113) I do not agree, provided the two parts remain friendly with each other.
('96', 129, 1, 25, 229185) [From Hindi]

('96', 130, 9, 20, 229920) 194. HINDI v.
('96', 130, 9, 21, 229934) HINDUSTANI
('96', 130, 10, 22, 229945) Shrimati Perinbehn Captain writes : 4
('96', 130, 11, 23, 229983) It was with shame, disgust and sorrow that I heard on the Delhi radio that our own group of men wished to dethrone our national language.
('96', 130, 11, 24, 230121) Please write to me fully what you would like: (1) our Hindustani Committee to do, (2)
('96', 130, 12, 25, 230207) 1 The letter was reported under the date line Ahmedabad, July 25. 2 The addressee, an old associate, had asked Gandhiji to return to Ahmedabad as Gandhiji had pledged on the eve of the Dandi March to go back to Sabarmati Ashram only after India attained swaraj.
('96', 130, 12, 26, 230469) 3 Gandhiji was referring to Hindustani Culture Society’s letter head used by the addressee.
('96', 130, 12, 27, 230561) 4 Only extracts from the letter are reproduced here.
('96', 131, 0, 1, 230614) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 131, 1, 2, 230656) our honest and self sacrificing Hindustani pracharaks to do, and (3) last but not least, those of our countrymen—Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, Christians and Jews, who have accepted and loved Hindustani as understood by the Congress resolution, to do .
('96', 131, 2, 3, 230904) Please try and prevent our friends from losing their vision through hatred and thereby losing all hopes of linking in true friendship and love the whole country from Kashmir to Kanya Kumari and Assam to Sind.
('96', 131, 2, 4, 231113) This represents the common grief of many nationalists like her, labelled congressmen or not.
('96', 131, 2, 5, 231206) Since this letter was written the threat has been postponed for two months or until such time as the Constituent Assembly meets again.
('96', 131, 2, 6, 231341) It is a wise postponement which gives time for passions to cool down in order to allow clear thinking.
('96', 131, 2, 7, 231444) Let the Hindu, by their conduct, direct or indirect, disprove the Muslim League statement that we, the Hindus and the Muslims of India, are not one nation but two and that too because of our respective religions.
('96', 131, 2, 8, 231657) Congressmen have declared from the very inception of the Congress that India is one nation composed of men belonging to all religions and sects known in the whole world and it has proved the claim often enough at crucial moments in spite of many lapses which it would be easy to fling in its face.
('96', 131, 2, 9, 231955) Dadabhai Naoroji, whose grand daughter has written the above letter with so much feeling, has become and still remains the only Grand Old Man of India.
('96', 131, 2, 10, 232107) Pherozeshah Mehta became the uncrowned king of the Bombay Presidency and after Dadabhai Naoroji’s death ruled the Congress by right of service unselfishly rendered.
('96', 131, 2, 11, 232272) Who was Badruddin Tyabjee—at one time President of the Congress?
('96', 131, 2, 12, 232337) Was he not a Mussalman every inch of him?
('96', 131, 2, 13, 232379) Was he any the less an Indian?
('96', 131, 2, 14, 232410) India has many religions but only one nationality and this, I dare to say, in spite of its two divisions.
('96', 131, 2, 15, 232516) They may persist for a long time, but we must not be enemies one of the other for a single minute.
('96', 131, 2, 16, 232615) It takes two to make a quarrel, but friendship does not require reciprocity.
('96', 131, 2, 17, 232692) That which requires reciprocity is a bargain.
('96', 131, 2, 18, 232738) This friendship, otherwise called love or non violence, belongs not to the cowardly but to the brave and the seeing.
('96', 131, 2, 19, 232855) I entirely endorse Perinbehn’s remark that not Hindi, highly Sanskritized written in the Nagari characters, nor Urdu, highly Persianized written in the Urdu characters, can even be the link between two or more communities in India.
('96', 131, 2, 20, 233087) It can only be Hindustani
('96', 132, 0, 1, 233113) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 133
('96', 132, 1, 2, 233159) which is a fusion of the two forms robbed of their artificial character and written either in the Nagari or the Urdu characters.
('96', 132, 1, 3, 233288) This natural fusion has been going on for many years and like all natural processes, it has been slow but nonetheless sure.
('96', 132, 1, 4, 233412) It does not matter to me whether any Muslim brother reciprocates or not, by trying to understand my form of speech or writing, but surely I am richer for endeavouring to understand his form of speech and writing.
('96', 132, 1, 5, 233625) Speaking to many Muslim divines I have not found it difficult to explain my meaning through Hindustani, though I have never attempted to pretend to speak their high flown Persianized Urdu.
('96', 132, 1, 6, 233814) They have as a rule been the losers and I invariably the gainer.
('96', 132, 1, 7, 233879) What is true of me is true, I am sure, of many more.
('96', 132, 1, 8, 233932) Now about her main questions: Every member of the Hindustani Committee is to live up to his creed, that is to say, he or she should himself or herself master both the scripts and be familiar with a mixture of the two forms, Hindi and Urdu.
('96', 132, 1, 9, 234172) This will happen when both are diligently studied in their simple forms.
('96', 132, 1, 10, 234245) And when this first requisite is fulfilled, he or she must try to induce others to acquire the knowledge.
('96', 132, 1, 11, 234351) Secondly, if the Hindustani pracharaks are honest and sacrificing they are bound to infect their surroundings with the spirit that actuates them.
('96', 132, 1, 12, 234497) Thirdly, those who have accepted Hindustani as the national language of the whole of India and love it, have to prove their acceptance by speaking and writing only in Hindustani, when it is meant for those who do not know the mother tongue.
('96', 132, 1, 13, 234738) Thus a Tamilian will speak only in Tamil to a fellow Tamilian, but with a non Tamilian he will make use of Hindustani and not English as is now the wont.
('96', 132, 1, 14, 234892) NEW DELHI, July 25, 1947 Harijan, 3 8 1947
('96', 132, 2, 15, 234935) 195. SCHEDULED CASTES
('96', 132, 3, 16, 234957) A correspondent writes:
('96', 132, 4, 17, 234981) If the Scheduled Castes of x area are included in Pakistan, they would probably have no alternative other than embracing Islam.
('96', 132, 4, 18, 235109) The correspondent is well educated and is an M.L.A. The question immediately arises as to what will happen to the Scheduled Caste member in the Pakistan areas where they are not living in
('96', 133, 0, 1, 235297) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 133, 1, 2, 235339) contiguous areas.
('96', 133, 1, 3, 235357) Will they all have to embrace Islam?
('96', 133, 1, 4, 235394) I can only say that their religion must be very poor stuff if it admits of change like one’s clothes.
('96', 133, 1, 5, 235496) Religion (binding faith)‚ is made of sterner stuff; it is a deep personal matter, more personal than honour.
('96', 133, 1, 6, 235605) To be true, it must be able to defy coercion of the extremest type.
('96', 133, 1, 7, 235673) So much for those who are in fear of compulsory conversion.
('96', 133, 1, 8, 235733) But what about those who inspire men and women with such fear?
('96', 133, 1, 9, 235796) I have heard it seriously argued that people have often mistaken voluntary for compulsory conversion.
('96', 133, 1, 10, 235898) I think the argument does not carry any conviction.
('96', 133, 1, 11, 235950) People have been known in all ages to resort to conversion when they have known their friends, relations or neighbours to profess conversion under duress.
('96', 133, 1, 12, 236105) When, therefore, there is suspicion all round, conversion should be stopped altogether.
('96', 133, 1, 13, 236193) Here I remind myself of the argument of the correspondent used only the other day that my ‘brave’ words about personal religion would be all right if they were confined to sannyasis but not to householders who were exposed to a variety of temptations from life.
('96', 133, 1, 14, 236455) Though I do not endorse this argument, for it weakens those on whose behalf it is led, I cannot help feeling that there is considerable force in it, especially when it is made applicable to members of the Scheduled Castes who have been ill treated by their fellow Hindus and would, therefore, yield to compulsion in the hope of avoiding ill treatment from their fellows who arrogate to themselves superiority, falsely so called.
('96', 133, 1, 15, 236884) Frequently this compulsion assumes subtle forms, as for instance, free grants of land or offer of service even beyond merit.
('96', 133, 1, 16, 237009) NEW DELHI, July 25, 1947 Harijan, 3 8 1947

('96', 134, 5, 7, 237646) BHANGI COLONY, NEW DELHI, July 25, 1947
('96', 134, 6, 8, 237686) DEAR MR. ROCK, What you ask for is essentially American.
('96', 134, 6, 9, 237743) I must confess my ignorance of La Prensa and in any case I do not feel inclined to lend myself to self advertisement or the advertisement of a newspaper or an institution.
('96', 134, 6, 10, 237915) I have come to the conclusion that men and things must be judged on their own merits and not on certificates of merit, however well earned they may be.
('96', 134, 6, 11, 238067) When I went to London as a lad, I was brought up to think that I must procure certificates about all kinds of things and I had some.
('96', 134, 6, 12, 238200) On my way back, I tore all the certificates I had had from friends about various things I had done or had not done and consigned them to the sea.

('96', 136, 5, 10, 240209) July 25, 1947 In the first place.
('96', 136, 5, 11, 240243) if people change their religion as they change their clothes every day or every hour, religion will lose all its power.
('96', 136, 5, 12, 240363) One’s religion represents the priceless spirit of resolution arising from deep faith.
('96', 136, 5, 13, 240449) If the strength of resolution is rooted in the heart, it will not yield or submit to any amount of force or coercion.

('96', 136, 7, 16, 240606) 203. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 136, 8, 17, 240636) NEW DELHI, July 25, 1947
('96', 136, 9, 18, 240661) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Rajendra Babu tells me that he has received some 50,000 postcards, between 25‚000 and 30‚000 letters and many thousands of telegrams demanding a ban on cow slaughter.
('96', 136, 9, 19, 240850) I spoke to you about this before.
('96', 136, 9, 20, 240884) Why this flood of telegrams and letters?
('96', 136, 9, 21, 240925) They have had no effect.
('96', 136, 9, 22, 240950) I have another telegram which says that a friend has started a fast for this cause.
('96', 136, 9, 23, 241034) In India no law can be made to ban cow slaughter.
('96', 136, 9, 24, 241084) I do not doubt that Hindus are forbidden the slaughter of cows.
('96', 136, 9, 25, 241148) I have been long pledged to serve the cow but how can my religion also be
('96', 137, 0, 1, 241222) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 137, 1, 2, 241264) the religion of the rest of the Indians?
('96', 137, 1, 3, 241305) It will mean coercion against those Indians who are not Hindus.
('96', 137, 1, 4, 241369) We have been shouting from the house tops that there will be no coercion in the matter of religion.
('96', 137, 1, 5, 241469) We have been reciting verses from the Koran at the prayer.
('96', 137, 1, 6, 241528) But if anyone were to force me to recite these verses I would not like it.
('96', 137, 1, 7, 241603) How can I force anyone not to slaughter cows unless he is himself so disposed?
('96', 137, 1, 8, 241682) It is not as if there were only Hindu in the Indian Union.
('96', 137, 1, 9, 241741) There are Muslims, Parsis, Christians and other religious groups here.
('96', 137, 1, 10, 241812) The assumption of the Hindus that India now has become the land of the Hindus is erroneous.
('96', 137, 1, 11, 241904) India belongs to all who live here.
('96', 137, 1, 12, 241940) If we stop cow slaughter by law here and the very reverse happens in Pakistan, what will be the result?
('96', 137, 1, 13, 242044) Supposing they say Hindus would not be allowed to visit temples because it was against Shariat to worship idols?
('96', 137, 1, 14, 242157) I see God even in a stone but how do I harm others by this belief?
('96', 137, 1, 15, 242224) If therefore I am stopped from visiting temples I would still visit them.
('96', 137, 1, 16, 242298) I shall therefore suggest that these telegrams and letters should cease.
('96', 137, 1, 17, 242371) It is not proper to waste money on them.
('96', 137, 2, 18, 242412) Besides some prosperous Hindus themselves encourage cow slaughter.
('96', 137, 2, 19, 242479) They do not do it with their own hands.
('96', 137, 2, 20, 242519) But who sends all the cows to Australia and other countries where they are slaughtered and whence shoes manufactured from cow hide are sent back to India?
('96', 137, 2, 21, 242674) I know an orthodox Vaishnava Hindu.
('96', 137, 2, 22, 242710) He used to feed this children on beef soup.
('96', 137, 2, 23, 242754) On my asking him why he did that he said there was no sin in consuming beef as medicine.
('96', 137, 2, 24, 242843) We really do not stop to think what true religion is and merely go about shouting that cow slaughter should be banned by law.
('96', 137, 2, 25, 242969) In villages Hindus make bullocks carry huge burdens which almost crush the animals.
('96', 137, 2, 26, 243053) Is it not cow slaughter, albeit slowly carried out?
('96', 137, 2, 27, 243105) I shall therefore suggest that the matter should not be pressed in the Constituent Assembly.
('96', 137, 2, 28, 243198) Where trees are in abundance, rainfall too is abundant.
('96', 137, 2, 29, 243254) The foliage in a forest attracts precipitation from clouds like milk from the udder of a cow.
('96', 137, 2, 30, 243348) It is a law of nature that where there are no trees there is no rainfall and the land soon becomes a desert.
('96', 137, 2, 31, 243457) I spent many years in Johannesburg.
('96', 137, 2, 32, 243493) The climate there is very salubrious.
('96', 137, 2, 33, 243531) After they planted trees there, rainfall too has been favourable.
('96', 137, 2, 34, 243597) Therefore the programme of tree planting that the authorities in Delhi have started is a very good thing.
('96', 137, 2, 35, 243703) Those who have no spare patch of ground can still
('96', 138, 0, 1, 243753) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 139
('96', 138, 1, 2, 243799) grow vegetables in earthen pots.
('96', 138, 1, 3, 243832) I have been asked, ‘Since in view of the atrocities being perpetuated by Muslims it is difficult to decide which of the Mus lims are to be trusted, what should be our attitude towards the Muslims in the Indian Union?
('96', 138, 1, 4, 244049) What should the non Muslims in Pakistan do?’ I have already answered this question.
('96', 138, 1, 5, 244133) I again repeat that all the religions of India today are being put to the test.
('96', 138, 1, 6, 244213) It has to be seen how the various religious groups such as the Sikhs, the Hindus, the Muslims and the Christians conduct themselves and how they carry on the affairs of India.
('96', 138, 1, 7, 244389) Pakistan may be said to belong to Muslims but the Indian Union belongs to all.
('96', 138, 1, 8, 244468) If you shake off cowardice and become brave you will not have to consider how you are to behave towards the Muslims.
('96', 138, 1, 9, 244585) But today there is cowardice in us.
('96', 138, 1, 10, 244621) For this I have already accepted the blame.
('96', 138, 1, 11, 244665) I am still wondering how my 30 years’ teaching has been so ineffective.
('96', 138, 1, 12, 244737) Why did I assume, to begin with, that non violence could be a weapon of cowards?
('96', 138, 1, 13, 244818) Even now if we can really become brave and love the Muslims, the Muslims will have to stop and think what they could gain by practising treachery against us.
('96', 138, 1, 14, 244976) They will return love for love.
('96', 138, 1, 15, 245008) Can we keep the crores of Muslims in the Indian Union as slaves?
('96', 138, 1, 16, 245073) He who makes slaves of others himself becomes a slave.
('96', 138, 1, 17, 245128) If we answer sword with sword, the lathi with lathi and kick with kick, we cannot expect that things will be different in Pakistan.
('96', 138, 1, 18, 245260) We shall then lose our freedom as easily as we have gained it.
('96', 138, 1, 19, 245323) I like the statement that has been issued on behalf of the future Governments of India and Pakistan.
('96', 138, 1, 20, 245424) But I wish to see it implemented.
('96', 138, 1, 21, 245458) However, we cannot assume that they will not do in Pakistan what the statement says.
('96', 138, 1, 22, 245543) To assume this will mean preparing for war.
('96', 138, 1, 23, 245587) The two armies will confront each other and the two nation theory of Mr. Jinnah will have been proved true.
('96', 138, 1, 24, 245695) I pray to God that He may not let us drift into such a situation.
('96', 138, 1, 25, 245761) [From Hindi]
('96', 138, 2, 26, 245774) Prarthana Pravachan I, pp.
('96', 139, 0, 1, 245801) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 139, 1, 2, 245843) 204. DISCUSSION WITH A CONGRESSMAN 1
('96', 139, 2, 3, 245880) NEW DELHI, [Before July 26, 1947] 2
('96', 139, 3, 4, 245916) A Congressman came to Gandhiji the other day asking him how he would
('96', 139, 4, 5, 245985) reorganize the Congress under the new set up.
('96', 139, 4, 6, 246031) Gandhiji was emphatic that if the
('96', 139, 5, 7, 246065) Congress was to live as a potent force, it must become a body of constructive
('96', 139, 6, 8, 246143) workers.
('96', 139, 6, 9, 246152) Constructive work, he knew, had never been over popular.
('96', 139, 6, 10, 246209) He thought that
('96', 139, 7, 11, 246225) it was never more necessary than now.
('96', 139, 7, 12, 246263) Without the backing of constructive work and
('96', 139, 8, 13, 246308) penetrating the villages, their legislators would practically be idle and the voters
('96', 139, 9, 14, 246393) would be exposed to the machinations of the vote catchers.
('96', 139, 9, 15, 246452) The labour vote would
('96', 139, 10, 16, 246474) presently be a drop in the ocean in the face of adult suffrage both for men and women.
('96', 139, 11, 17, 246561) It was probably the boldest experiment known to the world on a vast scale.
('96', 139, 11, 18, 246636) Unless it
('96', 139, 12, 19, 246646) was well planned and all attendant dangers anticipated and provided against, adult
('96', 139, 13, 20, 246729) suffrage might well prove a deluge drowning the whole country.
('96', 139, 13, 21, 246792) He (Gandhiji) knew
('96', 139, 14, 22, 246811) nothing so effective for the purpose as a well thought out constructive programme.
('96', 139, 14, 23, 246894) Harijan, 3 8 1947

('96', 141, 2, 4, 248631) I wholly agree with you that the number of years a person lives in this world is of no consequence whether to him or to the world but even a day spent in true service of mankind is of supreme and only importance.
('96', 141, 2, 5, 248844) I further agree with you that hope and faith are as often as not synonymous terms.
('96', 141, 2, 6, 248927) Of course good is eternal, evil transitory.

('96', 141, 2, 9, 249157) I am sure you will agree with me that a man of peace is out of place in a society full of strife.
('96', 141, 2, 10, 249255) He must know this fact and yet work and act in that society.
('96', 141, 2, 11, 249316) I wonder if I have at all made my meaning clear.
('96', 141, 2, 12, 249365) There is no such thing as surrender in me to the spirit of evil.

('96', 142, 12, 21, 250752) I have not mixed up socialism with sociology.

('96', 143, 1, 2, 251241) 214. A LETTER
('96', 143, 2, 3, 251255) July 26, 1947 I have your letter.
('96', 143, 2, 4, 251289) If a man believes that a peepul tree is haunted by a ghost, he will not get rid of his fear by going to the tree again and again.
('96', 143, 2, 5, 251419) Only if he visits the tree several times in the company of a person who does not share his fear and nothing happens to him, will his fear go.
('96', 143, 2, 6, 251561) This can happen in the case of brahmacharya only if a man of conventional ideas lives in the company of a perfect brahmachari from time to time.
('96', 143, 2, 7, 251706) But then, how are we to find such a brahmachari?
('96', 143, 2, 8, 251755) And who will accept such a claim by anybody?
('96', 143, 2, 9, 251800) The example of the peepul tree and the ghost is applicable only up to a certain point.
('96', 143, 2, 10, 251887) I hope you know that I have never claimed that I am a perfect brahmachari.
('96', 143, 2, 11, 251962) When shall I know that state supreme, When will the knots outer and inner snap?
('96', 143, 2, 12, 252042) I write this for a seeker.
('96', 143, 2, 13, 252069) Just now it is not germane to go further than this.
('96', 143, 2, 14, 252121) If the seeker finds his path, it might be pertinent to go further.
('96', 143, 2, 15, 252188) I have no doubt that if the Congress wishes to preserve its strength, it must vigorously pursue the constructive programme.
('96', 143, 2, 16, 252312) You worry about me from your sick bed.
('96', 143, 2, 17, 252351) But there is One who worries about you and me and everybody else; why don’t you leave everything to that Almighty?
('96', 143, 2, 18, 252466) And if I am destined to give still more service, nothing will happen to me.
('96', 143, 2, 19, 252542) For you, prayer is the only unfailing remedy.

('96', 144, 1, 2, 252673) 215. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL VALMIKI MANDIR, NEW DELHI, July 26, 1947
('96', 144, 2, 3, 252747) VALLABHBHAI, Two Khaksars came to see me yesterday.
('96', 144, 2, 4, 252799) One of them wept bitterly.
('96', 144, 2, 5, 252826) The other complained that although an official had assured them that now nothing would be done to them since they were going away, yet there was firing in the mosque the same evening, that many were killed, that an old man of seventy received seven bullets, that no one knew how many had died and how many had survived and that for three days the Khaksars were kept there without food and water, unable even to go out to answer calls of nature.
('96', 144, 2, 6, 253271) I was stunned to hear all this.
('96', 144, 2, 7, 253303) I rebuked them.
('96', 144, 2, 8, 253319) I said it could not be true.
('96', 144, 2, 9, 253348) I said, “Sardar told me only today that since the Khaksars would not leave the mosque police officials had to enter the mosque, that they did so with the permission of the Imam, that the action that was taken was ordered by the Muslim officer, that no violence had been used, nothing beyond tear gas had been fired and that no one had been killed.
('96', 144, 2, 10, 253696) I therefore cannot swallow what you say.” They answered, “If that is what your Sardar says, how can we hope to be believed?
('96', 144, 2, 11, 253820) What use asking for justice now?
('96', 144, 2, 12, 253853) One day you will know.
('96', 144, 2, 13, 253876) Truth will be out.” I said, “If I hear of a wrong being done I do not hide it even for the sake of my dear ones.
('96', 144, 2, 14, 253989) I shall say no more.
('96', 144, 2, 15, 254010) I will do my duty.” Now if there is anything in this please let me know.
('96', 144, 3, 16, 254083) Blessings from BAPU SARDAR VALLABHBHAI PATEL 1, AURANGZEB ROAD NEW DELHI [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro–2: Sardar Vallabhbhaine, pp.

('96', 147, 5, 24, 259816) The strike includes the employees of the Post and Telegraph department which operates not for the good of any particular individual but for the good of the community.
('96', 147, 5, 25, 259983) It is true that it has some big officers getting huge salaries and it is unjust that the members of the subordinate staff should be paid such low salaries.

('96', 149, 3, 16, 264140) 221. DISCUSSION WITH AN AMERICAN PACIFIST 1
('96', 149, 4, 17, 264184) NEW DELHI, [Before July 27, 1947] 2
('96', 149, 5, 18, 264220) A young American pacifist came to see Gandhiji some days ago.

('96', 149, 6, 22, 264564) Gandhiji’s reply was that they should behave as they would if the war was still going on.

('96', 149, 6, 24, 264738) The few would multiply into many.
('96', 149, 7, 25, 264772) The Friend was eloquent about Miss Lester.
('96', 149, 7, 26, 264815) He had great admiration for her.

('96', 149, 7, 29, 264942) There are many great women, but few good women.
('96', 149, 7, 30, 264990) If you had said that she was a very good woman, you would have been right.
('96', 149, 7, 31, 265065) A true pacifist’s language must

('96', 150, 4, 13, 265910) 222. THE NATIONAL FLAG 1
('96', 150, 5, 14, 265935) The National Flag has been in existence since 1921. Those who say that what was so far the Congress Flag has now become the National Flag of India make a meaningless fuss and at the same time insult the Congress.
('96', 150, 5, 15, 266148) The Congress has been national from its very inception.
('96', 150, 5, 16, 266204) It has never been sectional.
('96', 150, 5, 17, 266233) It embraces all sections and all Indians.
('96', 150, 5, 18, 266275) Of course, it is open to the Congress to become sectional and commit suicide.
('96', 150, 5, 19, 266353) If God’s wrath descends upon it the calamity may well overtake it.
('96', 150, 5, 20, 266420) Nevertheless, many will be praying that such a misfortune may not overtake it.
('96', 150, 5, 21, 266499) Is it possible that Jinnah’s jibe that the Congress is national only in name but Hindu in action, will be proved just?
('96', 150, 5, 22, 266618) Here, however, we shall confine ourselves to the Flag.
('96', 150, 5, 23, 266673) What has happened is that, having acquiesced in the division of India, the Congress has nevertheless delivered it from the British domination and has taken over the larger part.
('96', 150, 5, 24, 266851) Therefore, the flag under which the Congress has fought so many non violent battles will now be the flag of the Government of free India.
('96', 150, 5, 25, 266989) I see no haughtiness in this.
('96', 150, 5, 26, 267019) The joy that one finds in climbing the Himalayas, the views one sees, are not to be had on reaching the top.
('96', 150, 5, 27, 267128) The pleasure lies in the journey, not in arriving at the destination.
('96', 150, 5, 28, 267198) Similarly the pleasure that it gave us to fight under the National Flag has now come to an end.
('96', 150, 5, 29, 267294) I have just reread an article I wrote for Young India of April 13, 1921. I advise the reader to glance through that article.
('96', 150, 6, 30, 267419) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan of the same date.
('96', 151, 0, 1, 267491) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 151, 1, 2, 267533) reproduced in this issue.
('96', 151, 1, 3, 267559) The modified Flag has value only if it carries the significance attached to it.
('96', 151, 1, 4, 267639) If it does not, it is to me valueless.
('96', 151, 1, 5, 267678) There is reason for this caution.
('96', 151, 1, 6, 267712) Some say that the original flag has gone, that a new age has begun and with it have come new ways, and that the flag will be one to befit this new age.
('96', 151, 1, 7, 267864) I have not known a worthy son to whom his mother appeared ugly.
('96', 151, 1, 8, 267928) It may be possible to gild pure gold, but who can make his mother more beautiful?
('96', 151, 1, 9, 268010) Hence, in my opinion nothing would have been lost if no changes had been made in the original flag.
('96', 151, 1, 10, 268110) People are saying ‘the charkha was old women’s solace and Gandhi’s toy; but swaraj is not for old women.
('96', 151, 1, 11, 268215) It is for the warrior and we therefore want the Asoka emblem with lions and if the lions do not find a place on the flag, it is merely for artistic consi derations: they cannot be reproduced on cloth.

('96', 151, 1, 15, 268567) We shall talk about it when we see it.

('96', 151, 1, 26, 269086) We shall not treat it as an offence.
('96', 151, 1, 27, 269123) Old women in their huts may spin away on the charkha.
('96', 151, 1, 28, 269177) In this new age this should be considered a favour.’ I will refuse to salute the flag that is modified on the above lines however artistic it may appear.
('96', 151, 1, 29, 269331) Happily there is the other side which says: ‘The new flag is merely an improved design of the original.
('96', 151, 1, 30, 269435) The spinning wheel continues on it.

('96', 151, 1, 33, 269575) It always leaves something for the imagination.
('96', 151, 1, 34, 269623) The spinning wheel in a picture has no slivers and no spinners at work on it.
('96', 151, 1, 35, 269701) These are left for the imagination to fill in.
('96', 151, 1, 36, 269748) This rule applies as well to the improved design of the flag.
('96', 151, 1, 37, 269810) Thus conceived, the improve ment must appear innocent.
('96', 151, 1, 38, 269865) This tricolour flag with the wheel will certainly consist of hand spun and hand woven khadi.
('96', 151, 1, 39, 269958) Our country has called it khadi whether it is woven from hand spun cotton or silk.
('96', 151, 1, 40, 270041) When the original conception is kept intact
('96', 152, 0, 1, 270085) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 153
('96', 152, 1, 2, 270131) there is no harm in making a conce ssion to art.
('96', 152, 1, 3, 270180) When the country was at war with a foreign power, art lay in being engaged in the battle.
('96', 152, 1, 4, 270270) Now that it has ended in success, art must have a place, though perhaps, a subordinate one.
('96', 152, 1, 5, 270362) Otherwise we shall not be able to perpetuate the memory of the struggle.’ This is another interpretation.
('96', 152, 1, 6, 270468) If any further interpretations not inconsistent with this are added I see no harm in it.
('96', 152, 1, 7, 270557) One may see some other subtle meaning in the same three colours.
('96', 152, 1, 8, 270622) Those who see unity in the diversity of the universe may find it in the three colours.
('96', 152, 1, 9, 270709) Looking at the wheel some may recall that Prince of Peace, King Asoka, ruler of an empire, who renounced power.

('96', 155, 3, 20, 276728) 227. MESSAGE TO ARMY OFFICERS
('96', 155, 4, 21, 276758) NEW DELHI, July 27, 1947 I have only one message for you.
('96', 155, 4, 22, 276816) You have got your guns and sten guns and you are proficient in killing men and all living things.
('96', 155, 4, 23, 276914) Instead of that you should learn the art of using the sickle, ploughing the land and producing the food necessary for men and other living beings.
('96', 155, 4, 24, 277061) Forget violence and gain proficiency in non violence.
('96', 155, 4, 25, 277115) Maybe from this you will think that I have gone mad.
('96', 155, 4, 26, 277168) But look at the way Capt.
('96', 155, 4, 27, 277194) Shahnawaz and Col.
('96', 155, 4, 28, 277213) Jiwansingh live and work today.
('96', 155, 4, 29, 277245) They have ceased to be army officers and have become public servants and farmers.
('96', 155, 4, 30, 277327) Thus they have become more powerful.
('96', 155, 4, 31, 277364) They are themselves happy and have made people happy.
('96', 155, 4, 32, 277418) One of them is a Muslim and is
('96', 156, 0, 1, 277449) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 157
('96', 156, 1, 2, 277495) doing wonderful work in Bihar.
('96', 156, 1, 3, 277526) The other, in spite of being a Punjabi and orthodox Sikh, has identified himself with the Muslims of Noakhali.
('96', 156, 1, 4, 277637) I mention just these two names because I happen to remember them.
('96', 156, 1, 5, 277703) But many such persons have come to me.
('96', 156, 1, 6, 277742) They have changed their lives and have become happy.
('96', 156, 1, 7, 277795) Such a time is now coming.
('96', 156, 1, 8, 277822) You note down in your diary that the world will curse the scientist who has made the atom bomb.
('96', 156, 1, 9, 277918) People have wearied of bloodshed.
('96', 156, 1, 10, 277952) They would like to follow the path of non violence and peace.
('96', 156, 1, 11, 278014) India alone can give a lesson in that.
('96', 156, 1, 12, 278053) America has great riches.
('96', 156, 1, 13, 278079) Even other countries have more money than we have.
('96', 156, 1, 14, 278130) Because they have money, they are investing in devices of mass destruction.
('96', 156, 1, 15, 278206) That is why our scriptures and the Gita teach us not to hoard wealth.
('96', 156, 1, 16, 278276) The right way of becoming happy is the observance of truth, non violence, non hoarding, celibacy, non stealing and physical labour.
('96', 156, 1, 17, 278408) This is as true as a geometrical theorem.

('96', 156, 3, 21, 278566) 228. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 156, 4, 22, 278596) NEW DELHI, July 27, 1947
('96', 156, 5, 23, 278621) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, There are more than 800 princely States in India.
('96', 156, 5, 24, 278693) Some of them are very large and some very small.
('96', 156, 5, 25, 278742) Recently the Viceroy had summoned the Princes to Delhi.
('96', 156, 5, 26, 278798) So long the States had functioned under the protective umbrella of the British Empire which has now been taken away.
('96', 156, 5, 27, 278915) The Viceroy spoke to them in very gentle terms.
('96', 156, 5, 28, 278963) I liked his speech.
('96', 156, 5, 29, 278983) He advised these rulers that they should all opt for either India or Pakistan.
('96', 156, 5, 30, 279062) His speech was not a brief one.
('96', 156, 5, 31, 279094) What hurt me was that in his lengthy address there was not even a mention of the States’ people.
('96', 156, 5, 32, 279191) The relationship of the British Government was with the rulers of the States.
('96', 156, 5, 33, 279269) The subjects of the States did not figure anywhere.
('96', 156, 5, 34, 279321) Therefore, when paramountcy lapses these States legally become independent and the British Government cannot interfere, but after all the rulers have certain duties and obligations.
('96', 156, 5, 35, 279503) The States’ subjects can no longer be ruled at the point of the bayonet.
('96', 156, 5, 36, 279576) But the security they have under the British protection is no longer there.
('96', 157, 0, 1, 279652) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 157, 1, 2, 279694) Take some large State—Cochin, for instance.
('96', 157, 1, 3, 279738) It has an extensive sea coast.
('96', 157, 1, 4, 279769) It cannot enter into treaty relations with the whole world in order to ensure its security and it was the duty of the Viceroy to point this out.
('96', 157, 1, 5, 279914) I would have been happy if he had somewhere in his speech also mentioned the States’ People.
('96', 157, 1, 6, 280007) Since I was born in a Kathiawar State as a subject I have a right to say something about this question.
('96', 157, 1, 7, 280111) Formerly if a ruler wanted so much as to employ a Dewan he had to seek permission from the Viceroy.
('96', 157, 1, 8, 280211) They certainly did not like this.
('96', 157, 1, 9, 280245) If, therefore, they now have been deprived of British protection, they are also free of British pressure.
('96', 157, 1, 10, 280351) But there is now pressure from their people.
('96', 157, 1, 11, 280396) So, if the rulers want to stay as rulers, they can only do so as servants of their people.
('96', 157, 1, 12, 280487) They should seek the advice and co operation of their Prajaman dals in the work of administration.
('96', 157, 1, 13, 280586) It is true that the Prajamandals have no experience of administration.
('96', 157, 1, 14, 280657) But then even the leaders of the Central Government have had no previous experience of administration.
('96', 157, 1, 15, 280760) This does not mean that the rulers should nominate twenty or twenty five persons and call them Prajamandal.
('96', 157, 1, 16, 280868) They should do whatever they do with sinceri ty.
('96', 157, 1, 17, 280917) So far as the question of their joining Pakistan or the Indian Union is concerned, regard will have to be paid to the geographical situation.
('96', 157, 1, 18, 281059) A State in Gujarat or Kathiawar cannot unite itself with Bengal.
('96', 157, 1, 19, 281124) The States thus cannot free themselves from the constraints of geography.
('96', 157, 1, 20, 281198) It is curious that the British have not said that the paramountcy which they had so long exercised now vests in India and Pakistan.
('96', 157, 1, 21, 281330) This has complicated the problem both for India and Pakistan.
('96', 157, 1, 22, 281392) I must say that the rulers are now on their trial.
('96', 157, 1, 23, 281443) They may remain rulers but they must be servants of the people in fact.
('96', 157, 1, 24, 281515) I am saying this not because the Viceroy has complained to me about the rulers or that Jawaharlal or Rajendra Babu have said anything to me.
('96', 157, 1, 25, 281656) The fact is that people are now watching what the Indian Government and Pakistan Government will do?
('96', 157, 1, 26, 281757) But what is the plight of the States’ People?
('96', 157, 1, 27, 281803) Are they happy at the thought of the coming freedom?
('96', 157, 1, 28, 281856) Will they celebrate the day of independence?
('96', 157, 1, 29, 281901) As for me I shall fast on the day and my prayer will be: ‘O God, now that India is free do not destroy her.’ The States form one fourth of the area of the country.
('96', 157, 1, 30, 282065) Will the 10 crore subjects of the States celebrate August 15 as Independence Day?
('96', 157, 1, 31, 282147) If the Princes declare that they will from now on be servants of their people, then all will be well.
('96', 157, 1, 32, 282249) Then the taxes they raise from the
('96', 158, 0, 1, 282284) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 159
('96', 158, 1, 2, 282330) people will be for the uplift of the people.
('96', 158, 1, 3, 282375) They will return their revenue ten times over not in the form of money but in the form of schools, hospitals, roads, gardens and public parks.
('96', 158, 1, 4, 282518) Jawaharlal and Sardar Patel have made no comment on the speech of the Viceroy though they could not be very happy in their hearts.
('96', 158, 1, 5, 282649) But why should we have any poison in our hearts ?
('96', 158, 1, 6, 282699) It is like a game in which all one’s cards must be placed on the table.
('96', 158, 1, 7, 282771) Only when there is no poison in our hearts can we genuinely celebrate August 15 as Independence Day.
('96', 158, 1, 8, 282872) [From Hindi]
('96', 158, 2, 9, 282885) Prarthana Pravachan–I, pp.

('96', 164, 9, 17, 292262) 242. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 164, 10, 18, 292292) NEW DELHI, July 28, 1947
('96', 164, 11, 19, 292317) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I shall answer some questions today.
('96', 164, 12, 20, 292376) Q. After 15th of August will there be two Congress organizations in the two countries or only one or would there be no Congress at all ?
('96', 164, 13, 21, 292513) A. I think then the need for an organization like the Congress will be still greater.
('96', 164, 13, 22, 292599) Its programme will no doubt be altered.
('96', 164, 14, 23, 292639) 1Vide “Letter to Lord Mountbatten”, 28 7 1 47.
('96', 165, 0, 1, 292686) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 165, 1, 2, 292728) Congress does not foolishly accept the two nation theory, there will be only one Congress in the whole country.
('96', 165, 1, 3, 292840) The partition of India does not and should not mean the partition of the Congress.
('96', 165, 1, 4, 292923) The partition of India into two sovereign States does not mean that India is two nations.
('96', 165, 1, 5, 293013) Sup posing one or more Princely States kept out of the Union, would the Congress turn their representatives out of the Congress ?
('96', 165, 1, 6, 293143) Would the States’ people not expect it to take even greater interest in their welfare ?
('96', 165, 1, 7, 293231) Of course the problems that this will create will be even more complicated and some of them will be more difficult of solution, but there still will be no reason for the Congress to be broken up into two.
('96', 165, 1, 8, 293436) It will require greater political acumen, greater depth of thought and much more patient deliberation and decision.
('96', 165, 1, 9, 293552) We must not anticipate incapacitating difficulties.
('96', 165, 2, 10, 293604) Q. Will the Congress now become a communal organization ?
('96', 165, 2, 11, 293662) A demand is being vociferously raised that since the Muslims now consider themselves a separate nation, we too should candidly call ourselves Hindu India and place upon the country the deep imprint of Hinduism ?
('96', 165, 3, 12, 293874) A. The question betrays sheer ignorance.
('96', 165, 3, 13, 293915) The Congress can never become an organization of the Hindus.
('96', 165, 3, 14, 293976) Those who seek to make it such will be doing great harm to India and Hinduism.
('96', 165, 3, 15, 294055) India is the country of the millions but their voice is not heard.
('96', 165, 3, 16, 294122) It is only the vociferous sections living in cities who talk of two nations.
('96', 165, 3, 17, 294199) We should not mistake their voice for the voice of the millions.
('96', 165, 3, 18, 294264) Then it must be remembered that Muslims in the Indian Union have not said that they are not Indians and Hinduism with all its shortcomings has never encouraged separation.
('96', 165, 3, 19, 294436) People professing different religions have mingled to form the Indian nation and they are all citizens of India and no section has the right to oppress another section.
('96', 165, 3, 20, 294605) The power derived from the sword or from numbers is not real power.
('96', 165, 3, 21, 294673) Truth is real power.
('96', 165, 4, 22, 294694) Q. What attitude should non Muslims adopt towards the Pakistan flag!
('96', 165, 5, 23, 294763) A. The Pakistan flag for the time being will be the Muslim League’s flag.
('96', 165, 5, 24, 294837) If the Muslim League represents Islam then the Muslims all over the world should have one flag and those who are not hostile to Islam should respect that flag.
('96', 165, 5, 25, 294997) I do not know the flags of Islam, Hinduism, Christianity or of any other religion.
('96', 165, 5, 26, 295080) And if I have not made a deep study of Islam, I can be mistaken about its flag.
('96', 165, 5, 27, 295160) If the flag of Pakistan, whatever its colour, represents all the people
('96', 166, 0, 1, 295232) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 167
('96', 166, 1, 2, 295278) living in Pakistan then I shall salute that flag and so shall you.
('96', 166, 1, 3, 295345) In other words the two Dominions cannot become enemies of each other.
('96', 166, 1, 4, 295415) I am watching with much interest and more fear what attitude the Dominion of South Africa adopts towards India.
('96', 166, 1, 5, 295527) Can the people of South Africa hate the people of India ?
('96', 166, 1, 6, 295585) Will the South African Whites still refuse to travel with Indians in the same compartments?
('96', 166, 1, 7, 295677) [From Hindi]
('96', 166, 2, 8, 295690) Prarthana Pravachan–I, pp.

('96', 167, 1, 2, 296678) 245. LETTER TO J. P. BHANSALI
('96', 167, 2, 3, 296708) NEW DELHI, July 29, 1947
('96', 167, 3, 4, 296733) BHANSALI, You must not assume the entire responsibility for Pushpa.
('96', 167, 3, 5, 296801) In fact you ought not to assume any.
('96', 167, 3, 6, 296838) You are under my discipline.
('96', 167, 3, 7, 296867) You should, therefore, assume only as much of that responsibility as I entrust to you.
('96', 167, 3, 8, 296954) In doing that lies your good, as also mine, and that of Pushpa and of the Ashram too.
('96', 167, 3, 9, 297040) It is indeed a good thing that you have lost the capacity to judge people.
('96', 167, 3, 10, 297115) There was a time when you possessed it in good measure.
('96', 167, 3, 11, 297171) But you were more inclined to see the defects of men and of institutions.
('96', 167, 3, 12, 297245) You know the results of doing that.
('96', 167, 3, 13, 297281) And so you became a sannyasi, wandered about and submitted yourself to a great many hardships.
('96', 167, 3, 14, 297376) And now you are back where you were.
('96', 167, 3, 15, 297413) I see nothing but God’s hand in this.
('96', 167, 3, 16, 297451) I think it will be best for you to assume no responsibility not entrusted to you by me.
('96', 167, 3, 17, 297539) That is your real dharma and only by acting in that way can you keep a watch on the Ashram.
('96', 167, 3, 18, 297631) I have also explained to you the meaning of keeping a watch.
('96', 167, 3, 19, 297692) 1 It means that you should maintain the highest standard of purity in your own conduct so that everybody else may look upon you as the ideal to be followed.
('96', 167, 3, 20, 297849) I know of no better method of keeping a watch.
('96', 167, 3, 21, 297896) To notice and point at people’s defects does not mean keeping a watch.
('96', 167, 3, 22, 297967) You are sometimes swayed by emotion and act thoughtlessly.
('96', 167, 3, 23, 298026) I heard that you undertook a fast once again.
('96', 167, 3, 24, 298072) There was no need at all to do that.
('96', 167, 3, 25, 298109) To permit Pushpa to slacken in the least degree in the observance of rules will be tantamount to betraying her.
('96', 167, 3, 26, 298221) It was I who admitted her to the Ashram at some risk.
('96', 167, 3, 27, 298275) I pained her parents by doing that.
('96', 167, 3, 28, 298311) She has not succeeded in becoming a perfect devotee.
('96', 167, 3, 29, 298364) She has realized that she is far away from that sublime state.
('96', 167, 3, 30, 298427) But her wilfulness … 2 have not yet vanished.
('96', 167, 3, 31, 298473) She has still not realized the importance of abiding by the rules.
('96', 167, 3, 32, 298540) You should, therefore, humbly renounce your claim to be Pushpa’s elder brother or father or guardian.
('96', 167, 3, 33, 298642) She must observe the Ashram rules with the utmost punctiliousness and become one with it
('96', 167, 4, 34, 298731) 1Vide “Letter to J. P. Bhansali”, 24 7 1947. 2 Omission as in the source
('96', 168, 0, 1, 298804) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 169
('96', 168, 1, 2, 298850) as sugar becomes one with milk.
('96', 168, 1, 3, 298882) Till she merits such a certificate, I shall not be relieved of my worry on her account.
('96', 168, 1, 4, 298970) I owe a responsibility to her parents.
('96', 168, 1, 5, 299009) Even if her renunciation in giving up her intention to marry the person whom she wished to marry was not the result of selfishness or wilfulness, she has yet to demonstrate that it was an act of supreme self abnegation.
('96', 168, 1, 6, 299229) I don’t have to explain this to you.

('96', 172, 1, 9, 305860) Jawaharlal agreed but he said that he would again be going to Kashmir.

('96', 172, 1, 16, 306444) So I did not go.
('96', 172, 1, 17, 306461) And now the situation is such that either Jawaharlal or I should go to Kashmir.

('96', 179, 3, 16, 319525) 259. EVEN PROUD GUJARAT!
('96', 179, 4, 17, 319550) Shri Maganbhai Desai has sent me a copy of his correspondence with Shri Ratanlal Parikh.

('96', 184, 3, 6, 328292) RAWALPINDI,2
('96', 184, 4, 7, 328305) July 31, 1947
('96', 184, 5, 8, 328319) Speaking after the Ramdhun he said that he had received two letters which he would like to answer.
('96', 184, 5, 9, 328418) The first was in English.
('96', 184, 5, 10, 328444) The handwriting was good but that was little consolation for him.
('96', 184, 5, 11, 328510) The British were quitting India but the people had become so used to slavery that they still could not shake off the lure of the English language which few could ever hope to master.
('96', 184, 5, 12, 328693) This linguistic conquest constituted a worse type of slavery than the conquest by the British sword.
('96', 184, 5, 13, 328794) Every language was good in its own place.
('96', 184, 5, 14, 328836) He would not ask the Zulus or the Dutch in South Africa to learn Gujarati, for instance, Similarly, he would not ask all the sisters assembled there to learn English.
('96', 184, 5, 15, 329003) That was neither possible nor desirable.
('96', 184, 5, 16, 329044) His mother tongue was Gujarati.
('96', 184, 5, 17, 329076) He loved it.
('96', 184, 5, 18, 329089) But he would not think of making it the lingua franca of India.
('96', 184, 5, 19, 329153) There were hardly a crore of Indians who spoke Gujarati but there were nearly 21 crores who talked in Hindustani; whether they could read or write was a different matter.
('96', 184, 5, 20, 329324) Hindustani was written in the Urdu or Nagari script.
('96', 184, 6, 21, 329377) The second letter was written in beautiful Urdu handwriting.
('96', 184, 6, 22, 329438) He en couraged all those who came in contact with him to learn the two scripts and he was proud of the fact.
('96', 184, 6, 23, 329547) He would rather teach Urdu to his boys and girls than teach them English.
('96', 184, 7, 24, 329621) In the letter written in English, the writer had asked him to spend at least a week in Rawalpindi and see with his own eyes what the Hindus had suffered.
('96', 184, 7, 25, 329775) Why should he wish to go to Kashmir ?
('96', 184, 7, 26, 329813) His reply was that ever since he had gone to Delhi he had wanted to come to the Punjab.
('96', 184, 7, 27, 329901) He wanted to visit Lahore, Amritsar and Rawalpindi.
('96', 184, 7, 28, 329953) But he believed that he was in God’s hands.
('96', 184, 7, 29, 329997) God was the Master of all the universe and He could upset the plans of men.
('96', 184, 7, 30, 330073) The original plan was that he would spend a day at Lahore and Amritsar, two days at Rawalpindi and at least ten days in Kashmir.
('96', 184, 7, 31, 330202) Now he had only two or three days for Kashmir.
('96', 184, 7, 32, 330249) And that too was in fulfilment of a promise.
('96', 184, 8, 33, 330294) 1 St. Matthew, xix.
('96', 184, 8, 34, 330314) 19 2 According to the report the meeting was held in the compound of Lala Devraj Anand.
