('96', 186, 1, 2, 332634) 267. BURIED ALIVE?
('96', 186, 1, 3, 332653) A correspondent from Hyderabad (Deccan) writes: “Gandhi is being buried alive.”
('96', 186, 2, 4, 332733) Gandhi means Gandhi’s ideals.
('96', 186, 2, 5, 332763) It is through these ideals that we have reached where we are.
('96', 186, 2, 6, 332825) But we are kicking away the very ladder over which we have climbed so high.
('96', 186, 2, 7, 332901) And it is those who are considered Gandhi’s greatest followers who are doing this.
('96', 186, 2, 8, 332984) Hindu Muslim unity, Hindustani, khadi and village industries have been completely forgotten.
('96', 186, 2, 9, 333077) Those who still talk about them are either themselves deceived or are deceiving others.
('96', 186, 2, 10, 333165) This is by far the best way of burying me alive.
('96', 186, 2, 11, 333214) But can I believe that I have already been buried ?
('96', 186, 2, 12, 333266) Who is my greatest follower and who is the smallest ?
('96', 186, 2, 13, 333320) I have only one follower, that is myself, or all Indians.
('96', 186, 2, 14, 333378) My followers are those who have faith in the above mentioned activities.
('96', 186, 2, 15, 333451) I do hope that crores of villagers do believe in these few things.
('96', 186, 2, 16, 333518) Even then the allegation is quite true.
('96', 186, 2, 17, 333558) However, I find that even the members of the Muslim League have started saying that we are all brothers.
('96', 186, 2, 18, 333663) It has even been accepted that we are citizens of both the States.
('96', 186, 2, 19, 333730) For the time being there is no need for passports.
('96', 186, 2, 20, 333781) That will become necessary if either of the two countries introduces them.
('96', 186, 2, 21, 333856) Let us hope that passports will never be needed and let us so behave that they will not be needed.
('96', 186, 2, 22, 333955) Let us hope that neither of the communities will give up khadi and cause harm to the village industries.
('96', 186, 2, 23, 334060) I have already written about Hindustani.
('96', 186, 2, 24, 334101) How can we give it up?
('96', 186, 2, 25, 334124) How can the Muslims whose mother tongue is Urdu give it up?
('96', 186, 2, 26, 334184) They have to make their Urdu simple.
('96', 186, 2, 27, 334221) Similarly the Hindus will have to make Hindi simple.
('96', 186, 2, 28, 334274) Only then can the two communities understand each other.
('96', 186, 2, 29, 334331) The correspon dent has forgotten the most important thing.
('96', 186, 2, 30, 334390) The Hindus have to purify themselves by eschewing untouchability and caste differences.
('96', 186, 2, 31, 334478) Similarly, Muslims have to purify themselves by giving up their hatred of Hindus.
('96', 186, 3, 32, 334560) SRINAGAR, August 3, 1947 [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 17 8 1947
('96', 187, 0, 1, 334623) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 187, 1, 2, 334665) 268. THE TRI COLOUR
('96', 187, 2, 3, 334685) The correspondent from Hyderabad who wrote “Gandhi is being buried alive” 1 writes further on :
('96', 187, 3, 4, 334781) The tri colour was the symbol of our struggle.
('96', 187, 3, 5, 334828) A grave sin has been committed by taking away the wheel from it.
('96', 187, 3, 6, 334893) The new wheel or the old Asoka Chakra has no connection with Gandhi’s wheel; indeed it is incompatible with it.
('96', 187, 3, 7, 335005) Gandhi’s wheel was above religion while the new wheel is a symbol of Hinduism.
('96', 187, 3, 8, 335084) Gandhi’s wheel is a sign of ‘non violent economy’ while the new one represents the Sudarshan Chakra 2 (as Shri Munshi 3 says in his broadcast) which represents violence.
('96', 187, 3, 9, 335254) In this way the new flag will encourage the violent tendencies in the nation.
('96', 187, 3, 10, 335332) A deliberate attempt is being made in that direction.
('96', 187, 3, 11, 335386) This is not the way to bring Pakistan back into the fold but to perpetuate the division.
('96', 187, 3, 12, 335475) I have not read what Shri Munshi said.
('96', 187, 3, 13, 335514) The national flag is doomed if it signifies what the correspondent says.
('96', 187, 3, 14, 335587) Under no circumstances can the Asoka Chakra become a symbol of violence.
('96', 187, 3, 15, 335660) Emperor Asoka was a Buddhist and a votary of non violence.
('96', 187, 3, 16, 335719) The Sudarshan Chakra can have no connection with the wheel in the flag.
('96', 187, 3, 17, 335791) According to me the Sudarshan Chakra is a symbol of non violence.
('96', 187, 3, 18, 335857) But that is my personal view.
('96', 187, 3, 19, 335887) Generally the Sudarshan Chakra is believed to be an instrument of violence.
('96', 187, 3, 20, 335963) We can say from the debates which took place on the new flag that if it has not rendered the spinning wheel valueless it has without doubt diminished its value.
('96', 187, 3, 21, 336124) Whether the Asoka Chakra and the spinning wheel are the same thing will ultimately depend on the behaviour of the people.
('96', 187, 3, 22, 336246) SRINAGAR, August 3, 1947 [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 17 8 1947

('96', 188, 1, 2, 336660) 269. LETTER TO VENKATA RAO
('96', 188, 2, 3, 336687) SRINAGAR, August 3, 1947
('96', 188, 3, 4, 336712) BHAI VENKATA RAO, Two questions from your letter will be answered in Harijan.
('96', 188, 3, 5, 336790) I think it would be difficult to keep your wife in Sevagram.
('96', 188, 3, 6, 336851) It does not appear that I shall be able to go there.
('96', 188, 3, 7, 336904) The management of the Ashram is not in my hands.
('96', 188, 3, 8, 336953) You should not leave her.
('96', 188, 3, 9, 336979) Let her stay with you and serve her as best as you can.
('96', 188, 3, 10, 337035) I can do nothing about Hyderabad.
('96', 188, 3, 11, 337069) You have to think and decide for yourself about going or not going.
('96', 188, 3, 12, 337137) Write to Kakasaheb Kalelkar at Wardha about the language matter.
('96', 188, 3, 13, 337202) My knowledge of languages is superficial.
('96', 188, 4, 14, 337244) Blessings from BAPU 19 CANNING LANE NEW DELHI
('96', 188, 5, 15, 337290) From a copy of the Hindi: Pyarelal Papers.
('96', 188, 5, 16, 337333) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('96', 188, 6, 17, 337352) 270. THE REASON FOR ADDITION 1
('96', 188, 7, 18, 337383) During the three days I passed in Srinagar, though I had prayers in the compound of Lala Kishorilal’s bungalow, where I was accommodated, I made no speeches.
('96', 188, 7, 19, 337541) I had so declared before leaving Delhi.
('96', 188, 7, 20, 337581) But some of the audience sent me questions.
('96', 188, 7, 21, 337625) One was :
('96', 188, 8, 22, 337635) I attended your prayer meeting last evening in which you recited two prayers of the other communities.
('96', 188, 8, 23, 337738) May I know what is your idea in doing so and what you mean by religion ?
('96', 188, 8, 24, 337811) As I have observed before now, the selection from the Koran was introduced some years ago on the suggestion of Raihana Tyabji 2
('96', 188, 9, 25, 337939) who was then living in the Sevagram Ashram and the one from the Parsi prayers at the instance of Dr. Gilder who recited the Parsi prayer
('96', 188, 10, 26, 338076) 1 This appeared under the title “Notes”.
('96', 188, 10, 27, 338117) 2 Abbas Tyabji’s daughter, a devotee of Lord Krishna
('96', 189, 0, 1, 338170) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 189, 1, 2, 338212) on the break of my fast 1 in the Aga Khan Palace during our detention.
('96', 189, 1, 3, 338283) I am of opinion that the addition enriched the prayer.
('96', 189, 1, 4, 338338) It reached the hearts of a larger audience than before.
('96', 189, 1, 5, 338394) It certainly showed Hinduism in its broad and tolerant aspect.
('96', 189, 1, 6, 338457) The questioner ought also to have asked why the prayer commenced with the Buddhist prayer in Japanese.
('96', 189, 1, 7, 338560) The selection of the stanzas of the prayer has a history behind it befitting the sacred character.
('96', 189, 1, 8, 338659) The Buddhist prayer was the prayer which the whole of Sevagram resounded in the early morning when a good Japanese monk 2 was staying at the Sevagram Ashram and who by his silent and dignified conduct had endeared himself to the inmates of the Ashram.
('96', 189, 1, 9, 338911) JAMMU, August 5, 1947 Harijan, 17 8 1947
('96', 189, 2, 10, 338952) 271. SPEECH AT GURUDWARA, PUNJA SAHEB 3
('96', 189, 3, 11, 338992) [August 5, 1947] 4
('96', 189, 4, 12, 339011) Replying to the address Gandhiji [said he] did not consider it possible that Eastern Punjab should be handed over entirely to the Sikhs to govern.
('96', 189, 4, 13, 339158) He felt that Sikhs should never entertain such an unworthy ambition.
('96', 189, 4, 14, 339227) The Sikhs were reputed, and rightly, to be a warlike race.
('96', 189, 4, 15, 339286) With them of all the persons in the world, merit and merit alone should be the sole test for holding any office.
('96', 189, 4, 16, 339399) He hoped that throughout the two dominions merit would be the sole test.
('96', 189, 4, 17, 339472) The speaker invited the Sikhs to lead in this desirable competition.
('96', 189, 5, 18, 339541) Coming to the protection of Punja Saheb, Nankana Saheb and the other
('96', 189, 6, 19, 339610) Gurudwaras that may be found in Pakistan or elsewhere, he said: One Sikh is equal to one and a quarter lakh men.
('96', 189, 6, 20, 339723) Why should he beg for anyone’s help?
('96', 189, 6, 21, 339760) If they have the mettle no one can cast an evil eye on Punja Saheb.
('96', 189, 6, 22, 339828) But these days the Sikh brethren have taken to luxury and enjoyment.
('96', 189, 6, 23, 339897) I do not intend to say that Sikhs alone have fallen into that habit.
('96', 189, 6, 24, 339966) Among others women also have taken to fashionable ways though to a lesser degree.
('96', 189, 6, 25, 340048) But do not think that I
('96', 189, 7, 26, 340072) 1 On March 3, 1943; vide “Talk Before Breaking the 21 Day Fast”, 3 3 1943. 2 Rev.
('96', 189, 7, 27, 340154) G. Haishao 3 The Sikhs assembled at the Gurudwara of Punja Saheb, near Rawalpindi, one of the oldest of Sikh shrines, and presented an address to Gandhiji which described their sufferings and their fears for the Gurudwaras.

('96', 190, 0, 1, 340473) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 191
('96', 190, 1, 2, 340519) am defending them.
('96', 190, 1, 3, 340538) Some take liquor in large quantities while others take less but that does not mean that it is a virtue to drink less.
('96', 190, 1, 4, 340656) Similarly it is not a virtue to be less fashionable.
('96', 190, 1, 5, 340709) As long as true Sikhs are alive no one can cause you any harm.
('96', 190, 1, 6, 340772) Do not look to any other power outside yourselves for the protection of these shrines.
('96', 190, 1, 7, 340859) I would like every Sikh to be a defender of his faith and, therefore, of all the Gurudwaras and not merely of Punja Saheb which is one of the greatest.
('96', 190, 1, 8, 341011) At the same time I want you to shed all fear about the future.
('96', 190, 1, 9, 341074) I would ask you to rely upon the plighted word of the Muslim leaders.
('96', 190, 1, 10, 341144) They have got their Pakistan.
('96', 190, 1, 11, 341174) They have no quarrel now with anyone in India—at least they should have none.
('96', 190, 1, 12, 341252) If your fears materialize and any attempt at desecration of the Gurudwaras is made by the Muslims, it will be contrary to the tradition of Islam as I know it.
('96', 190, 1, 13, 341411) And those Muslims who take part in such desecration would be partakers in the destruction of Islam.
('96', 190, 1, 14, 341511) Every faith is on its trial in India.
('96', 190, 1, 15, 341549) God is the infallible Judge and the world which is His creation will judge the Muslim leaders not according to their pledge and promises but according to the deeds of these leaders and their followers.
('96', 190, 1, 16, 341751) What I have said of the Muslim leaders is also true of the leaders and followers of other faith.

('96', 190, 3, 19, 341900) 272. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('96', 190, 4, 20, 341932) WAH, August 5, 1947
('96', 190, 5, 21, 341952) Gandhiji said that he was glad that he was able to visit the Refugee Camp at Wah and see the patients in the Camp hospital and other appointments in connection with it.
('96', 190, 5, 22, 342121) He was glad too that he was able to pay what was his second visit to Punja Saheb.
('96', 190, 5, 23, 342203) He had a talk with the representatives of the Camp.
('96', 190, 6, 24, 342255) Before, however, he dealt with matters arising out of these talks with the representatives of the refugees, he said that he would like to say a word about his visit to Kashmir.
('96', 190, 6, 25, 342432) He had made up his mind not to hold any public meeting or address them but he was able see the workers.
('96', 190, 6, 26, 342536) Begum Saheba (wife of Sheikh Abdulla 2) was constantly with him throughout the three days he was in Srinagar.
('96', 190, 6, 27, 342646) He was able also
('96', 190, 7, 28, 342663) 1 This appeared under the title “Kashmir and Refugees”.
('96', 190, 7, 29, 342719) 2 Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, President (1905 82); National Muslim Conference; President, All India States People’s Conference; Prime Minister of Jammu and Kashmir, 1948 53 and 1975 82.
('96', 191, 0, 1, 342903) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 191, 1, 2, 342945) to see the Maharaja Saheb 1, the Maharani Saheb and Prime Minister Kak Saheb 2. He was sorry that he was not able to see Sheikh Abdullah who was undoubtedly the leader of the Kashmiris.
('96', 191, 1, 3, 343131) He had not gone there see the Sheikh Saheb.
('96', 191, 1, 4, 343175) He was able, however, to hold public prayers for two days in Kashmir and one day in Jammu.
('96', 191, 1, 5, 343266) These were attended by thousands.
('96', 191, 1, 6, 343300) He could say that on August 15, all being well, legally the State of Kashmir and Jammu would be independent.
('96', 191, 1, 7, 343409) But he was sure that the State would not remain in that condition for long after August 15. It had to join either the union or Pakistan.
('96', 191, 1, 8, 343546) It had a predominantly Muslim population.
('96', 191, 1, 9, 343588) But he saw that Sheikh Saheb had fired Kashmiris with local patriotism.
('96', 191, 1, 10, 343660) British Paramountcy would terminate on the 15th instant.
('96', 191, 1, 11, 343717) Real paramountcy would then commence.
('96', 191, 1, 12, 343755) He referred to the paramountcy of the Kashmiris.
('96', 191, 1, 13, 343804) They had one language, one culture and, so far as he could see, they were one people.
('96', 191, 1, 14, 343890) He could not distinguish readily between a Kashmiri Hindu and a Kashmiri Mussalman.
('96', 191, 1, 15, 343974) In the large deputation that he saw it was very difficult for him to know whether it was predominantly Muslim or Hindu.
('96', 191, 1, 16, 344094) Whatever it was, he had no hesitation in saying that the will of the Kashmiris was the supreme law in Kashmir and Jammu.
('96', 191, 1, 17, 344215) He was glad to say that the Maharaja Saheb and the Maharani Saheba readily acknowledged the fact.
('96', 191, 1, 18, 344313) He had the good fortune to read what was euphemistically called the Treaty of Amritsar 3 but which was in reality a deed of sale.
('96', 191, 1, 19, 344443) He supposed that it would be dead on August 15. The seller was the then British Governor General 4 and Maharaja Gulab Singh was the buyer.
('96', 191, 1, 20, 344582) The treaty going, would the State revert to the British and therefore, to England?
('96', 191, 1, 21, 344665) If to India, to which part ?
('96', 191, 1, 22, 344694) He held that without going into the intricacies of law which he had no right to dilate upon, common sense dictated that the will of the Kashmiris should decide the fate of Kashmir and Jammu.
('96', 191, 1, 23, 344885) The sooner it was done the better.
('96', 191, 1, 24, 344920) How the will of the people would be determined was a fair question.
('96', 191, 1, 25, 344988) He hoped that the question would be decided between the two Dominions, the Maharaja Saheb and the Kashmiris.
('96', 191, 1, 26, 345097) If the four could come to a joint decision, much trouble would be avoided.
('96', 191, 1, 27, 345172) After all Kashmir was a big State; it had the greatest strategic value, perhaps in all India.
('96', 191, 1, 28, 345266) So much for Kashmir.
('96', 191, 1, 29, 345287) He would now deal with the question of the refugees.
('96', 191, 1, 30, 345340) Among them they were nearly 9,000. The Hindus and the Sikhs who discussed the question with him said that they were afraid of the approach of August 15. He confessed that he did not in any way whatsoever share the fear.
('96', 191, 1, 31, 345560) Nor could he appreciate it.
('96', 191, 1, 32, 345588) The Muslims had got their Pakistan.
('96', 191, 1, 33, 345624) They could now have no quarrel with the Hindus and the Sikhs of the Punjab.
('96', 191, 1, 34, 345700) Jinnah Saheb and other Muslim Leaguers had given assurances that the non Muslims were as safe in Pakistan as the Muslims.
('96', 191, 1, 35, 345822) He invited the audience to accept the assurance.
('96', 191, 1, 36, 345871) Supposing that the assurance proved untrue and the worst fears
('96', 191, 2, 37, 345934) 1 Hari Singh 2 Ramchandra Kak 3 `Of March 16, 1846, by which the State of Jammu and Kashmir was created 4 Sir Henry Hardinge
('96', 192, 0, 1, 346059) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 193
('96', 192, 1, 2, 346105) of the refugees proved true, it would be the beginning of the ruin of Islam.
('96', 192, 1, 3, 346182) He refused to believe that Muslim leaders would be guilty of such a suicidal act.
('96', 192, 1, 4, 346264) He asked the refugees, men and women, to dispel all fear.
('96', 192, 1, 5, 346322) If he could put off his departure for Noakhali, he would gladly pass August 15 in the midst of the refugees at Wah.
('96', 192, 1, 6, 346438) He proposed, however, to do the next best thing.
('96', 192, 1, 7, 346487) The audience saw Dr. Sushila Nayyar taking notes of what he was saying.
('96', 192, 1, 8, 346559) She herself belonged to the district of Gujrat in Western Pakistan.
('96', 192, 1, 9, 346627) He had conferred with her before coming to the prayer meeting and though she was otherwise to accompany him to Noakhali, she had accepted his advice to stay with the refugees on his behalf, in order to help them to dispel all fear about August 15. He knew that she had no such fear.
('96', 192, 1, 10, 346910) She was with him in Noakhali as was also her brother Pyarelal.
('96', 192, 1, 11, 346973) She was posted in one of the worst affected areas of Noakhali and through medical assistance she had become popular among the Muslims as she was undoubtedly among the Hindus.
('96', 192, 1, 12, 347148) He had just heard from the District Commissioner who was a Muslim, that the refugees in and about Rawalpindi had nothing to fear.
('96', 192, 1, 13, 347278) They should feel as safe as the Muslim inhabitants.
('96', 192, 1, 14, 347330) Harijan, 24 8 1947

('96', 194, 3, 13, 351046) 275. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('96', 194, 4, 14, 351079) LAHORE, August 6, 1947
('96', 194, 5, 15, 351102) SARDAR SAHEB, I am giving this note to the Khaksar friends who had met me there 3. They complain of further injustice.
('96', 194, 5, 16, 351221) They had left their luggage in a hotel and come to see me.
('96', 194, 5, 17, 351280) The police took away their luggage in their absence.
('96', 194, 5, 18, 351333) I told them I could do no more than write and enquire.
('96', 194, 5, 19, 351388) They said: “No one would listen to us.
('96', 194, 5, 20, 351427) Give us a letter so that someone may give us a patient hearing, after that what is ordained will happen.” They say they desire nothing except to serve the people.
('96', 194, 5, 21, 351590) I am not asking you to hear them yourself.
('96', 194, 5, 22, 351633) It should be enough if you ask some official to hear their complaint.
('96', 194, 5, 23, 351703) Please send me a reply to my earlier letter on the subject.

('96', 195, 1, 2, 352063) 276. TALK WITH CONGRESS WORKERS
('96', 195, 2, 3, 352095) LAHORE, August 6, 1947
('96', 195, 3, 4, 352118) Mahatma Gandhi said : The rest of my life is going to be spent in Pakistan, maybe in East Bengal or West Punjab, or perhaps, the North West Frontier Province.
('96', 195, 4, 5, 352277) In answer to a question by Dr. Lehna Singh, General Secretary of the Punjab Provincial Congress Committee, Gandhiji said that if the Pakistan flag was such as would ensure equal rights and full protection to the minorities, they should all accept and honour the flag, and have absolutely no hesitation in saluting it.
('96', 195, 4, 6, 352595) He added : I would ask you not to disown the Pakistan flag merely on the ground that it bears the crescent.
('96', 195, 4, 7, 352703) I must, however, say that in case no assurance of the kind I have mentioned is forthcoming, at least I will refuse to salute the flag.
('96', 195, 5, 8, 352838) Replying to a similar question in connection with the flag of the Indian Union, he said: I must say that if the flag of the Indian Union will not contain the emblem of the charkha I will refuse to salute that flag.
('96', 195, 5, 9, 353053) You know the National Flag of India was first thought of by me and I cannot conceive of India’s National Flag without the emblem of the charkha.
('96', 195, 5, 10, 353198) We have, however, been told by Pandit Nehru and others that the sign of wheel or the chakra in the new National Flag symbolizes the charkha also.
('96', 195, 5, 11, 353344) Some describe the wheel mark as Sudarshan Chakra, but I know what Sudarshan Chakra means.
('96', 195, 6, 12, 353434) Referring to the Punjab, Gandhiji said : My heart has always been with the Punjab and the sad tales of woes and sufferings of the Punjab which I have been hearing, have made me always think of the Punjab.
('96', 195, 6, 13, 353639) Do not think that I have forgotten your province.
('96', 195, 6, 14, 353689) I am fully aware of the sufferings of the Punjab.
('96', 195, 6, 15, 353739) I have been yearning to come to the Punjab ever since I came to Delhi, but there were certain forces which were against my coming to this province.
('96', 195, 6, 16, 353887) My 10 present place is in Noakhali and I would go there even if I have to die.
('96', 195, 6, 17, 353966) But as soon as I am free from Noakhali I will come to the Punjab.
('96', 195, 6, 18, 354032) I hope to be free from Noakhali very soon.
('96', 195, 6, 19, 354075) I am grieved to learn that people are running away from the
('96', 196, 0, 1, 354135) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 197
('96', 196, 1, 2, 354181) West Punjab and I am told that Lahore is being evacuated by the non Muslims.
('96', 196, 1, 3, 354258) I must say that this is what it should not be.
('96', 196, 1, 4, 354305) If you think Lahore is dead or is dying, do not run away from it, but die with what you think is the dying Lahore.
('96', 196, 1, 5, 354420) When you suffer from fear you die before death comes to you.
('96', 196, 1, 6, 354481) That is not glorious.
('96', 196, 1, 7, 354503) I will not feel sorry if I hear that people in the Punjab have died not as cowards but as brave men.
('96', 196, 1, 8, 354604) I am not prepared to submit to any kind of compulsion or any interference with religion.
('96', 196, 1, 9, 354693) I would refuse to stop saying ‘Rama’ if I am forced to do so and would prefer to be murdered.
('96', 196, 1, 10, 354787) Similarly I cannot be forced to salute any flag.
('96', 196, 1, 11, 354836) But if in that act I am murdered I would bear no ill will against anyone and would rather pray for better sense for the person or persons who murder me.
('96', 196, 1, 12, 354989) My conception of a Sikh has always been of a brave person, who does not fear death, but who will not do any harm to any innocent person.
('96', 196, 2, 13, 355126) Gandhiji said that if the present quarrel between Hindus and Muslims and Sikhs continued it would serve as an invitation to any foreign power to come and invade India.
('96', 196, 2, 14, 355294) He, therefore, made an earnest appeal to put a stop to the present quarrel which did not credit either community.
('96', 196, 2, 15, 355408) The Hindustan Times, 8 8 1947
('96', 196, 3, 16, 355438) 277. TALK WITH RAILWAY GUARD
('96', 196, 4, 17, 355467) [After August 6, 1947] 1
('96', 196, 5, 18, 355492) There were big crowds at all the stops on the way.
('96', 196, 5, 19, 355543) On top of this, it began to rain heavily at night.
('96', 196, 5, 20, 355594) The roof of Gandhiji’s carriage leaked, flooding the compartment.
('96', 196, 5, 21, 355660) The guard suggested that Gandhiji shift to another compartment.
('96', 196, 6, 22, 355724) GANDHIJI: What will happen to this one?
('96', 196, 7, 23, 355764) GUARD: The passengers from the other compartment will occupy it.
('96', 196, 7, 24, 355829) If it is good enough for them, it should be good enough for me, too.
('96', 196, 7, 25, 355898) How can I think of making myself comfortable at others’ expense!
('96', 196, 8, 26, 355963) Is there any service I can render?
('96', 196, 8, 27, 355998) Do not harass poor passengers and do not take bribes.
('96', 196, 8, 28, 356052) That will be the greatest service you can render to me.

('96', 197, 1, 2, 356302) 278. A DRAFT DECLARATION
('96', 197, 2, 3, 356327) Shri Brijlal Nehru sends for publication the following draft declaration :
('96', 197, 3, 4, 356402) Draft declaration to be signed by all members of the Public Service in India, Civil or Military, and by all candidates for the Service, whether Central, Provincial or Local, and by all applicants for other profitable jobs under these Governments and the members of the legislatures including the Constituent Assembly :
('96', 197, 4, 5, 356721) I hereby solemnly declare that
('96', 197, 5, 6, 356752) 1. I am a subject of the Union of India to which I pledge my loyalty in all circumstances.
('96', 197, 6, 7, 356843) 2. I repudiate the theory that Hindus and the Muslims are two separate Nations and hold the view that all the people of India, to whatever race or religion they may belong, are parts of one Nation.
('96', 197, 7, 8, 357041) 3. I shall to conduct myself in all my actions and speech as to strengthen this idea of One Nationality of all the inhabitants of this ancient and sacred land.
('96', 197, 8, 9, 357201) 4. If at any time I am found guilty of a breach of this declaration, I shall render myself liable to removal from any office or post of profit that I may be holding at the time.
('96', 197, 8, 10, 357379) The wording may admit of improvement.
('96', 197, 8, 11, 357417) But the spirit behind is surely admirable and worthy of adoption if we are to get out of unhealthy growth in the body politic.
('96', 197, 9, 12, 357544) ON THE TRAIN TO PATNA, August 7, 1947

('96', 197, 11, 14, 357601) 279. NOTES
('96', 197, 12, 15, 357612) WHY NOT INDIAN?
('96', 197, 12, 16, 357628) His second question was why Lord Mountbatten was selected as the first Governor General.
('96', 197, 12, 17, 357717) The reason so far as I know is properly guessed by the questioner.
('96', 197, 12, 18, 357784) There was no equallysuitable Indian for the post.
('96', 197, 12, 19, 357834) He, being the part, if not the sole, author of the conception lying behind the Indian Independence Bill, seemed to the members of the Interim Government to be the fittest person to pilot the ship of State safe through the troubled waters.
('96', 197, 12, 20, 358073) The appointment if it was a
('96', 198, 0, 1, 358101) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 199
('96', 198, 1, 2, 358147) credit to the British, was equally a credit to the Indian statesmen who had shown themselves free from prejudice and who were capable of rising above prejudice.
('96', 198, 1, 3, 358308) They showed that they were brave enough to trust their erstwhile opponents.
('96', 198, 2, 4, 358384) THE MINORITIES
('96', 198, 3, 5, 358399) He next asks why I do not agree that the minorities should quit their respective dominions.
('96', 198, 3, 6, 358491) No one has asked me to agree.
('96', 198, 3, 7, 358521) But I should oppose any such movement There is no occasion to distrust the majority in either Dominion.
('96', 198, 3, 8, 358625) And in any case, now that there are two sovereign States in India, each has to ensure the proper treatment of the minorities in the other.
('96', 198, 3, 9, 358764) Let us hope that such a contingency will never arise.
('96', 198, 3, 10, 358818) I hold too that every right carries with it a duty, better still, there is no right which does not flow from duty duly performed.
('96', 198, 4, 11, 358948) LEAVING POLITICS AFTER THE 15TH?
('96', 198, 5, 12, 358981) Fourthly, he asks whether I would leave politics after the 15th when India will be free.
('96', 198, 5, 13, 359070) In the first instance there is no freedom approaching the Kingdom of God.
('96', 198, 5, 14, 359144) We seem to be as far from it as ever.
('96', 198, 5, 15, 359182) And in any case the life of the millions is my politics from which I dare not free myself without denying my life work and God.
('96', 198, 5, 16, 359310) That my politics may take a different turn is quite possible.
('96', 198, 5, 17, 359372) But that will be determined by circumstances.
('96', 198, 5, 18, 359418) Lastly he says :
('96', 198, 6, 19, 359435) You have done a lot of work in Bihar; why was the Punjab ignored?
('96', 198, 6, 20, 359501) All I can say is that my not going to the Punjab must not be counted as my neglect of the province.
('96', 198, 6, 21, 359601) Nevertheless the question is quite apposite and has been asked more than once.
('96', 198, 6, 22, 359680) The neatest answer I gave was that I had no call from within and my counsellors gave me no encouragement.

('96', 199, 1, 2, 359885) 280. STUDENTS’ DIFFICULTIES
('96', 199, 2, 3, 359913) There is an attempt today to bring together all the existing students’ organizations in a national convention, to revise the basis of the student movement and to evolve a united national organization of students.
('96', 199, 2, 4, 360126) What, in your opinion, should be the scope of this new organization?
('96', 199, 2, 5, 360195) What activities should this students’ organization undertake in the new circumstances in the country?
('96', 199, 2, 6, 360297) There is no doubt that there should be one national organization including the Hindus, the Muslims and the others.
('96', 199, 2, 7, 360412) Students are the makers of the future.
('96', 199, 2, 8, 360451) They cannot be partitioned.
('96', 199, 2, 9, 360479) I am sorry to observe that neither the students have thought for themselves nor have the leaders left them to their studies so that they can become good citizens.
('96', 199, 2, 10, 360642) The rot began with the alien government.
('96', 199, 2, 11, 360683) We, the inheritors, have not taken the trouble to rectify the errors of the past.
('96', 199, 2, 12, 360765) Then the different political groups have sought to catch the students as if they were shoals of fish.
('96', 199, 2, 13, 360867) And stupidly the students have run into the net spread for them.
('96', 199, 2, 14, 360932) It is therefore a herculean task for any students’ organization to undertake.
('96', 199, 2, 15, 361010) But there must be a heroic spirit among them who would not shrink from the task.
('96', 199, 2, 16, 361091) The scope will be to knit them together into one.
('96', 199, 2, 17, 361141) This they cannot do unless they will learn to steer clear of active politics.
('96', 199, 2, 18, 361219) A student’s duty is to study the various problems that require solution.
('96', 199, 2, 19, 361292) His time for action comes after he finishes his studies.
('96', 199, 3, 20, 361349) Today students’ organizations are more concerned with passing resolutions on political affairs than devoting their energies to the task of national reconstruction.
('96', 199, 3, 21, 361513) This is partly due to the attempts which political party have been making to capture the students’ organizations for their party purposes.
('96', 199, 3, 22, 361652) Our present disunity too can be traced to these party politics.
('96', 199, 3, 23, 361716) We, therefore, want to evolve some method by which we can prevent the repetition of all this party politics and disunity in the proposed national union of students.
('96', 199, 3, 24, 361881) Do you think it is possible for the students’ organizations to eschew politics completely?
('96', 199, 3, 25, 361972) If not, what, in your opinion, is the extent to which students’ organizations should interest themselves in politics?
('96', 199, 3, 26, 362090) This question is partly answered above.
('96', 199, 3, 27, 362130) They must eschew active politics.
('96', 199, 3, 28, 362164) It is a sign of one sided growth that all parties 14 have made use of the student world for their purpose.
('96', 199, 3, 29, 362271) This was probably inevitable when the purpose of education was to create a
('96', 200, 0, 1, 362346) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 201
('96', 200, 1, 2, 362392) race of slaves who would hug their slavery.
('96', 200, 1, 3, 362436) That part of the business is over, I hope.
('96', 200, 1, 4, 362479) The students’ first business is to think out the education that the children of a free nation should receive.
('96', 200, 1, 5, 362589) The education of today is obviously not such.
('96', 200, 1, 6, 362635) I must not go into the question as to what it should be.
('96', 200, 1, 7, 362692) Only they must not allow themselves to be deceived into the belief that it is the function only of the elders in the university senates.
('96', 200, 1, 8, 362829) They must stimulate the faculty of thinking.
('96', 200, 1, 9, 362874) I do not even remotely suggest that the students can force the situation by strikes and the like.
('96', 200, 1, 10, 362972) They have to create public opinion by offering constructive and enlightened criticism.
('96', 200, 1, 11, 363059) The senators having been brought up in the old school are slow to move.
('96', 200, 1, 12, 363131) They can truly be acted upon by enlightenment.
('96', 200, 2, 13, 363178) Today, the majority of students are not interesting themselves in national service.
('96', 200, 2, 14, 363262) Many of them are cultivating what they consider ‘fashionable’ western habits, and more and more students are resorting to bad habits like drinking, etc.
('96', 200, 2, 15, 363415) There is little efficiency and little desire for independent thinking.
('96', 200, 2, 16, 363486) We want to tackle all these problems, and build up character, discipline and efficiency in youth.
('96', 200, 2, 17, 363584) How do you think we can do it ?
('96', 200, 2, 18, 363616) This deals with the present distemper.
('96', 200, 2, 19, 363655) It will disappear when a calm atmosphere is produced, when the students cease to be agitators and take to sober studies.
('96', 200, 2, 20, 363776) A student’s life has been rightly likened to the life of a sannyasi.
('96', 200, 2, 21, 363845) He must be the embodiment of simple living and high thinking.
('96', 200, 2, 22, 363907) He must be discipline incarnate.
('96', 200, 2, 23, 363940) His pleasure is derived from his studies.
('96', 200, 2, 24, 363982) They do provide real pleasure when study ceases to be a tax the student has to pay.
('96', 200, 2, 25, 364066) What can be a greater pleasure than that a student marches from knowledge to more knowledge?

('96', 206, 4, 7, 373563) 290. INTERVIEW TO CONGRESS MINISTERS
('96', 206, 5, 8, 373600) August 10, 1947
('96', 206, 6, 9, 373616) The Congress Ministers of the Government of Bengal interviewed Gandhiji at 3.30 p.
('96', 206, 6, 10, 373699) One of the questions which they wanted to discuss was the manner in which the 15th should be celebrated.
('96', 206, 6, 11, 373804) Gandhiji said, according to him, the advice could only be for fasting, prayer and a dedication to the spinning wheel.
('96', 206, 6, 12, 373922) What else could they do when all around the country was burning, when people were dying from lack of food and clothing?
('96', 206, 7, 13, 374042) The question of the relation between Pakistan and India was also raised by one of the Ministers.
('96', 206, 7, 14, 374139) Gandhiji said : Each State should perform its duty properly.
('96', 206, 7, 15, 374200) If the conduct is straight, there is likelihood of reunion.
('96', 206, 7, 16, 374260) But what he witnessed today was a preparation for hostility not for friendship.
('96', 206, 8, 17, 374340) My Days with Gandhi, p.

('96', 207, 4, 5, 375299) 292. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 207, 5, 6, 375329) SODEPUR, August 10, 1947
('96', 207, 6, 7, 375354) Gandhiji said that he had thought that he was to go to Noakhali the next day (Monday).
('96', 207, 6, 8, 375441) Owing to the pressure from many Muslim friends who had seen him, he had decided to stay to see if he could contribute his share in the return of sanity in the premier city of India.
('96', 207, 6, 9, 375623) 2 The argument of the Muslim friends went home.
('96', 207, 6, 10, 375671) He had at the same time said that if he did not go to Noakhali and any mishap took place, his life would become forfeit as he had said already about Bihar.
('96', 207, 6, 11, 375827) He had seen the Ministers and others too during the day.
('96', 207, 6, 12, 375884) He would like to see the places where destruction was said to have been wrought by the Hindus.
('96', 207, 6, 13, 375979) He had also learnt that there were parts of Calcutta which were inaccessible to the Hindus, though many premises therein used to be occupied by them.
('96', 207, 6, 14, 376129) Similar was the case with the Hindu localities.
('96', 207, 6, 15, 376177) He hung his head in shame to listen to this recital of man’s barbarism.
('96', 207, 6, 16, 376249) He would love to go to these places and see for himself how much truth there was in these recitals.
('96', 207, 6, 17, 376349) He was told that there were not more than 23% Muslims in Calcutta.
('96', 207, 6, 18, 376416) It was unthinkable that such a minority could coerce the majority without countenance from or incompetence of authority.
('96', 207, 6, 19, 376537) Similarly it was unthinkable that in the midst of a government which knew the art of government, the majority could for one moment be permitted to coerce the minority.
('96', 207, 6, 20, 376705) He was also told that as the Muslim police and officers were alleged to be doing before, now that the Congress Ministry was in power, the Hindu police and officers had become partial in the administration of justice.
('96', 207, 6, 21, 376922) If this wretched spirit of communalism had entered the police force, the prospect was bleak indeed.
('96', 207, 6, 22, 377022) He hoped that the police would realize the dignity of their profession.
('96', 207, 6, 23, 377094) Harijan, 24 8 1947

('96', 211, 11, 26, 382159) 300. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 211, 12, 27, 382189) SODEPUR, August 11, 1947
('96', 211, 13, 28, 382214) This evening I must devote to answering some questions addressed to me.
('96', 211, 13, 29, 382286) One of them complains that prominent men were admitted but comparatively unknown persons were insulted.
('96', 211, 13, 30, 382390) There was an inordinate rush throughout the day, it being Sunday.
('96', 211, 13, 31, 382456) I agree that when there is such a rush, there should be no distinction made between known and unknown persons.
('96', 211, 13, 32, 382567) But I had given previous appointments to some who had to be admitted.
('96', 211, 13, 33, 382637) Then there were many
('96', 211, 14, 34, 382658) 1Vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 6 8 1947.
('96', 212, 0, 1, 382705) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 213
('96', 212, 1, 2, 382751) who were specially working for the day.
('96', 212, 1, 3, 382791) I would, therefore, plead with those who may feel disappointed on such occasions to have forbearance and patience as I would plead with the volunteers to be uniformly courteous and gentle with the public.
('96', 212, 1, 4, 382996) I read something about the Chittagong flood the day before yesterday, when I came to Calcutta.
('96', 212, 1, 5, 383091) This is the third day and I see that the angry waters have not subsided, and the extent of loss of life and property no one can yet assess with any degree of accuracy.
('96', 212, 1, 6, 383259) It is hardly necessary to remind ourselves in the face of such catastrophe that we may not think of East or West or Pakistan and Hindustan.
('96', 212, 1, 7, 383399) Adversity makes strange bed fellows.
('96', 212, 1, 8, 383436) Surely then those who were bed fellows till yesterday must not cease to be at least on such occasions, whatever their political or religious differences might be or might have been.
('96', 212, 1, 9, 383618) It is a calamity to cope with not merely for East Bengal but for the whole of Bengal, and not for Bengal only but certainly for the whole of India.
('96', 212, 1, 10, 383766) There must be a strong reliable committee to collect and distribute funds.
('96', 212, 1, 11, 383841) Local men come first.
('96', 212, 1, 12, 383863) Round them can arise an all Bengal relief committee, and if need be an all India one.
('96', 212, 1, 13, 383949) No trouble need be given to all India if Bengal alone can cope with the situation.
('96', 212, 1, 14, 384032) My whole heart goes out to Chittagong in its dire calamity.
('96', 212, 1, 15, 384092) May the survivors bear it with fortitude.
('96', 212, 1, 16, 384134) Correspondents continue to ask all sorts of questions about appointments of Governors, Ministers and the like, as if I was a member of the Congress Working Committee or could affect its decisions.
('96', 212, 1, 17, 384331) I know and admit that I have and shall always retain by right of service a place in the hearts of Congressmen.
('96', 212, 1, 18, 384442) I know too that I shall forfeit that place immediately I begin to overstep my limits.
('96', 212, 1, 19, 384528) Legal status I have none, moral status can be retained only so long as the moral platform is firmly held.
('96', 212, 2, 20, 384634) Do you agree that the leaders of both the communities should go to East and West Bengal and show that they have no differences now to quarrel over?
('96', 212, 2, 21, 384782) My answer is emphatically yes, if the leaders are one at heart.
('96', 212, 2, 22, 384846) If the word belies the thought, the going about will be worse than useless.
('96', 212, 2, 23, 384922) The newspaper war still continues.
('96', 212, 2, 24, 384957) I would always prefer an open war to the war of hearts.
('96', 212, 2, 25, 385013) Are we sure that the leaders trust one another?
('96', 212, 2, 26, 385061) My fear is that neither at the top nor at the bottom are we cleansed of hypocrisy.
('96', 212, 2, 27, 385144) I can, therefore, but repeat my old argument that we must unlearn the habit of retaliation in every shape and form.
('96', 213, 0, 1, 385260) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 213, 1, 2, 385302) Blow for blow is a crude form and probably more excusable than the subtle one of evil thought for its kind.
('96', 213, 1, 3, 385410) Thought is the root of speech and deed.
('96', 213, 1, 4, 385450) I am sorry that I am unable to return a more comfortable answer.
('96', 213, 1, 5, 385515) There is none that I know.
('96', 213, 1, 6, 385542) This is said to hearten ourselves, not to dishearten us.
('96', 213, 1, 7, 385599) For I have said the naked truth.
('96', 213, 1, 8, 385632) Within my experience it ever heartens.
('96', 213, 1, 9, 385671) Is it not heartening to know the true remedy for a disease?
('96', 213, 1, 10, 385731) Any other is a palliative and in the end aggravates the disease.

('96', 215, 5, 9, 388918) 304. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 215, 6, 10, 388948) SODEPUR, August 12, 1947
('96', 215, 7, 11, 388973) Gandhiji said that the 15th instant was to be a landmark in India’s history.
('96', 215, 7, 12, 389050) It was a day when India would be declared free of the foreign yoke.
('96', 215, 7, 13, 389118) It was to be an independent nation.
('96', 215, 7, 14, 389154) He had explained how the day was to be observed, 1 but he was probably alone in the view.
('96', 215, 7, 15, 389244) Already there was an announcement that the Muslims of Calcutta were to observe it as a day of mourning.
('96', 215, 7, 16, 389348) He hoped that it was not true.
('96', 215, 7, 17, 389379) No man could be compelled to observe the day in a particular manner.
('96', 215, 7, 18, 389448) It was to be a perfectly voluntary act.
('96', 215, 7, 19, 389488) He would ask his Muslim countrymen not to mourn over the freedom.
('96', 215, 7, 20, 389554) The present distemper was to go.
('96', 215, 7, 21, 389587) What were the Hindus in Pakistan to do?
('96', 215, 7, 22, 389627) They should salute the Pakistan Flag if it meant the freedom and equality of all in every respect, irrespective of caste, colour or creed.
('96', 215, 7, 23, 389766) He had heard further that on that day the Indians in the French and Portuguese possessions were to declare their freedom from France and Portugal respectively.
('96', 215, 8, 24, 389926) That, he said, would be a thoughtless act.
('96', 215, 8, 25, 389969) It would be a sign perhaps of arrogance.
('96', 215, 8, 26, 390010) The British were retiring, not the French and the Portuguese.
('96', 215, 8, 27, 390072) He, undoubtedly, held the view that the Indians in these possessions were bound to merge in Independent India in good time.
('96', 215, 8, 28, 390196) Only the Indians in those territories should not take the law in their own hands.
('96', 215, 8, 29, 390278) They had constitutional means open to them and then there was their Chief Minister who had vindicated the freedom of Indonesia.
('96', 215, 8, 30, 390406) Surely, he was not going to neglect his own kith and kin in the two possessions.
('96', 215, 8, 31, 390487) If they had any doubt about the validity of his advice, they should act on Panditiji’s advice.
('96', 215, 9, 32, 390582) He then came to another important subject.
('96', 215, 9, 33, 390625) They knew that he prolonged his stay in Calcutta by two days at the instance of Muslim friends.
('96', 215, 9, 34, 390721) Last night Shaheed Saheb Suhrawardy had come to see him.
('96', 215, 9, 35, 390778) He had suggested that it would be contrary to his (Gandhiji’s) practice to leave Calcutta while it was going through the horrors of communal strife.
('96', 215, 9, 36, 390927) Shaheed Saheb had suggested that Gandhiji should prolong his stay
('96', 215, 10, 37, 390993) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 8 8 1947.

('96', 216, 1, 2, 391083) in the city and work until real peace was restored.
('96', 216, 1, 3, 391135) Gandhiji had replied that Suhrawardy Saheb and he should live under the same roof in the disturbed parts.
('96', 216, 1, 4, 391241) It would be best to live unprotected by the police or the military.
('96', 216, 1, 5, 391309) In brotherly fashion, they would approach the people, argue with them and tell them that now that partition had taken place by agreement, there was no longer any reason why the parties should quarrel.
('96', 216, 1, 6, 391510) The decision of the Boundary Commission was going to be announced in a day or two, and it was in the fitness of things that all the parties should abide by the decision in a becoming manner.
('96', 216, 1, 7, 391701) After all, the parties had appointed an arbitration tribunal.
('96', 216, 1, 8, 391763) They were in honour bound to abide by the Award whatever it was.
('96', 216, 2, 9, 391828) Gandhiji’s proposal to Suhrawardy Saheb was of such an important nature that the latter could not afford to give a hasty reply.
('96', 216, 2, 10, 391956) Gandhiji had, therefore, asked Shaheed Saheb to consult his aged father as well as his daughter before coming to a decision.

('96', 216, 3, 12, 392259) It was now time, therefore, for the two friends to choose quarters in the midst of the worst affected areas and see what could be done by joint effort.

('96', 216, 4, 20, 392832) Nobody had any right to prejudge anybody.

('96', 216, 5, 26, 393265) They were to bless them on the mission on which they were embarking.

('96', 219, 1, 2, 396409) 309. DISCUSSION WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF DEMONSTRATORS 1
('96', 219, 2, 3, 396465) HYDARI MANSION, CALCUTTA, August 13, 1947
('96', 219, 3, 4, 396507) Presently the representatives of the demonstrators were ushered in to meet Gandhiji.
('96', 219, 3, 5, 396592) One of them began :
('96', 219, 4, 6, 396612) Last year when Direct Action was launched on the Hindus on August 16, you did not come to our rescue.
('96', 219, 4, 7, 396714) Now that there has been just a little trouble in the Muslim quarters, you have come running to their succour.
('96', 219, 4, 8, 396824) We don’t want you here.
('96', 219, 5, 9, 396848) GANDHIJI: Much water has flown under the bridge since August 1946. What the Muslims did then was utterly wrong.
('96', 219, 5, 10, 396960) But what is the use of avenging the year 1946 on 1947?
('96', 219, 5, 11, 397015) I was on my way to Noakhali where your own kith and kin desired my presence.
('96', 219, 5, 12, 397092) But I now see that I shall have to serve Noakhali only from here.
('96', 219, 5, 13, 397158) You must understand that I have come here to serve not only Muslims but Hindus, Muslims and all alike.
('96', 219, 5, 14, 397261) Those who are indulging in brutalities are bringing dis grace upon themselves and the religion they represent.
('96', 219, 5, 15, 397372) I am going to put myself under your protection.
('96', 219, 5, 16, 397420) You are welcome to turn against me and play the opposite role if you so choose.
('96', 219, 5, 17, 397500) I have nearly reached the end of my life’s journey.
('96', 219, 5, 18, 397552) I have not much farther to go.
('96', 219, 5, 19, 397583) But let me tell you that if you again go mad, I will not be a living witness to it.
('96', 219, 5, 20, 397667) I have given the same ultimatum to the Muslims of Noakhali also; I have earned the right.
('96', 219, 5, 21, 397757) Before there is another outbreak of Muslim madness in Noakhali, they will find me dead.
('96', 219, 5, 22, 397845) Why cannot you see that by taking this step I have put the burden of the peace of Noakhali on the shoulders of Shaheed Suhrawardy and his friends—including men like Mian Ghulam Sarwar and the rest?
('96', 219, 5, 23, 398043) This is no small gain.
('96', 219, 6, 24, 398066) 1 According to the source, “an old abandoned Muslim house in an indescribably filthy locality, had hastily been cleaned up for Gandhiji’s residence.
('96', 219, 6, 25, 398215) It was .
('96', 219, 6, 26, 398224) open on all sides .
('96', 219, 6, 27, 398244) An excited crowd of young men stood at the gate as Gandhiji’s car arrived.
('96', 219, 6, 28, 398319) They shouted : ‘Why have you come here ?
('96', 219, 6, 29, 398360) You did not come when we were in trouble.
('96', 219, 6, 30, 398402) Now that the Muslims have complained all this fuss is being made over it.
('96', 219, 6, 31, 398476) Why did you not go to places from where Hindus have fled?’ .
('96', 219, 6, 32, 398537) The situation threatened to take an ugly turn.
('96', 219, 6, 33, 398584) Gandhiji sent some of his men outside to expostulate with the demonstrators and tell them to send in their representatives to meet him.”
('96', 220, 0, 1, 398721) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 221
('96', 220, 1, 2, 398767) We do not want your sermons on ahimsa.
('96', 220, 1, 3, 398806) You go away from here.
('96', 220, 1, 4, 398829) We won’t allow the Muslims to live here.
('96', 220, 1, 5, 398870) This means that you do not want my services.
('96', 220, 1, 6, 398915) If you will co operate with me and allow me to carry on my work, it will enable the Hindus to return and to live in all the places from where they have been driven out.
('96', 220, 1, 7, 399084) On the other hand, it will profit you nothing to remember old wrongs and nurse old enmities.
('96', 220, 2, 8, 399177) An eighteen year old youngster interposed:
('96', 220, 3, 9, 399220) History shows that Hindus and Muslims can never be friends.
('96', 220, 3, 10, 399280) Anyway, ever since I was born I have seen them only fighting each other.
('96', 220, 4, 11, 399353) GANDHIJI: Well, I have seen more of history than anyone of you, and I tell you that I have known Hindu boys who called Muslims ‘uncle’.
('96', 220, 4, 12, 399489) Hindus and Muslims used to participate in each other’s festivals and other auspicious occasions.
('96', 220, 4, 13, 399586) You want to force me to leave this place but you should know that I have never submitted to force.
('96', 220, 4, 14, 399685) It is contrary to my nature.
('96', 220, 4, 15, 399714) You can obstruct my work, even kill me.
('96', 220, 4, 16, 399754) I won’t invoke the help of the police.
('96', 220, 4, 17, 399793) You can prevent me from leaving this house, but what is the use of your dubbing me an enemy of the Hindus ?
('96', 220, 4, 18, 399901) I will not accept the lable.
('96', 220, 4, 19, 399930) To make me quit, you have to convince me that I have made a mistake in coming here.
('96', 220, 5, 20, 400014) Thus it went on till eight o’clock.
('96', 220, 5, 21, 400050) At last Gandhiji said : I put it to you, young men, how can I, who am a Hindu by birth, a Hindu by creed and a Hindu of Hindus in my way of living, be an ‘enemy’ of Hindus?
('96', 220, 5, 22, 400223) Does this not show narrow intolerance on your part?
('96', 220, 6, 23, 400275) His words had a profound effect.
('96', 220, 6, 24, 400308) Slowly and imperceptibly the opposition began to soften.
('96', 220, 6, 25, 400365) Still they were not completely converted.
('96', 220, 6, 26, 400407) One of them said: “Perhaps we should now go.” Gandhiji replied : Yes, you must go.
('96', 220, 6, 27, 400490) It is already late.
('96', 220, 6, 28, 400510) Come again in the morning when you have thought things over.
('96', 220, 7, 29, 400571) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. II, pp.

('96', 228, 6, 14, 411391) If and when the Hindus of Beliaghata invited their Muslim neighbours to return, they would next move to a predominantly Muslim area, where they would stay till the Hindus were invited to return and so on till each community had invited its neighbours to return to their former houses all over Calcutta.

('96', 228, 8, 17, 411788) 323. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('96', 228, 9, 18, 411820) BELIAGHATA, CALCUTTA, August 14, 1947
('96', 228, 10, 19, 411858) He first said that the next day was the day fixed for deliverance from the foreign yoke.
('96', 228, 10, 20, 411947) It was, therefore, a great day.
('96', 228, 10, 21, 411979) They were bound to celebrate it.
('96', 228, 10, 22, 412012) In his opinion it was a day when both the Dominions were to shoulder a heavy burden.
('96', 228, 10, 23, 412097) He invited everyone to have twenty four hours’ fast and prayer during the day for the well being of India as a whole and pass it in spinning as much as possible.
('96', 228, 10, 24, 412259) For it was hand spinning that had knit the poor and the rich together and that had given occupation to countless men and women who were without occupation.
('96', 228, 11, 25, 412415) 1Vide also “Discussion with Representatives of Demonstrators”, 13 8 1947. 2 According to the source, “a packed audience listened to Gandhiji without the slightest disturbance.”
('96', 229, 0, 1, 412592) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 229, 1, 2, 412634) He then returned to the reason for his postponing the visit to Noakhali and coming to stay in the present place.
('96', 229, 1, 3, 412747) He said that Shaheed Saheb had come to see him and induce him to do his bit in bringing about peace in Calcutta which was burning.
('96', 229, 1, 4, 412878) The appeal had its effect upon him.
('96', 229, 1, 5, 412914) He agreed provided Shaheed Saheb went with him to the affected areas and stayed there under the same roof with him, till the fury had abated and till complete friendship between the two communities was restored.
('96', 229, 1, 6, 413126) Therefore, they were to work with one mind without mental reservation and without any secrets in the matter from one another.
('96', 229, 1, 7, 413252) Shaheed Saheb had taken one night to confer with his aged father and his daughter and had sent over his decision the next day.
('96', 229, 1, 8, 413379) 1 And he had sent one message which brought them to the present place yesterday.
('96', 229, 1, 9, 413460) He had had many warnings also against Shaheed Saheb.
('96', 229, 1, 10, 413513) He was unaffected by the warnings.
('96', 229, 1, 11, 413548) He was bound to believe his word as he expected him to accept his (Gandhiji’s) word.
('96', 229, 1, 12, 413633) Let them not think that they were to neglect the parts of Calcutta which were deserted by their Hindu inhabitants and were occupied by Muslims.
('96', 229, 1, 13, 413777) They were working for the peace of the whole of Calcutta and he invited his audience to believe with them that if Calcutta returned to sanity and real friendship, then Noakhali and the rest of India would be safe.
('96', 229, 1, 14, 413991) He mentioned that Shaheed Saheb was in the building, but he had, with his consent, kept himself away from the meeting as he wanted to avoid being the slightest cause of irritation to the meeting.
('96', 229, 1, 15, 414187) 2 But he was glad that the audience had exhibited becoming tolerance and gave him the courage to bring Shaheed Saheb to the meeting.
('96', 229, 1, 16, 414320) After all they should live and work together in the open and perfect co operation if their difficult mission was to succeed.
('96', 229, 1, 17, 414445) Harijan, 24 8 1947

('96', 231, 1, 2, 417342) 325. LETTER TO RAMENDRA G. SINHA
('96', 231, 2, 3, 417375) BELIAGHATA, CALCUTTA, August 15, 1947
('96', 231, 3, 4, 417413) DEAR FRIEND, I must take you at your word.
('96', 231, 3, 5, 417456) As you say, your father had in him non violence of the brave.
('96', 231, 3, 6, 417518) Such a one never dies, destruction of the body has no meaning for him.
('96', 231, 3, 7, 417589) Therefore, it is not right for you, your mother [or anyone] 1 to mourn over the death of your brave father.
('96', 231, 3, 8, 417697) He has left, in dying, a rich legacy which I hope you will all deserve.
('96', 231, 3, 9, 417769) The best advice I can give is that you should all do whatever you can for the building up of the freedom that has come to us today and the first thing you can do is to copy your father’s bravery.
('96', 231, 3, 10, 417965) Bravery of non violence is shown in a variety of ways, not necessarily in dying at the hands of an assassin.
('96', 231, 3, 11, 418074) There is no doubt that if you earn an honest price for the [loss] 2 of your [dear ones]3 that by itself will be a contribution to the preservation of the [dearly earned freedom].
('96', 231, 4, 12, 418253) Yours sincerely,
('96', 231, 5, 13, 418270) M. K. GANDHI RAMENDRA G. SINHA GOPAL MULLICK LANE BOWBAZAR CALCUTTA

('96', 234, 1, 2, 420860) 330. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('96', 234, 2, 3, 420892) CALCUTTA, August 15, 1947
('96', 234, 3, 4, 420918) Gandhiji congratulated Calcutta on Hindus and Muslims meeting together in perfect friendliness.
('96', 234, 3, 5, 421014) Muslims shouted the same slogans of joy as the Hindus.
('96', 234, 3, 6, 421069) They flew the tricolour without the slightest hesitation.
('96', 234, 3, 7, 421127) What was more, the Hindus were admitted to mosques and Muslims were admitted to the Hindu mandirs.
('96', 234, 3, 8, 421226) This news reminded him of the Khilafat days when Hindus and Muslims fraternized with one another.
('96', 234, 3, 9, 421324) If this exhibition was from the heart and was not a momentary impulse, it was better than the Khilafat days.
('96', 234, 3, 10, 421433) The simple reason was that they had both drunk the poison cup of disturbances.
('96', 234, 3, 11, 421512) The nectar of friendliness should, therefore, taste sweeter than before.
('96', 234, 3, 12, 421585) He was however sorry to hear that in a certain part the poor Muslims experienced molestation.
('96', 234, 3, 13, 421679) He hoped that Calcutta including Howrah will be entirely free from the communal virus for ever.
('96', 234, 3, 14, 421775) Then indeed they need have no fear about East Bengal and the rest of India.
('96', 234, 3, 15, 421851) He was sorry, therefore, to hear that madness still reged in Lahore.
('96', 234, 3, 16, 421920) He could hope and feel sure that the noble example of Calcutta, if it was sincere, would affect the Punjab and the other parts of India.
('96', 234, 3, 17, 422057) He then referred to Chittagong.
('96', 234, 3, 18, 422089) Rain was no respecter of persons.
('96', 234, 3, 19, 422123) It engulfed both Muslims and Hindus.
('96', 234, 3, 20, 422160) It was the duty of the whole of Bengal to feel one with the sufferers of Chittagong.
('96', 234, 4, 21, 422245) He then referred to the fact thet the people realizing that India was free, took possession of the Government House and in affection besieged their new Governor Rajaji.
('96', 234, 4, 22, 422414) He would be glad if it meant only a token of the people’s power.
('96', 234, 4, 23, 422479) But he would be sick and sorry if the people thought that they could do what they liked with the Government and other property.
('96', 234, 4, 24, 422607) That would be criminal lawlessness.
('96', 234, 4, 25, 422643) He hoped, therefore, that they had of their own accord vacated the Governor’s palace as readily as they had occupied it.
('96', 234, 4, 26, 422764) He would warn the people that now that they were free, they would use the freedom with wise restraint.
('96', 234, 4, 27, 422867) They should know that they were to treat the Europeans who stayed in India with the same regard as they would expect for themselves.
('96', 234, 4, 28, 423000) They must know that they were masters of no one but of themselves.
('96', 234, 4, 29, 423067) They must not compel anyone to do anything against his will.
('96', 234, 4, 30, 423128) Harijan, 24 8 1947
('96', 234, 5, 31, 423147) 1 The meeting was held in Rash Bagan Maidan, Beliaghata.
('96', 235, 0, 1, 423204) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 235, 1, 2, 423246) 331. MIRACLE OR ACCIDENT?
('96', 235, 2, 3, 423272) Shaheed Saheb Suhrawardy and I are living together in a Muslim manzil in Beliaghata where Muslims have been reported to be sufferers.
('96', 235, 2, 4, 423406) We occupied the house on Wednesday the 13th instant and on the 14th it seemed as if there never had been bad blood between the Hindus and the Muslims.
('96', 235, 2, 5, 423557) In their thousands they began to embrace one another and they began to pass freely through places which were considered to be points of danger by one party or the other.
('96', 235, 2, 6, 423727) Indeed, Hindus were taken to their masjids by their Muslim brethren and the latter were taken by their Hindu brethren to the mandirs.
('96', 235, 2, 7, 423861) Both with one voice shouted “Jai Hind” or “Hindu Muslims!
('96', 235, 2, 8, 423919) Be one”.
('96', 235, 2, 9, 423928) As I have said above, we are living in a Muslim’s house and Muslim volunteers are attending to our comforts with the greatest attention.
('96', 235, 2, 10, 424065) Muslim volunteers do the cooking.
('96', 235, 2, 11, 424099) Many were eager to come from the Khadi Pratishthan for attendance, but I prevented them.
('96', 235, 2, 12, 424188) I was determined that we should be fully satisfied with whatever the Muslim brothers and sisters were able to give for our creature comforts and I must say that the determination has resulted in unmixed good.
('96', 235, 2, 13, 424397) Here in the compound numberless Hindus and Muslims continue to stream in shouting the favourite slogans.
('96', 235, 2, 14, 424502) One might almost say that the joy of fraternization is leaping up from hour to hour.
('96', 235, 2, 15, 424587) Is this to be called a miracle or an accident?
('96', 235, 2, 16, 424634) By whatever name it may be described, it is quite clear that all the credit that is being given to me from all sides is quite undeserved; nor can it be said to be deserved by Shaheed Saheb.
('96', 235, 2, 17, 424824) This sudden upheaval is not the work of one or two men.
('96', 235, 2, 18, 424880) We are toys in the hands of God.
('96', 235, 2, 19, 424913) He makes us dance to His tune.
('96', 235, 2, 20, 424944) The utmost therefore, that man can do is to refrain from interfering with the dance and that he should render full obedience to his Maker’s will.
('96', 235, 2, 21, 425090) Thus considered, it can be said that in this miracle He has used us two as His instruments and as for myself I only ask whether the dream of my youth is to be realized in the evening of my life.
('96', 235, 2, 22, 425285) For those who have full faith in God, this is neither a miracle nor an accident.
('96', 235, 2, 23, 425366) A chain of events can be clearly seen to show that the two were being prepared, unconsciously to themselves, for fraternization.
('96', 235, 3, 24, 425495) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 24 8 1947.
('96', 236, 0, 1, 425565) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 237
('96', 236, 1, 2, 425611) In this process our advent on the scene enabled the onlooker to give us credit for the consummation of the happy event.
('96', 236, 1, 3, 425731) Be that as it may, the delirious happenings remind me of the early days of the Khilafat movement.
('96', 236, 1, 4, 425829) The fraternization then burst on the public as a new experience.
('96', 236, 1, 5, 425894) Moreover, we had then the Khilafat and swaraj as our twin goals.
('96', 236, 1, 6, 425959) Today we have nothing of the kind.
('96', 236, 1, 7, 425994) We have drunk the poison of mutual hatred and so this nectar of fraternization tastes all the sweeter and the sweetness should never wear out.
('96', 236, 1, 8, 426137) In the present exuberance one hears also the cry of ‘Long Live Hindustan and Pakistan,’ from the joint throats of the Hindus and the Muslims.
('96', 236, 1, 9, 426279) I think it is quite proper.
('96', 236, 1, 10, 426307) Whatever was the cause for the agreement, three parties accepted Pakistan.
('96', 236, 1, 11, 426382) If then the two are not enemies one of the other, and here evidently they are not, surely there is nothing wrong in the above cry.
('96', 236, 1, 12, 426513) Indeed, if the two have become friends, not to wish long life to both the States would probably be an act of disloyalty.
('96', 236, 2, 13, 426634) BELIAGHATA, August 16, 1947 Harijan, 24 8 1947

('96', 237, 9, 26, 428613) It could never promote, denominational education out of public funds 4 .

('96', 238, 2, 4, 429554) In his characteristic style, he said: We have discarded foreign power, not the unseen foreign influence.

('96', 239, 6, 15, 432523) 336. AN INDIAN GOVERNOR
('96', 239, 7, 16, 432547) In construing the word India, here it includes both Hindostan and Pakistan.
('96', 239, 7, 17, 432623) Hindustan may mean the country of the Hindus strictly so called, Pakistan may mean the country of the Muslims.
('96', 239, 7, 18, 432734) Both the uses are,in my opinion, irregular.
('96', 239, 7, 19, 432778) Hence, I have purposely use the word Hindostan.
('96', 239, 7, 20, 432826) The Khilafat Swaraj Non co operation Resolution of 1920 passed in Calcutta at the Special Session of the Congress 2 , which has brought freedom from the British yoke, was for both the Hindus and the Muslims, designed to induce self purification so as to bring about non co operation between forces of evil and those of good.
('96', 239, 7, 21, 433151) Hence 1. An Indian Governor should, in his own person and in his surroundings, be a teetotaller.
('96', 239, 7, 22, 433248) Without this, prohibition of the fiery liquid is well nigh inconceivable.
('96', 239, 7, 23, 433322) 2. He and his surroundings should represent hand spinning as a visible token of identification with the dumb millions of India, a
('96', 239, 8, 24, 433452) 1 By Dr. N. R. Dhar, is not reproduced here 2 Vide “The Non co operation Resolution”, 5 9 1920.
('96', 240, 0, 1, 433548) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 241
('96', 240, 1, 2, 433594) token of the necessity of ‘bread labour’ and organized non violence as against organized violence on which the society of today seems to be based.
('96', 240, 1, 3, 433741) 3. He must dwell in a cottage accessible to all, though easily shielded from gaze, if he is to do efficient work.
('96', 240, 1, 4, 433855) The British Governor naturally represented British might.
('96', 240, 1, 5, 433913) For him and his was erected a fortified residence—a palace to be occupied by him and his numerous vassals who sustained his Empire.
('96', 240, 1, 6, 434045) The Indian prototype may keep somewhat pretentious buildings for receiving princes and ambassadors of the world.
('96', 240, 1, 7, 434158) For these, being guests of the Governor, should constitute an education in what “Even Unto This Last”— equality of all—should mean in concrete terms.
('96', 240, 1, 8, 434308) For him no expensive furniture, foreign or indigenous.
('96', 240, 1, 9, 434363) Plain living and high thinking must be his motto, not to adorn his entrance but to be exemplified in daily life.
('96', 240, 1, 10, 434476) 4. For him there can be no untouchability in any form whatsoever, no caste or creed or colour distinction.
('96', 240, 1, 11, 434583) He must represent the best of all religions and all things Eastern or Western.
('96', 240, 1, 12, 434662) Being a citizen of India, he must be a citizen of the world.
('96', 240, 1, 13, 434723) Thus simply, one reads, did the Khalif Omar, with millions of treasures at his feet, live; thus lived Janaka of ancient times; thus lived, as I saw him, the Master of Eton in his residence in the midst of , and surrounded by, the sons of the Lords and Nabobs of the British Isles.
('96', 240, 1, 14, 435004) Will the Governors of India of the famished millions do less?
('96', 240, 1, 15, 435066) 5. He will speak the language of the province of which he is the Governor and Hindustani, the lingua franca of India written in the Nagari or Urdu script.
('96', 240, 1, 16, 435221) This is neither Sanskritized Hindi nor Persianized Urdu.
('96', 240, 1, 17, 435278) Hindustani is emphatically the language which is spoken by the millions north of the Vindhya Range.
('96', 240, 1, 18, 435378) This does not pretend to be an exhaustive list of the virtues that an Indian Governor should represent.
('96', 240, 1, 19, 435482) It is merely illustrative.
('96', 240, 1, 20, 435509) One would expect that the Britishers who have been chosen by Indian representatives as Governors and who have taken the oath of fealty to India and her millions would endeavour as far as possible to live the life an Indian Governor is expected to live.
('96', 240, 1, 21, 435762) They will represent the best that their country has to give to India and the world.
('96', 240, 1, 22, 435846) CALCUTTA, August 17, 1947 Harijan, 24 8 1947
('96', 241, 0, 1, 435891) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 241, 1, 2, 435933) 337. GOD IS GOOD
('96', 241, 2, 3, 435950) Not in the same sense as X is good.
('96', 241, 2, 4, 435986) X is comparatively good.
('96', 241, 2, 5, 436011) He is more good than evil, but God is wholly good.
('96', 241, 2, 6, 436062) There is no evil in Him.
('96', 241, 2, 7, 436087) God made man in His own image.
('96', 241, 2, 8, 436118) Unfortunately for us man has fashioned Him in his own.
('96', 241, 2, 9, 436173) This arrogation has landed man kind in a sea of troubles.
('96', 241, 2, 10, 436231) God is the Supreme Alchemist.
('96', 241, 2, 11, 436261) In His presence all iron and dross turn into pure gold.
('96', 241, 2, 12, 436317) Similarly does all evil turn into good.
('96', 241, 2, 13, 436357) Again God lives but not as we.
('96', 241, 2, 14, 436388) His creatures live but to die.
('96', 241, 2, 15, 436419) But God is life.
('96', 241, 2, 16, 436436) Therefore goodness and all it connotes is not an attribute.
('96', 241, 2, 17, 436496) Goodness is God.
('96', 241, 2, 18, 436513) Goodness conceived as apart from Him is a lifeless thing and exists only whilst it is a paying policy.
('96', 241, 2, 19, 436616) So are all morals.
('96', 241, 2, 20, 436635) If they are to live in us they must be considered and cultivated in their relation to God.
('96', 241, 2, 21, 436726) We try to become good because we want to reach and realize God.
('96', 241, 2, 22, 436790) All the dry ethics of the world turn to dust because apart from God they are lifeless.
('96', 241, 2, 23, 436877) Coming from God, they come with life in them.
('96', 241, 2, 24, 436923) They become part of us and ennoble us.
('96', 241, 2, 25, 436962) Conversely God conceived without Goodness is without life.
('96', 241, 2, 26, 437021) We give him life in our vain imaginings.

('96', 243, 1, 2, 438652) 340. SPEECH AT NARKELDANGA 1
('96', 243, 2, 3, 438681) CALCUTTA, [August 17, 1947] 2
('96', 243, 3, 4, 438711) Gandhiji said that there were indications that all was not well with the Muslims.
('96', 243, 3, 5, 438793) Some Hindus were now beginning to feel that they had the upper hand, and some Muslims were afraid that they would have to play the underdog in the Union today.
('96', 243, 3, 6, 438953) Gandhiji said that this would be shameful indeed.
('96', 243, 3, 7, 439003) If a minority in India, minority on the score of its religious profession, was made to feel small on that account, he could only say that this India was not the India of his dreams.
('96', 243, 3, 8, 439185) In the India for whose fashioning he had worked all his life every man enjoyed equality of status, whatever his religion was.
('96', 243, 3, 9, 439311) The State was bound to be wholly secular.
('96', 243, 3, 10, 439353) He went so far as to say that no denominational educational institution in it should enjoy State patronage.
('96', 243, 4, 11, 439461) All subjects would thus be equal in the eye of the law.
('96', 243, 4, 12, 439517) But every single individual would be free to pursue his own religion without let or hindrance so long as it did not transgress the common law.
('96', 243, 4, 13, 439660) The question of the protection of minorities was not good enough for him; it rested upon the recognition of religious grouping between citizens of the same State.
('96', 243, 4, 14, 439823) What he wished India to do, was to assure liberty of religious profession to every single individual.
('96', 243, 4, 15, 439925) Then only India could be great, for it was perhaps the one nation in the ancient world, which had recognized cultural democracy, whereby it was held that the roads to God were many, but the goal was one, because God was one and the same.
('96', 243, 4, 16, 440163) In fact the roads were as many as there were individuals in the world.
('96', 243, 4, 17, 440234) Harijan, 31 8 1947

('96', 243, 6, 19, 440285) CALCUTTA, August 17, 1947
('96', 243, 7, 20, 440311) Gandhiji said that it was well for Shaheed Saheb to speak sweet things.
('96', 243, 7, 21, 440383) They were justified.
('96', 243, 7, 22, 440404) There was no exaggeration in his speech.
('96', 243, 7, 23, 440445) But he felt bound to draw attention to certain disturbing things.
('96', 243, 7, 24, 440511) They should not be drowned in the pardonable

('96', 244, 2, 10, 441272) He made a worthy suggestion about a joint influential committee going to the East and West of Bengal and consolidate the good work being done in Calcutta.
('96', 244, 2, 11, 441427) He hoped the suggestion would be quickly acted upon.

('96', 244, 2, 13, 441616) He agreed and hoped that there would be a body of Hindu and Muslim workers who would tackle the subject efficiently.
('96', 244, 2, 14, 441733) Both grain and workers were wanted more than money.
('96', 244, 2, 15, 441785) The Mayor of Calcutta had sent him a cheque for Rs.15,000 in aid of relief.
('96', 244, 2, 16, 441861) He was thankful for the cheque.
('96', 244, 2, 17, 441893) He would see to it that it was well employed.
('96', 244, 3, 18, 441939) Gandhiji then turned to Chandranagore from which the news was received that the Administrator’s bungalow was surrounded by those who called themselves satya grahis but were in fact duragrahis, if the statement received by him was true.
('96', 244, 3, 19, 442175) It was suggested that he had approved of the step.
('96', 244, 3, 20, 442226) He must say it was wholly untrue.

('96', 244, 4, 34, 443351) He, however, expected that the crowd would become perfectly orderly, so that the contemplated withdrawal might not be necessary.
('96', 244, 4, 35, 443480) The police and the military today were after all servants of the public and not their masters.
('96', 244, 5, 36, 443575) Lastly, Gandhiji referred to the coming Id celebration.
('96', 244, 5, 37, 443631) For twenty years in South Africa he had participated in the celebration with Muslim friends in masjids.
('96', 244, 5, 38, 443735) Now that a flood of goodwill was sweeping over the city of Calcutta, he expected
('96', 245, 0, 1, 443816) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHTAMA GANDHI
('96', 245, 1, 2, 443858) everyone to take such steps as would render the friendly feeling permanent.
('96', 245, 1, 3, 443934) It was easy to share in a rising tide of emotion; but it was quite another matter to produce constructive workers who would toil from day to day in order to consolidate the feeling.
('96', 245, 1, 4, 444116) Gandhiji would love to see such work in the city, for, he was sure that its effect would then be felt by the rest of the country.
('96', 245, 1, 5, 444246) If they failed to do this, Gandhiji warned them, today’s freedom would prove only a nine day wonder.

('96', 249, 22, 34, 451670) successfully gained independence through peaceful means, were now unable to check
('96', 249, 23, 35, 451752) the tide of civil war through the same means?
('96', 249, 24, 36, 451798) Gandhiji replied that it was indeed a searching question which he must answer.
('96', 249, 25, 37, 451877) He confessed that it had become clear to him that what he had mistaken for satyagraha

('96', 250, 30, 39, 454582) CALCUTTA, [Before August 20, 1947]
('96', 250, 31, 40, 454617) Gandhiji first asked them if any of them had taken part in the riots, to which
