('96', 251, 0, 1, 454804) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 252
('96', 251, 1, 2, 454846) This gave Gandhiji an opportunity of speaking on some of the vital problems
('96', 251, 2, 3, 454922) connected with non violence.
('96', 251, 2, 4, 454951) He said that mankind had all along tried to justify
('96', 251, 3, 5, 455003) violence and war in terms of unavoidable self defence.
('96', 251, 3, 6, 455058) It was a simple rule that the
('96', 251, 4, 7, 455088) violence of the aggressor could only defeated by superior violence of the defender.
('96', 251, 5, 8, 455172) All over the world, men had thus been caught in a mad race for armaments, and no one
('96', 251, 6, 9, 455257) yet knew at what point of time the world would be really safe enough for turning the
('96', 251, 7, 10, 455342) sword into the plough.
('96', 251, 7, 11, 455365) Mankind, he stated, had not yet mastered the true art of self 
('96', 251, 8, 12, 455428) defence.
('96', 251, 9, 13, 455437) But great teachers, who had practised what they preached, had successfully
('96', 251, 10, 14, 455512) shown that true defence lay along the path of non retaliation.
('96', 251, 10, 15, 455575) It might sound
('96', 251, 11, 16, 455590) paradoxical; but this is what he meant.
('96', 251, 11, 17, 455630) Violence always thrived on counter violence.
('96', 251, 12, 18, 455675) The aggressor had always a purpose behind his attack; he wanted something to be
('96', 251, 13, 19, 455755) done, some object to be surrendered by the defender.
('96', 251, 13, 20, 455808) Now, if the defender steeled his
('96', 251, 14, 21, 455841) heart and was determined not to surrender even one inch, and at the same time to resist
('96', 251, 15, 22, 455929) the temptation of matching the violence of the aggressor by violence, the latter could
('96', 251, 16, 23, 456016) be made to realize in a short while that it would not be paying to punish the other
('96', 251, 17, 24, 456100) party and his will could not be imposed in that way.
('96', 251, 17, 25, 456153) This would involve suffering.
('96', 251, 18, 26, 456183) was this unalloyed self suffering which was the truest form of self defence which
('96', 251, 19, 27, 456265) knew no surrender.
('96', 251, 20, 28, 456284) Someone might ask how it could be called self defence if through such non 
('96', 251, 21, 29, 456359) resistance the defender was likely to lose his life.
('96', 251, 21, 30, 456412) Jesus lost his life on the Cross and
('96', 251, 22, 31, 456449) the Roman Pilate won.
('96', 251, 22, 32, 456471) Gandhiji did not agree.
('96', 251, 22, 33, 456495) Jesus had won, as the world’s history
('96', 251, 23, 34, 456533) had abundantly shown.
('96', 251, 23, 35, 456555) What did it matter if the body was dissolved in the process, so
('96', 251, 24, 36, 456619) long as by Christ’s act of non resistance, the forces of good were released in society?
('96', 251, 25, 37, 456707) This art of the self defence by means of which man gained his life by losing it,
('96', 251, 26, 38, 456788) had been mastered and exemplified in the history of individuals.
('96', 251, 26, 39, 456853) The method had not
('96', 251, 27, 40, 456872) been perfected for application by large masses of mankind.
('96', 251, 27, 41, 456931) India’s satyagraha was a
('96', 251, 28, 42, 456956) very imperfect experiment in that direction.
('96', 251, 28, 43, 457001) Hence, during the Hindu Muslim quarrel,
('96', 251, 29, 44, 457041) it proved a failure on the whole.

('96', 259, 1, 2, 468204) 361. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('96', 259, 2, 3, 468236) CALCUTTA, August 21, 1947
('96', 259, 3, 4, 468262) Gandhiji drew attention to the two flags of Pakistan and the Indian Union that were being prominently flown among the audience and hoped that that pleasing sight would be universal in India.
('96', 259, 3, 5, 468453) He was glad too that Shaheed Saheb had suggested the revival of the slogan ‘Hindu Muslim ki Jai’, for it was started during the palmy Khilafat days.
('96', 259, 3, 6, 468602) He recalled the memory of the old days when a Muslim fellow prisoner used to sing Iqbal’s Sare Jahanse Achchha.
('96', 259, 3, 7, 468714) He used to have it sung equally sweetly by the late Saraladevi Chowdharani.
('96', 259, 3, 8, 468790) The third time was this evening when he heard it sung with equal sweetness and force.
('96', 259, 3, 9, 468876) The words of the poem were as sweet as the tune.
('96', 259, 3, 10, 468925) And among them what could be sweeter than that religion never taught mutual hatred?
('96', 259, 3, 11, 469009) He hoped and prayed that the beginning thus auspiciously made would last for ever and that they would never resort to the sword for the solution of their difficulties.
('96', 259, 3, 12, 469177) If that was to be so, they would see that no untoward incidents were allowed to happen and flimsy things were not exaggerated so as to make them look like a communal disturbance as had come to his notice even that very day.
('96', 259, 3, 13, 469401) He pleaded, too, that a strong rehabilitation committee might collect enough funds to give aid where it was required.
('96', 259, 4, 14, 469519) Absolute impartiality was needed to bring all the evacuees back to their places.
('96', 259, 4, 15, 469600) There was a complaint that certain Muslims, who used to supply carts for transfer of goods from place to place, were displaced during the direct action days.
('96', 259, 4, 16, 469758) They had not found any other occupation.
('96', 259, 4, 17, 469799) He was clear that if the state ment was true, they should be reinstated.
('96', 259, 4, 18, 469872) What was then to be done with the substitutes who were imported from other provinces?
('96', 259, 4, 19, 469958) It was a ticklish question.
('96', 259, 4, 20, 469986) But it was not beyond the wit of merchants.
('96', 259, 4, 21, 470030) Where there was a will, there was a way.
('96', 259, 4, 22, 470071) In scrupulous attention to such matters lay the foundation for permanent unity.
('96', 259, 4, 23, 470151) There was, too, the question of landlords taking undue advantage of the evacuees who were eager to return.
('96', 259, 4, 24, 470258) They must not expect payment for the days that the bustees were unoccupied or think of charging higher rents.
('96', 259, 4, 25, 470368) He added that if they were quite honest in all their dealings both the communities were true to one another, he was sure that the union of hearts would act unfailingly on the Punjab and help the good work that was being done by the ministers of the two Dominions.
('96', 259, 5, 26, 470632) He then came to the Award of the Umpire in the Boundary Commission.
('96', 259, 6, 27, 470700) 1 Held in the Park Circus Maidan, a predominantly Muslim locality, the meeting began with Iqbal’s song Sare Jahanse Achchha Hindostan Hamara.
('96', 260, 0, 1, 470842) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 261
('96', 260, 1, 2, 470888) Umpire was chosen by all the parties to the dispute.
('96', 260, 1, 3, 470941) It would be unjust and unworthy to impute motives to the Umpire.
('96', 260, 1, 4, 471006) He was specially invited by the parties to the thankless task.
('96', 260, 1, 5, 471069) The parties and the public they represented, were loyally to abide by the Award.
('96', 260, 1, 6, 471150) No Award that he knew—and he had to do with many arbitrations— completely satisfied the parties.
('96', 260, 1, 7, 471247) But having made the choice they were bound to carry out the terms of the Award.
('96', 260, 1, 8, 471327) No doubt the best way was for the parties to adjust differences themeselves.
('96', 260, 1, 9, 471404) This royal road was open to them any time as Khwaja Saheb Nazimuddin and Dr. Ghosh, the two Premiers, had wisely pointed out.
('96', 260, 2, 10, 471530) He knew that the Muslims of Murshidabad and Malda were as gravely disappointed as the Hindus in Khulna or Gopalganj and the Buddhists in the Chittagong Hill tracts.
('96', 260, 2, 11, 471695) The latter had gone to East Bengal.
('96', 260, 2, 12, 471731) He would say to all these parties that it was not only foolish but unbecoming to quarrel over the Award.
('96', 260, 2, 13, 471836) It should not matter that on the 15th, the day was celebrated according to the national division.
('96', 260, 2, 14, 471934) If he had been consulted he would have advised non celebration because of the state of uncertainty.
('96', 260, 2, 15, 472034) But having by mistake flown in the respective places the wrong flag, there should be no hesitation whatsoever in replacing the wrong flag by the right one.
('96', 260, 2, 16, 472190) But as he had already said, there was no flag wrong in their Dominion for the simple reason that there was no quarrel left between the parties.
('96', 260, 2, 17, 472334) Both the Dominions had sincerely professed mutual friendship and mutual regard.
('96', 260, 2, 18, 472414) Therefore, he would advise the parties to fly both the flags of both the Dominions or be equally respectful whichever flag was flown for the time being.
('96', 260, 3, 19, 472567) He could not understand the misgivings of the Muslims in that Murshidabad and Malda went to West Bengal, nor could he understand the misgivings of the Hindus in Khulna and Gopalganj and of the Buddhists in the Chittagong Hill tracts.
('96', 260, 3, 20, 472801) For, in view of the friendship professed by all the parties, there was not the slightest occasion for entertaining any fear.
('96', 260, 3, 21, 472926) Surely, there would be no compulsion used against the minorities in either of Bengal.
('96', 260, 3, 22, 473012) The minorities would enjoy equal rights with the majorities.
('96', 260, 3, 23, 473073) Harijan, 31 8 1947
('96', 260, 4, 24, 473092) 362. HOW TO SAVE THE COW?
('96', 260, 5, 25, 473118) There is serious ignorance about the place of the cow in Hinduism and in the economy of Indian life.
('96', 260, 5, 26, 473219) At the same time that India has become independent of foreign rule, by common consent it has been cut into twain so as to induce the untenable belief that one part is popularly described as Hindu India and the other part as Muslim India.
('96', 260, 5, 27, 473457) Like all superstitions, this of Hindu and Muslim India will die hard.
('96', 260, 5, 28, 473527) The fact is that the Indian Union and Pakistan belong
('96', 261, 0, 1, 473581) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 262
('96', 261, 1, 2, 473623) equally to all who call themselves and are, sons of the soil, irrespective of their creed or colour.
('96', 261, 1, 3, 473724) Nevertheless, a large number of local Hindus have begun to believe in the superstition that the Union belongs to the Hindus and the that, therefore, they should enforce their belief by law even among non Hindus.
('96', 261, 1, 4, 473936) Hence an emotional wave is sweeping the country, in order to secure legislation prohibiting the slaughter of cows within the Union.
('96', 261, 1, 5, 474068) In this state, which I hold, is based on ignorance, claiming to be a knowing lover and devotee, second to none in India of the cow, I must try in the best manner I can to dispel the ignorance.
('96', 261, 1, 6, 474261) Let us at the outset realize that cow worship in the religious sense is largely confined to Gujarat, Marwar, the United Provinces and Bihar.
('96', 261, 1, 7, 474402) Marwaris and Gujaratis being enterprising merchants, have succeeded in making the greatest noise without at the same time devoting their business talent to the solution of the very difficult question of conserving the cattle wealth of India.
('96', 261, 1, 8, 474644) It is obviously wrong legally to enforce one’s religious practice on those who do not share that religion.
('96', 261, 1, 9, 474751) In so far as the pure economic necessity of cow protection is concerned, it could be easily secured if the question was considered on that ground alone.
('96', 261, 1, 10, 474904) In that event all the dry cattle, the cows who give less milk than their keep and the aged and unfit cattle would be slaughtered without a second thought.
('96', 261, 1, 11, 475059) This soulless economy has no place in India although the inhabitants of this land of paradoxes may be, indeed are, guilty of many soulless acts.
('96', 261, 1, 12, 475204) Then how can the cow be saved without our having to kill her off when she ceases to give the economic quantity of milk or when she becomes otherwise an uneconomic burden?
('96', 261, 1, 13, 475375) The answer to the question can be summed up as follows: 1. By the Hindus performing their duty towards the cow and her progeny.
('96', 261, 1, 14, 475503) If they did so, our cattle would be the pride of India and the world.
('96', 261, 1, 15, 475573) The contrary is the case today.
('96', 261, 1, 16, 475605) 2. By learning the science of cattle breeding.
('96', 261, 1, 17, 475652) Today there is perfect anarchy in this work.
('96', 261, 1, 18, 475697) 3. By replacing the present cruel method of castration by the humane method practised in the West.
('96', 261, 1, 19, 475796) 4. By thorough reform of the pinjarapoles of India which are
('96', 262, 0, 1, 475857) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 263
('96', 262, 1, 2, 475903) today, as a rule, managed ignorantly and without any plan by men who do not know their work.
('96', 262, 1, 3, 475996) 5. When these primary things are done, it will be found that the Muslims will, of their own accord, recognize the necessity, of only for the sake of their Hindu brethren, of not slaughtering cattle for beef or otherwise.
('96', 262, 1, 4, 476217) The reader will observe that behind the foregoing requirements lies one thing and that is ahimsa, otherwise known as universal compassion.
('96', 262, 1, 5, 476356) If that supreme thing is realized, everything else becomes easy.
('96', 262, 1, 6, 476421) Where there is ahimsa, there is infinite patience, inner calm, discrimination, self sacrifice and true knowledge.
('96', 262, 1, 7, 476535) Cow protection is not an easy thing.
('96', 262, 1, 8, 476572) Much money is wasted in its name.
('96', 262, 1, 9, 476606) Nevertheless, in the absence of ahimsa the Hindus have become destroyers instead of saviours of the cow.
('96', 262, 1, 10, 476711) It is even more difficult than the removel of foreign rule from India.
('96', 262, 2, 11, 476782) CALCUTTA, August 22, 1947
('96', 262, 3, 12, 476808) Harijan, 31 8 1947

('96', 264, 6, 13, 479508) 367. DISCUSSION WITH KASTURBA TRUST TRAINEES 1
('96', 264, 7, 14, 479555) CALCUTTA, [August 22, 1947] 2
('96', 264, 8, 15, 479585) One of the teachers had submitted a statement about her experiences with regard to the method of training itself.
('96', 264, 9, 16, 479699) But Gandhiji did not wish to enter into the actual details of the training course; he was sure this had to be adjusted to the conditions and needs of rural Bengal and the details must naturally be worked out by the teachers from their own experience.
('96', 264, 10, 17, 479950) The question which Gandhiji took up for discussion was asked by one of the trainees: In view of the resistance encountered from the rural people and the numerous disappointments which they had to face, how would Gandhiji advise them to proceed, so that success could be ensured?
('96', 264, 11, 18, 480229) Gandhiji began by saying that he was glad that a very fundamental question had been raised.
('96', 264, 11, 19, 480321) He had, however, only one answer for it.
('96', 264, 11, 20, 480362) The education through which India had passed for over a century was essentially designed for a particular purpose.
('96', 264, 11, 21, 480477) In order to feed the interests of capitalism , the entire economic life of India had been changed, the city had become the centre of gravity and not the village; the village had been dethroned from its position of supremacy and virtually been
('96', 264, 12, 22, 480720) 1 Twenty three trainees and three teachers from the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust training camp, Shahib Nagar, had called on Gandhiji.
('96', 264, 12, 23, 480865) 2 From Calcuttano Chamatkar
('96', 265, 0, 1, 480893) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 266
('96', 265, 1, 2, 480935) converted into a slum, kept as far away from city as practicable.
('96', 265, 1, 3, 481001) The educational system had been planned to supply the needs of this lop sided economy.
('96', 265, 1, 4, 481088) If, now, we wanted to create a new India our outlook must be changed altogether.
('96', 265, 1, 5, 481169) Democracy has to be built up inch by inch in economic, social and political life.
('96', 265, 1, 6, 481251) Considering the magnitude of the task, it would naturally require a very stout heart to grapple with the problem.
('96', 265, 2, 7, 481365) To the trainees, his advice was one.
('96', 265, 2, 8, 481402) They must be brave, intelligent and persevering.
('96', 265, 2, 9, 481451) The villagers might not readily respond.
('96', 265, 2, 10, 481492) They might even prove hostile.
('96', 265, 2, 11, 481523) Many interests would have to be disturbed before the ne cessary change could be effected.
('96', 265, 2, 12, 481613) But non violent workers should choose the line of least resistance.
('96', 265, 2, 13, 481681) They should suffer in their own persons before they could aspire to gain the co operation of the inert or hostile villagers.
('96', 265, 2, 14, 481806) Day in and day out, they must persevere at their chosen task, whether it was village sanitation or the imparting of education to a few children, whomperhaps nobody else would care to touch.
('96', 265, 2, 15, 481996) They might not have the resources to supply their own bread.
('96', 265, 2, 16, 482057) But even then, through hunger, they must persist without retirement, without bitterness.
('96', 265, 2, 17, 482146) Then only would their conduct strike the imgination of the villagers; and this element of surprise would open the way to their hearts.
('96', 265, 2, 18, 482281) Once the inert mass had begun to yield, work would make rapid progress.
('96', 265, 3, 19, 482353) Another trainee then said that there were no signs of response from the villagers even after a year of patient work.
('96', 265, 3, 20, 482470) Gandhiji comforted her by saying that one year’s work was not enough.
('96', 265, 3, 21, 482540) We had to sweep aside the accumulated debris of centuries of subjugation.
('96', 265, 3, 22, 482614) Even a lifetime might not prove enough.
('96', 265, 3, 23, 482654) 1 If our education had been otherwise, we might not have perhaps yielded so readily to despondence.
('96', 265, 3, 24, 482754) We had to steel our hearts and look towards the bright future to enable us to get out of the Slough of Despond.
('96', 265, 3, 25, 482866) So long as we persevered, the struggle itself was victory.
('96', 265, 3, 26, 482925) It was only courage of this kind which could lead India to the New Age.

('96', 266, 1, 2, 483235) 368. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('96', 266, 2, 3, 483267) CALCUTTA, August 22, 1947
('96', 266, 3, 4, 483293) Gandhiji drew attention to the fact that while some men in the audience responded and kept time, the women hardly responded.
('96', 266, 3, 5, 483418) He said that those who had some experience knew the power that the Ramdhun, meaning recital of God’s name from the heart, meant.
('96', 266, 3, 6, 483547) He knew the power that lakhs of soldiers marching in step to the tune of their band meant.
('96', 266, 3, 7, 483638) The desolation that military prowess had wrought in the world, he who ran could see.
('96', 266, 3, 8, 483723) Though the War said to have ended, the aftermath was worse than actual warfare.
('96', 266, 3, 9, 483803) Such was the bankruptcy of military power.
('96', 266, 4, 10, 483846) Without the slightest hesitation he was there to contend that the power exerted by the Ramdhun recited by millions of mankind with true beat of time, was different in kind from and infinitely superior to the display of mili tary strength.
('96', 266, 4, 11, 484085) And this recital of God’s name from the heart, would produce lasting peace and happiness in the place of the present desolation they wit nessed.
('96', 266, 4, 12, 484230) That brought him to what was going on in the Punjab.
('96', 266, 4, 13, 484283) If there was lasting peace in Calcutta, it must have its effect on the Punjab.
('96', 266, 4, 14, 484362) But it was not so as yet.
('96', 266, 4, 15, 484388) He felt sorrow and shame to learn that the Hindus were leaving Lahore and the Muslims were leaving Amritsar.
('96', 266, 4, 16, 484497) It was deplorable that the Muslims should distruct the former.
('96', 266, 4, 17, 484560) He hoped that the Muslims and the Hindus and the Sikh leaders would stop the reported exodus.
('96', 266, 5, 18, 484654) Gandhiji referred then to the visit he had from some Muslims from Kharagpur.
('96', 266, 5, 19, 484731) Though now there was comparative quiet there, there was no assurance that it would last.
('96', 266, 5, 20, 484820) They complained that the Hindu officer was partial.
('96', 266, 5, 21, 484872) He hoped this was not so.
('96', 266, 5, 22, 484898) He must warn all the officers and their men in the police force that in their work they were neither Muslims nor Hindus nor Sikhs.
('96', 266, 5, 23, 485029) They were Indians bound by oath to give full protection to the afficted without regard to their religion.
('96', 266, 5, 24, 485135) Thereby they did not cease to be Muslims, Hindus or Sikhs, but became better.
('96', 266, 6, 25, 485213) Religion was a personal matter and if we succeeded in confining it to the personal plane, all would be well in our political life.
('96', 266, 6, 26, 485344) The manifestation of brotherhood which was being witnessed today would prove a passing show if we did not consolidate it by suitable acts in the social and political spheres.
('96', 266, 6, 27, 485519) If officers of the Government as well as members of the public undertook the responsibility and worked wholeheartedly for the creation of a secular State, we could build a new India that would be the glory of the world.

('96', 267, 7, 10, 486321) Gandhiji first referred to the cry of Allah o Akbar to which some Hindus had objected.
('96', 267, 7, 11, 486408) He held that it was probably a cry than which a greater one had not been produced by the world.
('96', 267, 7, 12, 486504) It was a soul stirring religious cry which meant, God only was great.
('96', 267, 7, 13, 486574) There was nobility in the meaning.
('96', 267, 7, 14, 486609) Did it become objection able because it was Arabic?
('96', 267, 7, 15, 486661) He admitted that it had in India a questionable association.
('96', 267, 7, 16, 486722) It often terrified the Hindus because sometimes the Muslims in anger come out of the mosques with that cry on their lips to belabour the Hindus.
('96', 267, 7, 17, 486867) He confessed that the original had no such association.
('96', 267, 7, 18, 486923) So far as he knew, the cry had no such association in other parts of the world.
('96', 267, 7, 19, 487003) If, therefore, there was to be a lasting friendship between the two, the Hindus should have no hesitation in uttering the cry together with their Muslim friends.
('96', 267, 7, 20, 487165) God was known by many names and had many attributes.
('96', 267, 7, 21, 487218) Rama, Rahim, Krishna, Karim, were all names of the one God.
('96', 267, 7, 22, 487278) Sat Shri Akal, was an equally potent cry.
('96', 267, 7, 23, 487320) Should a single Muslim or Hindu hesitate to utter it?
('96', 267, 7, 24, 487374) It meant that God was and nothing else was.
('96', 267, 7, 25, 487418) The Ramdhun had the same virtue.
('96', 267, 8, 26, 487451) He then came to Vande Mataram.

('96', 269, 5, 22, 493041) My views remain as they are.
('96', 269, 5, 23, 493070) In the scheme of reconstruction for Free India, its villages should no longer depend, as they are now doing, on its cities, but cities should exist only for and in the interest of the villages.
('96', 269, 5, 24, 493264) Therefore, the spinning wheel should occupy the proud position of the centre round which all the life giving village industries would revolve.

('96', 271, 1, 10, 496309) It would do you no good to let you accompany me on my tours.
('96', 271, 2, 11, 496370) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G. N. 9280
('96', 271, 3, 12, 496435) 374. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 271, 4, 13, 496465) CALCUTTA, August 24, 1947
('96', 271, 5, 14, 496491) In thanking the Corporation for the address, Gandhiji said he could not help recalling the late Dr. P. C. Ray under whose roof he had lived for one month in 1901. When he was with the late Deshbandhu, he used to see him with a few friends engaged in lively but strictly scientific conversation under the shadow of the Orchelony Monument near which they had met.
('96', 271, 5, 15, 496853) That was their recreation.
('96', 271, 5, 16, 496880) Gandhiji asked Dr. Ray whether they had any drinks or eatables.
('96', 271, 5, 17, 496944) Dr. Ray emphatically said, “No.” Their food and drink consisted of their instructive as distinct from idle conversation.
('96', 271, 6, 18, 497065) Referring to the address, Gandhiji said that this was third time he was receiv ing an address from the the Corporation.
('96', 271, 6, 19, 497185) The first was given to him by the Deshbandhu when he was the Mayor.
('96', 271, 6, 20, 497253) 1 He recalled the fact that the caskets were then auctioned in the interest of the Harijans.
('96', 271, 6, 21, 497346) He hoped that this casket too would be sold in the same interest by the Mayor.
('96', 271, 7, 22, 497425) He would repeat what he had said in answer to the first address that he could not be satisfied till Calcutta had become the premier city in the world for sanitation.
('96', 271, 7, 23, 497591) He included in this the sanitation of the streets in Calcutta which was absent today.
('96', 271, 7, 24, 497677) The citizens should have healthy minds in healthy bodies.
('96', 271, 7, 25, 497735) That they would have no goondas, no vagabonds, no drunkards.
('96', 271, 7, 26, 497796) If the mortality in Calcutta was to be reduced, Calcutta should be flowing with clean milk.
('96', 271, 7, 27, 497888) Today it was a most difficult commodity to procure.
('96', 271, 7, 28, 497940) Then he would expect the corporators, by honest application, to put the friendship between the Hindus and the Muslims on a permanent footing in the manner
('96', 271, 8, 29, 498095) 1Vide “Speech in Reply to Corporation Address, Calcutta”, 6 11 1924.
('96', 272, 0, 1, 498164) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 273
('96', 272, 1, 2, 498210) Shaheed Saheb had pointed out.
('96', 272, 2, 3, 498241) Gandhiji said that he had a message from Khwaja Saheb Nazimud din 1 that he (Gandhiji) should help in procuring at least 500 tons of rice out of the shipment that was coming from Burma.
('96', 272, 2, 4, 498427) The need was so urgent that the ship with the rice should be diverted to Chittagong to deliver the 500 tons.
('96', 272, 2, 5, 498536) He gladly assciated himself with the request and he hoped that Dr. Rajendra Prasad would, if it was at all possible, allow 500 tons of the precious cargo to be delivered at the Chittagong port.
('96', 272, 3, 6, 498730) In this connection he could not help mentioning the complaint that petty officials in charge of flood relief confined the distribution to Muslim sufferers only.
('96', 272, 3, 7, 498891) He hoped the news was not true.
('96', 272, 3, 8, 498923) If unfortunately it was, he had no doubt that the ministers and high rank officials would redress the wrong.
('96', 272, 3, 9, 499032) If the two Dominions were to live creditably and as friends, the communal spirit would be wholly purged.
('96', 272, 3, 10, 499137) It was up to the Hindu and Muslim leaders to see that the seeds of poison that were sown, while they were fighting, would be removed forthwith.
('96', 272, 3, 11, 499281) Then he said he deplored the fact that the Muslims in Government services when the choice was offered to them, preferred Pakistan and the Hindus, the Indian Union.
('96', 272, 3, 12, 499445) The choice was made, he did not doubt, in haste.
('96', 272, 3, 13, 499494) He would be sorry to find that the communal virus had entered the services.
('96', 272, 3, 14, 499570) He advised that the two Premiers should confer with each other and if it was at all honestly possible, the services should be given the opportunity to reconsider their choice.
('96', 272, 3, 15, 499746) It would be a sorry things for India if Hindu officials could not be trusted by Muslims and vice versa.
('96', 272, 3, 16, 499850) Much would depend upon the leaders who influenced the services and the public.
('96', 272, 4, 17, 499929) Lastly, he had heard that Khulna was to celebrate its entry into Pakistan.
('96', 272, 4, 18, 500004) He deplored such celebration after the Award.
('96', 272, 4, 19, 500050) But he was consoled by Shaheed Saheb that celebration would be joint and that the Hindus were associating with it.
('96', 272, 4, 20, 500165) Nevertheless, he could not regard the example with happiness.
('96', 272, 4, 21, 500227) The jubilant parties ought to restrain themselves, as the aggrieved ones should accept the Award with perfect resignation.
('96', 272, 4, 22, 500350) It must be regarded as final except to the extent that the ministers of the two Dominions agreed to vary it for the mutual satisfaction of the parties concerned.
('96', 272, 4, 23, 500512) There was no other worthy or gentlemanly way.
('96', 272, 4, 24, 500558) Harijan, 7 9 1947

('96', 275, 1, 2, 502522) 379. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('96', 275, 2, 3, 502554) CALCUTTA, August 25, 1947 I am sorry that today being my silence day I cannot speak to you.
('96', 275, 2, 4, 502646) I have, therefore, to write out what I wish to say to you.
('96', 275, 2, 5, 502705) I have been speaking every day about the vital duty of the Hindus in Western Bengal, who are the majority community, towards their Muslim brethren This duty they will perform truly, if they are able to forget the past.
('96', 275, 2, 6, 502924) We know how all over the world enemies have become fast friends.
('96', 275, 2, 7, 502989) The example of the Britons and the Boers who fought one anotherstrenuously, becoming friends we all know.
('96', 275, 2, 8, 503095) There is much greater reason why the Hindus and the Muslims should become friends.
('96', 275, 2, 9, 503178) We cannot do that if we are not great enough to shed all malice.
('96', 275, 2, 10, 503243) This evening I wish to devote to Sylhet.
('96', 275, 2, 11, 503284) I have received frantic telegrams from Sylhet about the serious riots that have broken out there.
('96', 275, 2, 12, 503382) The cause is not known.
('96', 275, 2, 13, 503406) I am sorry that I am unable to go just now to Sylhet, nor am I vain enough to think that my presence would immediately abate the mob fury.
('96', 275, 2, 14, 503545) I know, too, that one should not without peremptory cause abandon his present duty, however humble it may be, in favour of one which may appear to be higher.
('96', 275, 2, 15, 503703) To adopt the Salvation Army language, we are all soldiers of God to fight the battle of right against wrong, by means which are strictly non violent and truthful.
('96', 275, 2, 16, 503866) As His soldiers ours is “not to reason why”, ours is “but to do and die”.
('96', 275, 2, 17, 503940) Though, therefore, I am unable to respond to the urgent call of the sufferers of Sylhet, I can appeal, not in vain, to the authorities in East Bengal in general and Sylhet in particular to put forth their best effort on behalf of the sufferers and deal sternly with the recal citrants.
('96', 275, 2, 18, 504226) Now that there is peace between the Hindus and the Muslims, I am sure the authorities do not relish these ugly outbreaks.
('96', 275, 2, 19, 504348) It would be wrong and misleading to underestimate the trouble by calling it the work of goondas.
('96', 275, 2, 20, 504445) The minorities must be made to realize
('96', 275, 3, 21, 504484) 1 The meeting was held at Howrah Maidan.
('96', 275, 3, 22, 504525) As Gandhiji was observing silence he wrote out his speech to be translated into Bengali by N. K. Bose, who however was delayed due to rain and reached the meeting an hour late.
('96', 275, 3, 23, 504702) By then it was time for Gandhiji to break his silence.
('96', 275, 3, 24, 504757) The first two paragraphs of the speech were written.
('96', 275, 3, 25, 504810) The rest is a report of what Gandhiji spoke.
('96', 276, 0, 1, 504855) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 277
('96', 276, 1, 2, 504901) that they are as much valued citizens of the State they live in, as the majority.
('96', 276, 1, 3, 504983) Let the Premiers of the two divisions of Bengal meet often enough and jointly devise means to preserve peace in the two States and to find enough healthy food and clothing for the inhabitants and enough work for the masses in East and West Bengal.
('96', 276, 1, 4, 505231) When the masses, Hindu and Muslim, see their chiefs acting together and working together honestly, courageously and without intermission, the masses living in the two States will take the cue from the leaders and act accordingly.
('96', 276, 1, 5, 505461) To the sufferers I would advise bravely to face the future and never to give way to panic.
('96', 276, 1, 6, 505552) Such disturbances do happen in the lifetime of a people.
('96', 276, 1, 7, 505609) Manliness demands there should be no weakness shown in facing them.
('96', 276, 1, 8, 505677) Weakness aggravates the mischief, courage abates it.
('96', 276, 2, 9, 505730) Gandhiji first apologized to the vast audience for having to stand or sit on the wet and muddy ground.
('96', 276, 2, 10, 505833) He then referred to the insult that was done to Shaheed Saheb at a meeting held in honour of Major General Shah Nawaz in Howrah.
('96', 276, 2, 11, 505962) The General had gently rebuked the men who were guilty of discourtesy.
('96', 276, 3, 12, 506033) Gandhiji said that the past must be forgotton and whilst they were both acting together for a common cause without mental reservations, the insult done to one was done to the other also.
('96', 276, 3, 13, 506220) And as they together tried to represent Hindu Muslim unity, the insult done to a Hindu or a Muslim, was an insullt done to the two partners.
('96', 276, 4, 14, 506361) He then referred to the visit of Punjabi friends who pressed him to visit the Punjab as early as passible.
('96', 276, 4, 15, 506468) He assured them that he was in constant correspondence with Panditji.
('96', 276, 4, 16, 506538) After all, the Punjab was as much his as any other part of India, for he claimed to be the servant of the whole of India.
('96', 276, 4, 17, 506660) Moreover, he had passed six months in that Province during the Martial Law days.
('96', 276, 4, 18, 506741) He would hasten to the Punjab as early as necessary.
('96', 276, 4, 19, 506794) Indeed, he was wanted in Sylhet, Malda, Murshidabad and other places.
('96', 276, 4, 20, 506864) It was not given to any one man to cover all calls upon his time nor was it healthy to depend upon man’s assistance in times of trouble.
('96', 276, 4, 21, 507001) It was manly and dignified to rely upon God for the dissolution of all troubles.
('96', 276, 4, 22, 507082) He was the only infallible Help, Guide and Friend.
('96', 276, 5, 23, 507133) He then pointed out that rehabilitation was not going on smoothly.
('96', 276, 5, 24, 507200) The landlords seemed also to be in the way.
('96', 276, 5, 25, 507244) They were in duty bound to invite and receive evacuees with open arms.
('96', 276, 5, 26, 507315) He expected them not to charge or expect rents for months or days enforced absence.
('96', 276, 6, 27, 507399) The last thing he referred to was a letter from a Muslim who described himself as a sufi.
('96', 276, 6, 28, 507489) He had sent this communication through Shaheed Saheb.
('96', 276, 7, 29, 507543) The purport was that in his opinion there was nothing common between Hinduism and Islam and that the two could not be as if they were one.
('96', 276, 7, 30, 507682) For, he argued that the Hindus did not believe in the one and only God but held cows and goats as superior to man and believed in high and low, whereas Islam was a brotherhood in
('96', 277, 0, 1, 507861) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 278
('96', 277, 1, 2, 507903) which there was no hierarchy and which believed in one God as Allah.
('96', 277, 1, 3, 507972) In this there was a carica ture of Hinduism.
('96', 277, 1, 4, 508017) There was no Hindu who put animals, the cow and the goat, before man.
('96', 277, 1, 5, 508087) But he submitted that if anyone like him believed himself to be the lowest in God’s creation, there was nothing wrong.
('96', 277, 1, 6, 508206) It was a sign of true humility.
('96', 277, 1, 7, 508238) He held that every Hindu believed in the one and only God.
('96', 277, 1, 8, 508297) He admitted that excrescences had grown round Hinduism and that its votaries had not always been true to Hinduism undefiled.
('96', 277, 1, 9, 508422) It was, therefore, up to an impartial man to understand Hinduism as its votaries like him understood it, just as it was the duty of an impartial Hindu to understand Islam as a good Muslim understood it.
('96', 277, 1, 10, 508625) That, he held, was the safest rule of interpretation for any faith.
('96', 277, 1, 11, 508693) Then it would be found that all great religions sprang from the same source and the fundamentals were common to them all.
('96', 277, 1, 12, 508815) Harijan, 7 9 1947

('96', 281, 5, 15, 515764) There was a huge crowd at the meeting and the audience was talking among themselves, creating a noise which, Gandhiji said, disabled him from speaking as he wanted to.
('96', 281, 5, 16, 515932) As, however, a large part of the audience was patient, he said he would say a few words.
('96', 281, 5, 17, 516021) He referred first to the fact that rehabilitation was not proceeding as rapidly as could be wished.
('96', 281, 5, 18, 516121) If the process was not completed in time and the evacuees did not return to their places, the peace, in spite of the very large meetings every day, would prove transitory.
('96', 281, 5, 19, 516293) He drew pointed attention to the fact that the Lake Area was inhabited by rich men.
('96', 281, 5, 20, 516377) If they made up their minds to do their duty, it was possible for them to make their contribution to the rehabilitation scheme.
('96', 281, 5, 21, 516505) If the police but did their duty without fear or favour , he said, half the work would be done.
('96', 281, 5, 22, 516601) He next referred to the visit he had from Anglo Indian sisters and brothers.
('96', 281, 5, 23, 516678) While he was not able to address them at a meeting, he would gladly mention them at one of his prayer meetings.
('96', 281, 5, 24, 516790) During the foreign regime, they were a favoured community.
('96', 281, 5, 25, 516849) He could not hold out any hope that the favoured treatment would be continued during independence.
('96', 281, 5, 26, 516948) But they are entitled to the full justice that was the right of every citizen.
('96', 281, 5, 27, 517027) The Anglo Indians were as much citizens as any other group in India.
('96', 281, 5, 28, 517096) It was the duty of both the Hindus and the Muslims to regard them as fully their equals and as brothers and sisters.
('96', 281, 5, 29, 517213) He then referred to the provincial spirit that seemed to be infecting the pro vinces.

('96', 284, 1, 2, 520938) 390. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('96', 284, 2, 3, 520970) CALCUTTA, August 27, 1947
('96', 284, 3, 4, 520996) Gandhiji said that the present was his second visit to Motiaburz.
('96', 284, 3, 5, 521062) The first was when Maulana Saheb Abul Kalam Azad and he visited them years ago because there was a fight between Hindus and Muslim workmen.
('96', 284, 3, 6, 521202) Fortunately when they reached the scene of trouble, it was almost over but they got undeserved credit.
('96', 284, 3, 7, 521305) The present was a happy occasion.
('96', 284, 3, 8, 521339) The Hindus and the Muslims had adjusted their differences and had become friends.
('96', 284, 3, 9, 521421) He hoped that this was a lasting friendship.
('96', 284, 3, 10, 521466) He wanted to say a few words to the workmen in the working men’s locality.
('96', 284, 3, 11, 521541) He hoped that there was no distinction between the Hindus and the Muslims in labour.
('96', 284, 3, 12, 521626) They were all labourers.
('96', 284, 3, 13, 521651) If the communal canker entered the labour ranks, both would weaken labour and therefore, themselves and the country.
('96', 284, 3, 14, 521768) Labour was a great leveller of all distinctions.
('96', 284, 3, 15, 521817) If they realized that truth, he would like them to go a step further.
('96', 284, 3, 16, 521887) Labour, because it chose to remain unintelligent, either became subservient or insolently believed in damaging capitalists’s goods and machinary or even in killing capitalists.
('96', 284, 3, 17, 522064) He was a lobourer by conviction and a Bhangi.
('96', 284, 3, 18, 522110) As such his interests were bound with those of labour and he wished to tell them that violence would never save them.
('96', 284, 3, 19, 522228) They would be killing the goose that laid golden eggs.
('96', 284, 3, 20, 522283) What he had been saying for years was that labour was far superior to capital.
('96', 284, 3, 21, 522362) Without labour gold, silver and copper were a useless burden.
('96', 284, 3, 22, 522424) It was labour which extracted precious ore from the bowels of the earth.
('96', 284, 3, 23, 522497) He could quite conceive of labour existing without metal.
('96', 284, 3, 24, 522555) Labour was priceless, not gold.
('96', 284, 3, 25, 522587) He wanted marriage between capital and labour.
('96', 284, 3, 26, 522634) They could work wonders in co operation.
('96', 284, 3, 27, 522675) But that could happen only when labour was intelligent enough to co operate with itself and then offer co operation with capital on terms of honourable equality.
('96', 284, 3, 28, 522837) Capital controlled labour because it knew the art of combination.
('96', 284, 3, 29, 522903) Drops in separation could only fade away; drops in co operation made the ocean which carried on its broad bosom ocean greyhounds.
('96', 284, 3, 30, 523033) Similarly, if all the labourers in any part of the world combined together, they could not be tempted by higher wages or helplessly allow themselves to be attracted for a pittance.
('96', 284, 3, 31, 523214) A true and non violent combination of labour would act like a magnet attracting to it all the needed capital.
('96', 284, 3, 32, 523324) Capitalists would then exist only as trustees.
('96', 284, 3, 33, 523371) When that happy day dawned, there would be no difference between capital and labour.
('96', 284, 3, 34, 523456) The labour will have ample food, good and sanitary dwellings, all the necessary education for their children, ample leisure for self education and proper medical assistance.
('96', 284, 4, 35, 523630) Then he came to the nationalist Muslims who had sent him the following
('96', 284, 5, 36, 523701) 1 Held on the grounds of Clive Jute Mills

('96', 285, 2, 2, 523785) You have expressed the opinion that the nationalist Muslims should join the League.
('96', 285, 2, 3, 523869) Then does it imply that the Congress has now become a communal organization.
('96', 285, 3, 4, 523946) Gandhiji said that he was not guilty of asking them to discard nationalism or of expecting the Congress to be another Hindu Sabha.
('96', 285, 3, 5, 524077) He hoped that the Congress would never commit suicide by being communal organization.
('96', 285, 3, 6, 524163) When the Congress ceased to represent all who were proud to call themselves Indians, whether prince or pauper, Hindus, Muslims or any other, it will have destroyed itself.
('96', 285, 3, 7, 524335) Therefore, he could not advise a Muslim Congressman to join the League if the condition of joining the League was to discard or suppress his Congress membership.
('96', 285, 3, 8, 524497) He would vote for those resolutions of the League which were in the nation’s interest and against those which were contrary to the nation’s interest.
('96', 285, 3, 9, 524647) He had in mind several Muslims of staunch faith who were neither in the Congress nor in the League.
('96', 285, 3, 10, 524747) He advised the nationalist Muslim friends to join the League if they wanted to affect the Muslim masses.
('96', 285, 3, 11, 524852) Real nationalists needed no encouragement from him or anyone else.
('96', 285, 3, 12, 524919) Nationalism, like virtue, was its own reward.
('96', 285, 3, 13, 524965) His one warning was that they should never think of power or bettering their worldly prospects by joining the one or the other organization.
('96', 285, 3, 14, 525106) A nationalist would ever think of service, never of power or riches.
('96', 285, 3, 15, 525175) There could be one President of the Congress or the League.
('96', 285, 3, 16, 525235) Presidentship came by merit and strength of service.
('96', 285, 3, 17, 525288) The League had become what it was, not by his or Congress cajolery.
('96', 285, 3, 18, 525356) The Qaid e Azam was an able President, whom neither riches nor titles could buy.
('96', 285, 3, 19, 525437) He was a front rank barrister and rich man.
('96', 285, 3, 20, 525481) Being the son of a merchant he knew how to multiply his earnings as a lawyer by wise investments.
('96', 285, 3, 21, 525579) This acknowledgement did not mean that Gandhiji liked all his ways or that the latter had led the Muslims in the right way.
('96', 285, 3, 22, 525703) He had his differences with the Qaid e Azam and the League.
('96', 285, 3, 23, 525763) But he could not withhold merit where it was due.
('96', 285, 3, 24, 525813) It was, he hoped, clear to the nationalist Muslims under what conditions he advised them to join the League.
('96', 285, 4, 25, 525922) Gandhiji then came to the question addressed to him by some members of the Azad Hind Fauj.

('96', 287, 1, 4, 527786) He would be eligible for the certificate only when he had learnt the second script, too.
('96', 287, 1, 5, 527875) It is not correct to say that because I have not used the phrase “whereas” in the draft resolution, the language of the draft is not legal.
('96', 287, 1, 6, 528015) The word is used in court documents.

('96', 287, 1, 11, 528409) Hence my emphaitc advice in the present circumstances is to be cling all the more resolutely to the policy to which we have adhered till now.
('96', 287, 1, 12, 528551) To me, ever since I understood the problem, Hindi and Hindustani have been two forms of the same language.
('96', 287, 1, 13, 528658) And there will be a difference between Urdu and Hindustani as there is between Hindi and Hindustani.
('96', 287, 1, 14, 528759) I would, thus, describe Hindustanias a language midway between Urdu and Hindi, one which would bring about a confluence of the two.
('96', 287, 1, 15, 528891) Accordingly, if in course of time only one script survives in use, Hindustani will have become and will remain one from of Hindi and Urdu.
('96', 287, 1, 16, 529030) We need not object if the Governments do not make knowledge of the two scripts obligatory but only encourage it.
('96', 287, 1, 17, 529143) If we keep our house in order and clean it regularly, we shall have done our duty.
('96', 287, 1, 18, 529226) It will be tantamount to harassing the Urdu speaking people to make the Nagari script compulsory for all.
('96', 287, 1, 19, 529332) I would, therefore, earnestly appeal to all the members of the Conference that they should not only acquire a good knowledge of both the scripts, but also boldly advocate such a policy in public.
('96', 287, 1, 20, 529528) Only then shall we be able to influence the various State Governments.

('96', 289, 8, 17, 531546) CALCUTTA, August 28, 1947
('96', 289, 9, 18, 531572) Gandhiji addressed after prayer the students of Calcutta.
('96', 289, 9, 19, 531630) He said that he had done teaching in his own way from his early youth and probably the very first meeting he addressed after his return to India in 1915 was that of students.
('96', 289, 9, 20, 531805) Since then he had addressed numerous student meetings throughout his many wanderings in India.
('96', 289, 9, 21, 531900) He was not new to them nor were they new to him.
('96', 289, 9, 22, 531949) But of late he had ceased to address meetings as he used to do before.
('96', 289, 9, 23, 532020) He was, therefore, glad that he was able to address the students.
('96', 289, 9, 24, 532086) Their Vice Chancellor was good enough to see him about the evening’s proceedings.
('96', 289, 9, 25, 532168) He was nervous about the students’ behaviour towards Shaheed Saheb.
('96', 289, 9, 26, 532236) He said that he would have only the prayer and his usual after prayer speech.
('96', 289, 9, 27, 532314) It should not have been so.
('96', 289, 9, 28, 532342) Everywhere there appeared to be anarchy in the student world.
('96', 289, 9, 29, 532404) They did not tender obedience to their teachers and their Vice Chancellor.
('96', 289, 9, 30, 532479) On the contrary.
('96', 289, 9, 31, 532496) they expected obedience from their teachers.
('96', 289, 9, 32, 532541) It was a painful exhibition on the part of those who were to be the future leaders of the nation.
('96', 289, 9, 33, 532639) They gave an exhibition of unruliness that evening.
('96', 289, 9, 34, 532691) He was forced with placards in the foreign tongue depicting his comrade Shaheed Saheb in unbecoming language.
('96', 289, 10, 35, 532801) 1 Son of Amrita Lal Chattarjee 2 Held in the University Science College
('96', 290, 0, 1, 532873) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 291
('96', 290, 1, 2, 532919) suggested to them that inasmuch as they had insulted Shaheed Saheb, they had insulted the speaker.
('96', 290, 1, 3, 533018) Shaheed Saheb could not be insulted by the language used against him.
('96', 290, 1, 4, 533088) But the speaker could not take up that attitude.
('96', 290, 1, 5, 533137) The students should be, above all, humble and correct.
('96', 290, 1, 6, 533192) They had an object lesson in their Vice Chancellor.
('96', 290, 1, 7, 533244) The Chief Minister, Shaheed Saheb and he sat on the platform provided for them but the Vice Chancellor sat among the rest of the visitors.
('96', 290, 1, 8, 533383) His humility reminded him of Krishna who, when Raja Yudhishthira performed his yajna, chose the menial work of washing the feet of the guests.
('96', 290, 1, 9, 533526) Thereby he showed his innate nobility.
('96', 290, 1, 10, 533565) The greatest to remain great had to be the lowliest by choice.
('96', 290, 1, 11, 533628) If he could speak from his knowledge of Hindu belief, the life of a student was to correspond to the life of a sannyasi up to the time his studies ended.
('96', 290, 1, 12, 533782) He was to be under the strictest discipline.
('96', 290, 1, 13, 533827) He could not marry nor indulge in dissipation.
('96', 290, 1, 14, 533874) He could not indulge in drinks and the like.
('96', 290, 1, 15, 533919) His behaviour was to be a pattern of exemplary self restraint.
('96', 290, 1, 16, 533982) Had they lived at all up to the pattern, they would not have done what they did at the prayer meeting.

('96', 290, 3, 18, 534163) to his opinion about them.
('96', 290, 3, 19, 534190) He said that he had come in close contact with some of the

('96', 290, 4, 21, 534271) In referring to the Fauj he felt constrained to refer to Nataji who,

('96', 290, 5, 23, 534416) He had the
('96', 290, 6, 24, 534427) pleasure of coming in touch with Subhas Babu when the latter had just returned from
('96', 290, 7, 25, 534511) England with the determination to sacrifice a lucrative career that was open to him.
('96', 290, 8, 26, 534596) perferred selfless service to selfish ambition and placed himself under the
('96', 290, 9, 27, 534672) Deshbandhu.
('96', 290, 9, 28, 534684) Therefore he was able to come in close touch with the speaker.
('96', 290, 10, 29, 534747) Subhas Babu became a non violent non co operator, he never saw eye to eye with the
('96', 290, 11, 30, 534830) speaker in his unadulterated non violence.
('96', 290, 11, 31, 534873) His was a life full of perilous adventure and
('96', 290, 12, 32, 534919) romance.
('96', 290, 12, 33, 534928) His daring was unequalled.
('96', 290, 12, 34, 534955) He scraped together an army composed of Indians
('96', 290, 13, 35, 535003) drawn from all provinces, belonging to all religions and by his glorious example he
('96', 290, 14, 36, 535087) had infused into them the spirit of willing discipline and obedience.
('96', 290, 14, 37, 535157) It was not a small
('96', 290, 15, 38, 535176) thing for his handful of army which his genius had scraped together to offer battle to
('96', 290, 16, 39, 535263) the mightiest empire of modern times.
('96', 290, 16, 40, 535301) Gandhiji was told by the officers of the Azad
('96', 290, 17, 41, 535347) Hind Fauj that Subhas Babu had advised the members of the Army to carry out what he
('96', 290, 18, 42, 535431) (Gandhiji) might suggest; for the struggle in India was of his (Gandhiji’s) conception
('96', 290, 19, 43, 535518) as the struggle outside India was of Netaji’s.

('96', 290, 20, 45, 535607) the members of the Azad Hind Fauj were not to expect to be absorbed in the current
('96', 290, 21, 46, 535690) military ranks nor to be a separate unit of the army in any of the two parts of India.

('96', 297, 7, 19, 545021) 411. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('96', 297, 8, 20, 545053) CALCUTTA, August 29, 1947
('96', 297, 9, 21, 545079) Gandhiji, therefore, commenced his speech by congratulating Shaheed Saheb and the other Muslims on standing.
('96', 297, 9, 22, 545188) He purposely kept seated because he had learnt that their culture did not require standing as a mark of respect when any national song or bhajan was sung.
('96', 297, 9, 23, 545343) It was an unnecessary importation from the West.
('96', 297, 9, 24, 545392) A respectful posture on such occasions was the correct attitude.
('96', 297, 9, 25, 545457) After all, it was the mental attitude that mattered, not the superficial appearance.
('96', 297, 9, 26, 545542) He then suggested that there should be one universal notation for Vande Mataram, if it was to stir millions; it must be sung by millions in one tune and one mode.
('96', 297, 9, 27, 545705) After all, national songs could only be two or three.
('96', 297, 9, 28, 545759) But they should all have their common notation.
('96', 297, 9, 29, 545807) It was up to the Santiniketan authorities or some such authoritative society to produce an acceptable notation.
('96', 297, 10, 30, 545919) Gandhiji then referred to the Christians.
('96', 297, 10, 31, 545961) He had had the pleasure of receiving them the day before.
('96', 297, 10, 32, 546019) They said that the major communities had taken care of themselves but what was to happen to the Christian Indians?
('96', 297, 10, 33, 546134) Were they to have no
('96', 297, 11, 34, 546155) 1 The source has: “The standard time today began at 2.30 a.m.” 2 The meeting was held on Tolly Gunge Police Ground.
('96', 297, 11, 35, 546271) When Vande Mataram was sung everyone including Suhrawardy and other Muslims had stood up.
('96', 298, 0, 1, 546361) VOL. 96: 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 299
('96', 298, 1, 2, 546406) seats in the Governments or the legislatures?
('96', 298, 1, 3, 546452) He told the friends that the poisonous favouritism of the foreign rule was dead and gone.
('96', 298, 1, 4, 546542) Merit should now be the sole test.
('96', 298, 1, 5, 546577) In a well ordered society there should be no minority.
('96', 298, 1, 6, 546632) Why should they not feel that they were of the forty crores, but not a mere handful in the forty crores?
('96', 298, 1, 7, 546737) Whatever their religion, all born in India and proud of their birth were equal in the eye of the law.
('96', 298, 1, 8, 546839) On the strength of merit, i.e., intellectual capacity, self sacrifice, courage and incorruptibility, a Christian could be the Chief Minister without exhibiting greater merit than a Hindu or Muslim.
('96', 298, 1, 9, 547037) Religion was a purely personal matter.
('96', 298, 1, 10, 547076) He expected that what was true of the Union was equally true of Pakistan.
('96', 298, 1, 11, 547150) He asked his Christian brethren also not to take their Christianity as it was interpreted in the West.
('96', 298, 1, 12, 547253) They knew that there they fought with one another as never before.
('96', 298, 1, 13, 547320) After all Jesus was an Asiatic depicted as wearing the Arabian flowing robe.
('96', 298, 1, 14, 547397) He was the essence of meekness.
('96', 298, 1, 15, 547429) Gandhiji hoped that the Christians of India would express in their lives, Jesus, the crucified of the Bible, and not as interpreted in the West with its blood stained fingers.
('96', 298, 1, 16, 547605) He had no desire to criticize the West.
('96', 298, 1, 17, 547645) He knew and valued the many virtues of the West.
('96', 298, 1, 18, 547694) But he was bound to point out that Jesus of Asia was misrepresented in the West except in individuals.
('96', 298, 2, 19, 547797) Then he answered the question whether the minorities would have recognition as religious minorities had; thus, whether Bengalis of Bihar, though a minority, would have recognition.
('96', 298, 2, 20, 547978) This was a ticklish question.
('96', 298, 2, 21, 548008) In his opinion an Indian was a citizen of India enjoying equal rights in every part of India.
('96', 298, 2, 22, 548102) Therefore, a Bengali had every right in Bihar as a Bihari.
('96', 298, 2, 23, 548161) But he wished to emphasize that a Bengali must merge in the Bihari.
('96', 298, 2, 24, 548229) He must never be guilty of exploiting Biharis or feeling a stranger or behaving as a stranger in Bihar.
('96', 298, 2, 25, 548333) If the speaker brought his Gujarat manners to Bengal and imposed himself on the province, he would expect the Bengalis to expel him.
('96', 298, 2, 26, 548466) He could not then claim the rights of an Indian as against Bengalis.
('96', 298, 2, 27, 548535) All rights flowed from duties previously and duly performed.
('96', 298, 2, 28, 548596) One thing he must stress, that in both the Dominions of India, the use of force for the assertion of rights must be eschewed altogether if they were to make any progress.
('96', 298, 2, 29, 548767) Thus, neither the Bengalis nor the Biharis could assert themselves at the point of the sword, nor could the Boundary Commission Award similarly be changed.
('96', 298, 2, 30, 548923) It was the first lesson to be learnt in a democratic, independent India.
('96', 298, 2, 31, 548996) Their independence was yet only a fortnight old.
('96', 298, 2, 32, 549045) Liberty never meant the licence to do anything at will.
('96', 298, 2, 33, 549101) Independence meant the voluntary restraint and discipline, voluntary acceptance of the rule of law in the making of which the whole of India had its hand through its elected representatives.
('96', 298, 2, 34, 549292) The only force at the disposal of democracy was that of public opinion.
('96', 298, 2, 35, 549364) Satyagraha, civil disobedience and fasts had nothing in common with the use of force, veiled or open.
('96', 298, 2, 36, 549466) But even these had restricted use in democracy.
('96', 298, 2, 37, 549514) They could not even think of them whilst the Governments were settling down and the communal distemper was still stalking from one province to another.

('96', 306, 7, 11, 565024) 421. QUESTION BOX
('96', 306, 8, 12, 565042) QUESTION: You have often stated while you were in Noakhali that failure of your mission there would be the failure of your own ahimsa and not of ahimsa itself.

('96', 306, 9, 14, 565331) ANSWER: It is a correct statement that has been attributed to me.
('96', 306, 9, 15, 565397) Ahimsa is always infallible.
('96', 306, 9, 16, 565426) When, therefore, it appears to have failed, the failure is due to the inaptitude of the votary.
('96', 306, 9, 17, 565522) I have never felt that my ahimsa has failed in Noakhali, nor can it be said that it has succeeded.
('96', 306, 9, 18, 565621) It is on its trial.
('96', 306, 9, 19, 565641) And when I talk of my ahimsa I do not think of it as limited to myself.
('96', 306, 9, 20, 565713) It must include all my co workers in Noakhali.
('96', 306, 9, 21, 565760) Success or failure would, therefore, be attributable to the aggregate of the activities of my co workers and myself.
('96', 306, 9, 22, 565877) What I have said about Noakhali applies to Calcutta.
('96', 306, 9, 23, 565930) It is too early to state that the application of ahimsa to the communal problem in this great city has succeeded beyond doubt.
('96', 306, 9, 24, 566057) As I have already remarked, it is wrong to contend that the establishment of friendliness between the two communities was a miracle.

('96', 308, 1, 2, 567844) 424. ADDRESS TO MUSLIM MERCHANTS 1
('96', 308, 2, 3, 567879) CALCUTTA, August 31, 1947
('96', 308, 3, 4, 567905) In his speech before the moneyed men Gandhiji said that he want to them as a beggar.
('96', 308, 3, 5, 567990) Somehow or other when he began life after studies he found that he had the gift of begging from the rich and the poor alike.
('96', 308, 3, 6, 568115) He hoped that his appeal would not go in vain.
('96', 308, 3, 7, 568162) There were two ways of rebuilding and rehabilitation—either the Government or the rich men of Calcutta had to find the money.
('96', 308, 3, 8, 568288) He held that if the Government found the funds, it would carry no merit.
('96', 308, 3, 9, 568361) But if the moneyed men took up the duty, it carried double merit.
('96', 308, 3, 10, 568427) They as citizens,would have of their own free will discharged their duty and it would be a substantial proof of real friendship between the communities.
('96', 308, 4, 11, 568580) Mahatma Gandhi in his speech congratulated the organizers of the function which was to cement Hindu Muslim unity.
('96', 308, 4, 12, 568694) He asked them to form their own committees, for raising funds, and making expenditure for rehabilitation work.
('96', 308, 4, 13, 568805) Those who were interested and those who were in a position to pay should sit together and devise the programme.
('96', 308, 4, 14, 568917) They should not merely think of rehabilitating these poor sufferers in the kind of bustees that existed today and which the poor had been forced to choose as their abodes.
('96', 308, 4, 15, 569089) But they should think more as to how these people could live with comfort.
('96', 308, 4, 16, 569164) Those who had money should not think that it was for themselves alone.
('96', 308, 4, 17, 569235) As a matter of fact, they must look upon themselves as trustees and should pay for the cause of suffering humanity.
('96', 308, 4, 18, 569351) They knew that Dr. P. C. Ghosh, their Chief Minister, wanted a crore for rehabilitation work.
('96', 308, 4, 19, 569445) They should apply themselves to that.
('96', 308, 4, 20, 569483) If Hindus and Muslims, rich and poor, could work together, it was bound to have effect in East and West Punjab and the work that they would do here would be the work for the whole country.
('96', 308, 5, 21, 569672) The spectacular meetings were, no doubt, necessary, but they were not all.
('96', 308, 5, 22, 569747) That which led to permanent friendship was contented rehabilitation.
('96', 308, 5, 23, 569816) All parties, all groups, had to do their duty in the direction.
('96', 308, 5, 24, 569880) For the purity of hearts it was necessary for all to forget the past.
('96', 308, 5, 25, 569950) Forgetfulness properly cultivated was a great gift.
('96', 308, 5, 26, 570002) It was a rich gift bestowed upon man by the Maker.
('96', 308, 5, 27, 570053) The rich men would not be able to put their hands into their pockets, if they had not the faculty for forgetting the past.
('96', 308, 5, 28, 570176) He asked the rich men, after Shaheed Saheb and he had withdrawn, to sit together and not to leave the Hotel till they had come to a wise decision.
('96', 308, 6, 29, 570323) Harijan, 21 9 1947, and Amrita Bazar Patrika, 1 9 1947
('96', 308, 7, 30, 570378) 1 The Muslims of the Lower Chitpur Road held a function for Hindu Muslim unity at the Grand Hotel.

('96', 308, 7, 32, 570649) 2 This paragraph is from Amrita Bazar Patrika.

('96', 309, 2, 3, 570768) CALCUTTA, August 31, 1947
('96', 309, 3, 4, 570794) After prayer Gandhiji said that as he had addressed the meeting of the wealthy men, he did not propose to say much to the audience.
('96', 309, 3, 5, 570926) He was glad to be informed by Kamal Babu, their M.L.A., that there was now perfect friendship between the two communities and that the evacuees were ready to return.

('96', 309, 3, 9, 571398) He informed the audience that he proposed to leave for Noakhali on Tuesday.
('96', 309, 3, 10, 571474) If Shaheed Saheb too could accompany him at the same time, he would do so.
('96', 309, 3, 11, 571549) He did not propose to stay in Noakhali for long and hoped to return to Calcutta to finish the work that had begun under happy auspices.
('96', 309, 3, 12, 571685) Meanwhile, he hoped that the work of rehabilitation would be continued with double speed.
('96', 309, 3, 13, 571775) It did not admit of delay if there was to be lasting peace.

('96', 310, 1, 2, 572914) 427. A NOTE
('96', 310, 2, 3, 572926) [August 1947] 1
('96', 310, 3, 4, 572942) I will give you a talisman.
('96', 310, 3, 5, 572970) Whenever you are in doubt, or when the self becomes too much with you, apply the following test.
('96', 310, 3, 6, 573067) Recall the face of the poorest and the weakest man whom you may have seen, and ask yourself if the step you contemplate is going to be of any use to him.
('96', 310, 3, 7, 573221) Will he gain anything by it?
('96', 310, 3, 8, 573250) Will it restore him to a control over his own life and destiny?
('96', 310, 3, 9, 573314) In other words, will it lead to swaraj for the hungry and spiritually starving millions?
('96', 310, 3, 10, 573403) Then you will find your doubts and yourself melting away.
('96', 310, 4, 11, 573461) M. K. GANDHI 2

('96', 314, 4, 9, 580140) 433. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('96', 314, 5, 10, 580168) September 1, 1947 I regret to have to report to you that last night some young men brought to the compound a bandaged man.
('96', 314, 5, 11, 580291) He was reported to have been attacked by some Muslims.
('96', 314, 5, 12, 580346) The Prime Minister 4 had him examined and the report was that he had no marks on his body of stabbing which he was said to have received.
('96', 314, 5, 13, 580484) The seriousness of the injury however is not the chief point.
('96', 314, 5, 14, 580546) What I want to emphasize is that these young men tried to become judges and executioners.
('96', 314, 5, 15, 580636) This was about 10 p.m., Calcutta time.
('96', 314, 5, 16, 580675) They began to shout at the top of their voices.
('96', 314, 5, 17, 580723) My sleep was disturbed but I tried to lie quiet not knowing what was happening.
('96', 314, 5, 18, 580803) I heard the window panes being smashed.
('96', 314, 5, 19, 580843) I had lying on either side of me two very brave girls.
('96', 314, 5, 20, 580898) They would not sleep but, without my knowledge, for my eyes were closed, they went among the small crowd and tried to pacify them.
('96', 314, 5, 21, 581029) Thank God the crowd did
('96', 314, 6, 22, 581053) 1 Some leading members of the Marwari community sought Gandhiji’s advice as to what they should do to quench the fire of communal riots.

('96', 314, 6, 24, 581474) For he added: “Of course, I cannot do today what I have told them to do.
('96', 314, 6, 25, 581547) I will not be permitted to.
('96', 314, 6, 26, 581575) I saw that yesterday.
('96', 314, 6, 27, 581597) Everybody will protect me from harm if I went in the midst of the maddened crowd.
('96', 314, 6, 28, 581679) I may drop down from sheer physical exhaustion—that is nothing.
('96', 314, 6, 29, 581743) It won’t do for a soldier to be exhausted in the midst of battle.” 4 The reference is to the Chief Minister of Bengal, Dr. P. C. Ghosh.

('96', 315, 3, 30, 583499) Happily Shaheed Saheb had gone home to prepare for tomorrow’s proposed departure for Noakhali.
('96', 315, 3, 31, 583594) In view of the above ugly incident which no one could tell where it would lead to I could not think of leaving Calcutta for Noakhali.
('96', 315, 4, 32, 583728) What is the lesson of the incident?
('96', 315, 4, 33, 583764) It is clear to me that if India is to retain her dearly won independence all men and women must completely forget lynch law.

('96', 324, 1, 18, 600607) If after the British had quitted, the collective wisdom and statesmanship of India were still unable to achieve a peaceful solution, I would have invited the Muslim League to take charge of the Government.
('96', 324, 1, 19, 600813) 2 The Congress Ministers would have made way for them if I had asked them to.
('96', 324, 1, 20, 600891) Pandit Nehru and the Sardar had told me that they would carry out my orders if I took over command.
('96', 324, 2, 21, 600991) I shall endeavour to do my best on your lines for the establishment of peace.

('96', 324, 4, 24, 601146) September 2, 1947

('96', 324, 6, 26, 601279) GANDHIJI: Perhaps you are right.

('96', 324, 6, 28, 601382) Any avoidable delay would have meant further loss of innocent lives.

('96', 325, 1, 2, 601594) I do not wish to prolong the argument.

('96', 328, 3, 5, 608287) 448. INTERVIEW TO A BRITISH JOURNALIST 2
('96', 328, 4, 6, 608328) CALCUTTA, [Before September 4, 1947] 3
('96', 328, 5, 7, 608367) An English journalist came to Beliaghata the other day.
('96', 328, 5, 8, 608423) It was a busy day for Gandhiji and he could spare only a few minutes.
('96', 328, 5, 9, 608493) Although Gandhiji’s activities ranged from wide social and political fields to the smallest and intensely personal ones, the journalist asked him, how he was able to maintain a spirit of detachment in such a surprising manner.
('96', 328, 5, 10, 608720) Gandhiji replied that it was not true that he was never off his balance.
('96', 328, 5, 11, 608793) Such occasions were rare, yet the long exercise of self restraint enabled him, through God’s grace, to keep his irritation within very narrow bounds.
('96', 328, 5, 12, 608943) This led the interviewer on to a more fundamental question.
('96', 328, 5, 13, 609003) From a reading of Gandhiji’s writings, the friend had gathered that the root of all of Gandhiji’s activities was the desire for moksha, emancipation.
('96', 328, 5, 14, 609153) But why was not this aspect emphasized sufficiently ?
('96', 328, 5, 15, 609207) Gandhiji replied by taking recourse to a simile.
('96', 328, 5, 16, 609256) He said the desire for moksha was indeed there, but it was not meant for anyone other than the individual himself.
('96', 328, 5, 17, 609371) The world was interested in the fruits, not the root.
('96', 328, 5, 18, 609425) For the tree itself, however, the chief concern should be not the fruit, but the root.
('96', 328, 5, 19, 609512) It was in the depth of one’s own being that the individual had to concentrate.
('96', 328, 5, 20, 609591) He had to nurse it with the water of his labour and suffering.
('96', 328, 5, 21, 609654) The root was his chief concern.
('96', 328, 5, 22, 609686) But society was concerned with the fruit alone.
('96', 328, 5, 23, 609734) It had no other data for judgment than the fruits.
('96', 328, 5, 24, 609785) Was not a tree judged by its fruits?
('96', 328, 5, 25, 609822) It was this practice of trying to limit himself to the root, and then not be concerned about the fruit that had given Gandhiji the apparent detachment which the English friend had noticed.
('96', 328, 5, 26, 610011) But, in his personal opinion, he was yet far from the fullness of its realization.
('96', 328, 5, 27, 610094) He was still a soul yearning to be wholly free, but ever failing to reach the ideal which he knew to be true., Hence, it would be enough if he could take care of the immediate task before him, whether great or small, with all the care and freedom from bias or mental worries which he could bring to bear upon it.
('96', 328, 5, 28, 610407) Harijan, 28 9 1947
('96', 328, 6, 29, 610426) 1 After they had left Gandhiji added: “Let the evil doers desist from evil, not to save my life, but as a result of a true heart change.
('96', 328, 6, 30, 610563) Let all understand that a make believe peace cannot satisfy me.
('96', 328, 6, 31, 610627) I do not want a temporary lull to be followed by a worse carnage.
('96', 328, 6, 32, 610693) If that happens, I shall have to go on an unconditional fast unto death.” 2 This appeared under the title “The Root and the Fruit” with the date line “Calcutta, 4 9 1947”.

('96', 329, 1, 2, 610907) 449. RIGHT OR WRONG 1
('96', 329, 2, 3, 610929) Among my correspondence there is a typical letter in Gujarati from which I give below the following summary : In the Young India of 15th September, 1927 A. D., in your Madras speech 2 reported therein, you have said that that which is opposed to true economics is not religion and that economics which is inconsistent with religion is not true and should, therefore, be denounced.
('96', 329, 2, 4, 611310) I am aware that you have held the view for many years, but it has not commanded universal acceptance.
('96', 329, 2, 5, 611412) Therefore, it seems to me that your devoting your time and energy to the abatement of atrocities being committed in the name of religion is not proper.
('96', 329, 2, 6, 611564) Where is your constructive programme today?
('96', 329, 2, 7, 611608) The National Congress has the reins of Government in the best part of India.
('96', 329, 2, 8, 611685) Complete political independence is in our hands.
('96', 329, 2, 9, 611734) The British power has quitted.
('96', 329, 2, 10, 611765) In such a case, is it not well that you should devote your energy to the prosecution of the constructive programme and through it demonstrate to the country that religion and economics are not two opposites?
('96', 329, 3, 11, 611973) You write nothing against the unmoral economics of India.
('96', 329, 3, 12, 612031) The consequence is that credulous people have begun to believe that you are behind the present economic policy of the Congress Government.
('96', 329, 3, 13, 612170) I have begun to believe that you, who are the creator of constructive programme, are now destroying it.
('96', 329, 3, 14, 612274) So far as I know, there is not a single institution connected with khadi or village industries which is based on true economics and on principles of self sufficiency.
('96', 329, 3, 15, 612441) This writer has written in a moment of excitement.
('96', 329, 3, 16, 612492) Therefore, he has not been able to express the whole truth.
('96', 329, 3, 17, 612552) The main fact is that communal unity is a vital part of my being.
('96', 329, 3, 18, 612618) It was so when khadi and all the village industries were not even conceived by me.
('96', 329, 3, 19, 612701) At the time communal unity possessed me, I was a lad twelve years old, just a beginner in English.
('96', 329, 3, 20, 612800) It was then that I had realized that all Hindus and

('96', 330, 1, 22, 615125) When more capable men are found, I am sure they will give place to their betters.

('96', 332, 1, 2, 618228) 450. LETTER TO KHWAJA NAZIMUDDIN 1
('96', 332, 2, 3, 618263) September 4, 1947 This will be presented to you by Pyarelal.
('96', 332, 2, 4, 618324) You may know that Satis Babu and some inmates of Khadi Pratishthan together with the helpers, whom I brought with me from Delhi, were posted in Noakhali to help the terror struck and demoralized Hindus and, if possible, to prevent them from running away from Noakhali.
('96', 332, 2, 5, 618593) In doing so, I felt that I was serving the Muslims, too, of Noakhali, though they stood in no need of help from me.
('96', 332, 2, 6, 618709) But on reaching there I found taht I could be of some help to them also.
('96', 332, 2, 7, 618782) I had announced that I would do or die in Noakhali in the sense that I would prefer to die there unless through what I could do the two communities should become friends.
('96', 332, 2, 8, 618953) Meantime, there came a call from Bihar.
('96', 332, 2, 9, 618993) and I hurried to Bihar, this time to help the Muslims of whom large numbers had already fled to Bengal, Sind and other Muslim majority parts.
('96', 332, 2, 10, 619135) Since then I have not been able to return to Noakhali.
('96', 332, 2, 11, 619190) When at last I came to Calcutta on the 9th ultimo, I found myself caught by Shaheed Saheb and here I am.
('96', 332, 2, 12, 619295) The sequel you know.
('96', 332, 2, 13, 619316) I am dictating this letter from my bed.
('96', 332, 2, 14, 619356) Everybody consoles me by saying that the first fifteen days of peace will soon return.
('96', 332, 2, 15, 619443) If so, I may be able to break my fast early enough to enable me to resume my work forthwith.
('96', 332, 2, 16, 619536) I have an urgent call from both parts of the Punjab, which have gone, in my opinion, utterly mad.
('96', 332, 2, 17, 619634) Meanwhile, I would like you to tell me all about Noakhali.
('96', 332, 2, 18, 619693) Pyarelal will tell you all about it from my point of view.
('96', 332, 2, 19, 619752) I know that you have become Premier of East Bengal 2 at a most critical period.
('96', 332, 2, 20, 619832) May God help you.
('96', 332, 3, 21, 619850) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. II, pp.

('96', 332, 4, 23, 619942) 2 On July 3, 1947, consequent upon the partition of Bengal
