('96', 333, 4, 11, 620439) 452. DISCUSSION WITH FRIENDS 2
('96', 333, 5, 12, 620470) September 4, 1947
('96', 333, 6, 13, 620488) The present occasion was not one in which there was scope for a sympathetic fast.
('96', 333, 6, 14, 620570) Hindus and Muslims had fought for one whole year, at the end of which the major parties had agreed that India should be divided into two States.
('96', 333, 6, 15, 620715) Both had Hindu and Muslim subjects.
('96', 333, 6, 16, 620751) It was now time for everyone to create the sense of common citizenship, to rebuild the land so that men might taste the fruits of freedom.
('96', 333, 6, 17, 620890) To this end all should work.
('96', 333, 6, 18, 620919) Gandhiji said that if the friends had come to him only for the sake of saving his life, it was nothing.
('96', 333, 7, 19, 621023) Referring to the Poona Fast which ended with the desired amendment of the Communal Award, [Gandhiji said that] it was suggested by some that though the amendment was not to their desire, they accepted it for the sake of saving his life.
('96', 333, 7, 20, 621260) This was a wholly wrong approach.
('96', 333, 7, 21, 621294) Such fasts were intended to stir the conscience and remove mental sluggishness.
('96', 333, 7, 22, 621374) Truth could not be sacrificed even for the sake of saving a life, however precious it was.
('96', 333, 7, 23, 621465) Gandhiji, therefore, warned the present company that they should create real Hindu Muslim unity by educating the people in a sense of common citizenship of the State, where every single man enjoyed perfect equality of rights which flowed from duty performed.
('96', 333, 7, 24, 621724) If they worked with this aim in view, and succeeded after a few days’ effort in making the Muslims in Calcutta feel safe where they now did not, it would be time for him to break the fast.
('96', 333, 7, 25, 621913) Gandhiji was
('96', 333, 8, 26, 621926) 1 Brother of Subhas Chandra Bose.
('96', 333, 8, 27, 621960) He met Gandhiji at 11.30 a.m.
('96', 333, 8, 28, 621990) “with a request that he must take plenty of rest and not talk at all.” 2 Shortly after the talk with Dr. Sunil Bose twenty seven friends belonging to Central Calcutta promised Gandhiji that “there would be no more incidents”.
('96', 333, 8, 29, 622216) They tried to persuade him to “break his fast now, otherwise all of them were prepared to go on a sympathetic fast”.
('96', 333, 8, 30, 622333) This is a summary of a long argument extracted from the article “The Fast” by N. K. Bose.
('96', 334, 0, 1, 622423) VOL. 96: 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 335
('96', 334, 1, 2, 622468) clearly of opinion that although his work was now confined to Calcutta, yet his one aim with respect to the Hindu Muslim question was that the solution would be complete only when the minority, whether in the Indian Union or in Pakistan felt perfectly safe even if they were in the minority of one.
('96', 334, 1, 3, 622767) There would be no favoured and no depressed community anywhere.
('96', 334, 1, 4, 622831) All should forget their religious affiliations.
('96', 334, 1, 5, 622879) He was working to this end.
('96', 334, 1, 6, 622907) He was working in such a manner that the majority community in each State should go forward and create the necessary conditions for freedom.
('96', 334, 2, 7, 623048) Someone asked him: Was it possible that his fast would have any effect on the anti social elements in society?
('96', 334, 2, 8, 623159) Today, i.e., during the present recrudescence, it was this element which had gained the upper hand.
('96', 334, 2, 9, 623259) Could their hearts be converted by Gandhiji’s crucifixion ?
('96', 334, 3, 10, 623319) Gandhiji’s answer was very clear and emphatic.
('96', 334, 3, 11, 623366) He said that goondas were there because we had made them so.
('96', 334, 3, 12, 623427) During the past one year of anarchy, it was understandable how these elements in society had gained respectability.
('96', 334, 3, 13, 623543) But the war between Pakistanis and those for Undivided India had ended.
('96', 334, 3, 14, 623615) It was time for peace loving citizens to assert themselves and isolate goondaism.
('96', 334, 3, 15, 623697) Non violent non co operation was a universal remedy.
('96', 334, 3, 16, 623750) Good was self existent, evil was not.
('96', 334, 3, 17, 623788) It was like a parasite living on and round good.
('96', 334, 3, 18, 623837) It would die of itself when the support that good gave was withdrawn.
('96', 334, 3, 19, 623907) The hearts of the anti social elements may or may not be changed; it would be enough if they were made to feel that the better elements of society were asserting themselves in the interest of peace and in the interest of normality.
('96', 334, 4, 20, 624139) To the interviewers from Central Calcutta Gandhiji’s advice, therefore, was thet they should desist from a sympathetic fast, go forth among the oppressed in each quarter, assure them that they were safe and rebuild life so that safety would be a permanent feature of the new State of India.
('96', 334, 4, 21, 624430) He would personally have loved to move about from quarter to quarter in Calcutta in order to place his views before the various bodies, but his physical condition would not permit it.
('96', 334, 4, 22, 624614) If others worked, how could he rest?
('96', 334, 4, 23, 624651) Yet he was bound to make his contribution.
('96', 334, 4, 24, 624694) He felt that it should be in the shape of a fast.
('96', 334, 4, 25, 624744) Harijan, 14 9 1947

('96', 335, 1, 2, 624805) 453. DISCUSSION WITH A DEPUTATION 1
('96', 335, 2, 3, 624841) September 4, 1947
('96', 335, 3, 4, 624859) Gandhiji told them that he would break his fast only when they could assure
('96', 335, 4, 5, 624935) him that there would never again be recrudescence of communal madness in the city
('96', 335, 5, 6, 625017) even though the whole of West Bengal and, for that matter, India, might go forth into
('96', 335, 6, 7, 625103) a blaze, and the Muslims themselves would come and tell him that they now felt safe
('96', 335, 7, 8, 625187) and secure and, therefore, he need not further prolong his fast.
('96', 335, 7, 9, 625252) 2 He did not expect, he
('96', 335, 8, 10, 625276) proceeded to explain, to be able to control all the goondas in the city, though he
('96', 335, 9, 11, 625359) would love to, as he had not the requisite degree of purity, detachment and
('96', 335, 10, 12, 625435) steadfastness of mind.
('96', 335, 10, 13, 625458) But if he could not even make them purge themselves of the
('96', 335, 11, 14, 625517) communal virus, he would feel that life was not worth living and he would not care to
('96', 335, 12, 15, 625603) prolong it.
('96', 335, 12, 16, 625615) They had referred to the oppression of his fast.
('96', 335, 12, 17, 625664) He could not understand
('96', 335, 13, 18, 625688) Why should they have a feeling of oppression if what they had told him came
('96', 335, 14, 19, 625764) right from their hearts?
('96', 335, 14, 20, 625789) If a single step was taken under pressure of the fast, not from
('96', 335, 15, 21, 625853) conviction, it would cause oppression; but there should be no oppression if there was
('96', 335, 16, 22, 625939) complete co operation between the head and the heart.
('96', 335, 16, 23, 625993) The function of my fast is to purify, to release our energies by overcoming our inertia and mental sluggishness, not to paralyse us or to render us inactive.
('96', 335, 16, 24, 626151) My fast isolates the forces of evil; the moment they are isolated they die, for evil by itself has no legs to stand upon.
('96', 335, 16, 25, 626273) I expect you therefore to work with even greater vigour under the instigation of my fast, not to feel its oppression.
('96', 335, 16, 26, 626391) Harijan, 14 9 1947

('96', 336, 5, 11, 627414) CALCUTTA, September 4, 1947
('96', 336, 6, 12, 627442) The deputation told Gandhiji that they had been to all the affected parts of the city and there was quiet everywhere.
('96', 336, 6, 13, 627560) They would hold themselves responsible for anything untoward that might happen thereafter.
('96', 336, 6, 14, 627651) They had every reason to hope that there would be no recrudescence of trouble which they maintained was “really not communal” but “the work of the goondas”.
('96', 336, 6, 15, 627808) They requested him to terminate his fast.
('96', 336, 7, 16, 627850) After some reflection Gandhiji spoke.
('96', 336, 7, 17, 627888) He deprecated the suggestion that the outbreak of violence was not communal in character but really the work of the goondas.
('96', 336, 7, 18, 628013) It is we who make the goondas and we alone can unmake them.
('96', 336, 7, 19, 628073) Goondas never act on their own.
('96', 336, 7, 20, 628105) By themselves they cannot function.
('96', 336, 8, 21, 628141) It was the cowardice or passive sympathy of the average citizen or “the man with a stake” that gave the so called goondas the power to do mischief.
('96', 336, 8, 22, 628289) My fast should make you more vigilant, more truthful, more careful, more precise in the language you use.
('96', 336, 8, 23, 628395) You have all come here

('96', 339, 1, 2, 634350) 456. SPEECH BEFORE BREAKING OF FAST
('96', 339, 2, 3, 634386) CALCUTTA, September 4, 1947 I would like to tell you something before breaking the fast.
('96', 339, 2, 4, 634475) I am breaking this fast so that I might be able to do something for the Punjab.
('96', 339, 2, 5, 634555) I am doing so at your assurance and not for any other reason.
('96', 339, 2, 6, 634617) It would indeed be very unfortunate if anything happened to make me regret my step.
('96', 339, 2, 7, 634701) I would like to live—as people tell me—to serve all the more.
('96', 339, 2, 8, 634763) I have the will power to live and would like to live but I do not want to be deceived in order to live.
('96', 339, 2, 9, 634867) I expect that the Hindus and Muslims here will not force me to undertake a fast again.
('96', 339, 2, 10, 634954) On the first day Rajaji had asked me whether I had undertaken the fast hoping for something to happen.
('96', 339, 2, 11, 635057) I told him that people would not let me prolong the fast.
('96', 339, 2, 12, 635115) It lasted for three days, it could have for thirty.
('96', 339, 2, 13, 635167) Still I would like to warn you that you should not be lulled into complacence after I break my fast.
('96', 339, 2, 14, 635268) What happens here is bound to have its effect in the Punjab and Noakhali.
('96', 339, 2, 15, 635342) If something happens here how can I control the rowdy Muslims in Noakhali?
('96', 339, 2, 16, 635417) Calcutta today holds the key to the peace of the whole of India.
('96', 339, 2, 17, 635482) If you want to achieve great things, you must work for them.
('96', 339, 2, 18, 635543) Even if the whole world went up in a blaze, Calcutta should remain untouched by the flames.
('96', 339, 2, 19, 635635) May God grant wisdom to everyone.
('96', 339, 2, 20, 635669) These girls have just now sung Ishwar Allah tere nam, sabko sanmati de Bhagwan.
('96', 339, 2, 21, 635749) And, of course, above all, there is God, our witness.
('96', 339, 3, 22, 635803) [From Hindi]
('96', 339, 4, 23, 635816) Calcuttano Chamatkar pp.

('96', 340, 1, 2, 635985) 457. MESSAGE TO UNESCO CONFERENCE ON EDUCATION 1
('96', 340, 2, 3, 636034) [Before September 5, 1947] 2
('96', 340, 3, 4, 636063) I am deeply interested in the efforts of the United Nations Economic, Social and Cultural Organization to secure peace through educational and cultural activities.
('96', 340, 3, 5, 636227) I fully appreciate that real security and lasting peace cannot be secured so long as extreme inequalities in education and culture exist as they do among the nations of the world.
('96', 340, 3, 6, 636407) Light must be carried even to the remotest homes in the less fortunate countries which are in comparative darkness, and I think that in this cause the nations which are economically and educationally advanced have a special responsibility.
('96', 340, 3, 7, 636647) I wish your Conference every success, and I hope that you will be able to produce a workable plan for provinding the right type of education particularly in countries in which opportunities for education are restricted owing to economic and other circumstances.
('96', 340, 3, 8, 636909) Harijan, 16 11 1947
('96', 340, 4, 9, 636929) 458. APPEAL TO FRIENDS
('96', 340, 5, 10, 636952) [Before September 5, 1947] Gandhiji has been receiving letters and telegrams from friends asking for permission to come to Calcutta to help in any matter.
('96', 340, 5, 11, 637107) Gandhiji would warn friends against rushing to Calcutta.
('96', 340, 5, 12, 637164) Any such arrival would complicate matters.
('96', 340, 5, 13, 637207) He has efficient nursing and other necessary attendants.
('96', 340, 5, 14, 637264) He, therefore, requires no extra help for his bodily assistance.
('96', 340, 5, 15, 637329) Accommodation in his new residence is strictily limited as it is all over Calcutta.
('96', 340, 5, 16, 637413) Food is rationed.
('96', 340, 5, 17, 637431) In this condition of scarcity Gandhiji is of opinion that those friends including Ashram members, who are naturally anxious to be near him should understand him and respect his wish that they should restrain themselves against their natural desire.
('96', 340, 5, 18, 637680) They will help him
('96', 340, 6, 19, 637699) on the contrary by strict adherence to their duty in which they are at present engaged.
('96', 340, 7, 20, 637787) Gandhiji wishes to add that he is perfectly at peace and ease and has fullest trust in God’s succour.
('96', 340, 7, 21, 637889) The Hindustan Standard, 5 9 1947

('96', 342, 1, 2, 639661) 462. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 342, 2, 3, 639691) CALCUTTA, Spetember 6, 1947
('96', 342, 3, 4, 639719) Gandhiji, referring to the Deputy Mayor’s speech, said that the word farewell was misapplied.
('96', 342, 3, 5, 639813) He had made his home in Calcutta among the Muslim friends in Beliaghata and not in Khadi Pratishthan, Sodepur, which was his permanent home.
('96', 342, 3, 6, 639954) He would not even allow Hemprobha Devi and her co workers to come to his new abode for looking after him.
('96', 342, 3, 7, 640060) He said that he would be satisfied with what Muslim friends gave him in the shape of service.
('96', 342, 3, 8, 640154) He had made no mistake.
('96', 342, 3, 9, 640178) He was accustomed to living comfortably in Muslim homes in South Africa.

('96', 342, 4, 11, 640327) He was not sorry.
('96', 342, 4, 12, 640345) Such innocent deaths were necessary to keep the two communities together.

('96', 342, 4, 18, 640911) He must say that he was no fool.

('96', 342, 4, 28, 641813) Neither they nor anybody else had any right to question a man’s motives.

('96', 342, 4, 30, 641967) That was the only right way to get on with people.
('96', 342, 4, 31, 642018) They should know that he had been condemned as enemy No.
('96', 342, 4, 32, 642075) 1 of Islam and that in spite of his protestations to the contrary.

('96', 347, 1, 2, 648925) 467. SPEECH AT GOBRA LEPROSY HOSPITAL 1
('96', 347, 2, 3, 648965) CALCUTTA, [September 7, 1947] 2
('96', 347, 3, 4, 648997) Gandhiji visited the Leprosy Hospital this evening before leaving Calcutta.
('96', 347, 3, 5, 649073) Addressing the patients and the staff he said that the he considered it wrong that leprosy should carry more stigma than any other infectious disease.
('96', 347, 3, 6, 649224) Real stigma in his opinion attached to moral ailments rather than to physical ones.
('96', 347, 3, 7, 649308) Drunkards, gamblers and those who suffered from such other ailments of society deserved far more abhorrence than a disease like leprosy.
('96', 347, 3, 8, 649445) He advised them to take refuge in God.
('96', 347, 3, 9, 649484) He alone was the Healer of all ailments—physical, mental or moral.
('96', 347, 4, 10, 649551) The members of the asylum had no occasion whatsoever to feel dejected.
('96', 347, 4, 11, 649622) The fact that moral lepers were worse than the physical ones was surely a matter of some consolation to them.
('96', 347, 4, 12, 649732) The real consolation lay in their utter reliance on God.
('96', 347, 4, 13, 649789) Then they would not feel the want of games and other aids to whiling away time.
('96', 347, 4, 14, 649869) This however did not mean that society did not owe a great duty to the lepers in its midst who after all were the outward symbol of society’s many blemishes which being general were not noticed.
('96', 347, 4, 15, 650064) He thought that the abhorrence which was shown towards lepers was a superstition born of ignorance.
('96', 347, 4, 16, 650164) This he had learnt during his visits to most of the leper asylums of India.

('96', 348, 1, 2, 651242) 469. TASK BEFORE MINISTERS 1
('96', 348, 2, 3, 651271) I have before me quite a number of letters fiercely criticizing what they consider to be their luxurious life.
('96', 348, 2, 4, 651382) They accuse them too of favouritism, even nepotism.
('96', 348, 2, 5, 651434) I know that much criticism comes from ignorance.
('96', 348, 2, 6, 651483) Ministers should not be sensitive.
('96', 348, 2, 7, 651518) They should take in good part even carping criticism.
('96', 348, 2, 8, 651572) They would be surprised if I were to send them the letters I receive; probably, they receive worse.
('96', 348, 2, 9, 651672) Be that as it may, the moral I draw from them is that the critics expect much more from these chosen servants of the people than from others in the way of simplicity, courage, honesty and industry.
('96', 348, 2, 10, 651870) In this matter we cannot imitate the English rulers of the past, except perhaps in industry and discipline.
('96', 348, 2, 11, 651978) The whole purpose of this note will be served if on the one hand the ministers profit by valid criticism and the critics learn to be sober and precise about their facts.
('96', 348, 2, 12, 652148) Inaccuracy or exaggeration spoils a good case.

('96', 348, 3, 14, 652255) 470. BIHAR FOR BIHARIS AND INDIA
('96', 348, 4, 15, 652288) Bihar is undoubtedly for Biharis but it is also for India.
('96', 348, 4, 16, 652347) What is true of Bihar is equally true of all the provinces in the Union.
('96', 348, 4, 17, 652420) No Indian can be treated as a foreigner in Bihar as he may be treated in Pakistan of today and vice versa.
('96', 348, 4, 18, 652527) It is necessary to bear this difference in mind if we are to avoid difficulties and heart burn[ing].
('96', 348, 4, 19, 652628) Though then every Indian of the Union has a right to settle in Bihar, he must not do so to oust the Biharis.
('96', 348, 4, 20, 652737) If the qualification was not actively operated, it is possible to conceive such an inrush of non Bihari Indians as to flood out the Biharis.
('96', 348, 4, 21, 652878) We are thus forced to the conclusion that a non Bihari who settles in Bihar must do so to serve Bihar, not to exploit it after the manner of our old masters.
('96', 348, 4, 22, 653036) This way of examining the proposition brings us to the question of the zamindars and the ryots.
('96', 348, 4, 23, 653132) When a non Bihari enters Bihar for the sake of making money, he will in all probability do so to exploit the ryot in league with the zamindars.
('96', 348, 4, 24, 653276) If the zamindars really became the
('96', 348, 5, 25, 653311) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.

('96', 349, 1, 2, 653384) trustees of their zamindari for the sake of the ryots, there never could be an unholy league as has been here conceived.

('96', 349, 1, 17, 655108) “Use what you consider yours so as not to injure others,” is a famous maxim of equity.
('96', 349, 1, 18, 655195) It is also a grand moral code of conduct.
('96', 349, 1, 19, 655237) How apposite today?
('96', 349, 1, 20, 655257) Hitherto I have dealt with the question of new arrivals.

('96', 349, 1, 25, 655715) The process of progressive blending must be one of rejecting the bad and absorbing the good.
('96', 349, 1, 26, 655808) As a Gujarati in Bengal, I must quickly absorb all that is good in Bengal and never touch that which is bad; I must ever serve Bengal, never selfishly exploit it.

('96', 350, 2, 5, 656275) 471. PROHIBITION OF INTOXICANTS 1
('96', 350, 3, 6, 656309) This is the fittest time for this reform.
('96', 350, 3, 7, 656351) Thesre is a people’s Government.
('96', 350, 3, 8, 656384) Both parts of India including the Indian States are ready for the reform.
('96', 350, 3, 9, 656458) All over the two parts there is a shortage of foodstuffs and clothing.
('96', 350, 3, 10, 656529) Dare one think of indulging in intoxicants—drinks or drugs—when people are on the border land of starvation and nakedness?
('96', 350, 3, 11, 656652) The money spent on wines and opiates is not only a waste, but it adds to it loss of self control.
('96', 350, 3, 12, 656750) One labouring under the influence of intoxicants will do things which he will never do in a sober state.
('96', 350, 3, 13, 656855) Thus from every point of view prohibition is a vital necessity.
('96', 350, 3, 14, 656919) We cannot eradicate the evil merely by passing laws.
('96', 350, 3, 15, 656972) The addict will manage to satisfy his craving anyhow.
('96', 350, 3, 16, 657026) Those carrying on the black trade will not readily give it up.
('96', 350, 3, 17, 657089) Therefore the following steps will have to be taken simult aneously in order to make a success of the reform : 1. Passing of the requisite law 2. Educating public opinion 3. Opening at the same place as grog shops refreshmentrooms selling harmless drinks and providing innocent entertainment in the form of books, newspapers, games, etc.
('96', 350, 3, 18, 657427) 4. The income from the sale of intoxicants should be spent on cultivating public opinion in favour of prohibition.
('96', 350, 3, 19, 657542) It is criminal to spend the income from the sale of intoxicants on the education of the nation’s children or other publice services.
('96', 350, 3, 20, 657675) The Government must overcome the temptation of using such revenue for nation building purposes.
('96', 350, 3, 21, 657771) Experience has shown that the moral and physical gain of the abstainer more than makes up for the loss of this tainted revenue.
('96', 350, 3, 22, 657899) If we eradicate the evil, we will easily find other ways and means of increasing the nation’s income.

('96', 351, 0, 1, 658123) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 352
('96', 351, 1, 2, 658165) 472. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('96', 351, 2, 3, 658193) NEW DELHI, September 9, 1947 ‘Man proposes, God disposes’ has come true often enough in my lifetime as it must have done in many others’.
('96', 351, 2, 4, 658331) I knew nothing about the sad state of things in Delhi when I left Calcutta on Sunday last.
('96', 351, 2, 5, 658422) On reaching Delhi, I have been listening the whole day long to the tale of woe that is Delhi today.
('96', 351, 2, 6, 658522) I saw several Muslim friends who recited their pathetic story.
('96', 351, 2, 7, 658585) I heard enough to warn me that I must not leave Delhi for the Punjab until it had regained its former self.
('96', 351, 2, 8, 658693) I must do my little bit to calm the heated atmosphere.
('96', 351, 2, 9, 658748) I must apply the old formula “Do or Die” to the capital of India.
('96', 351, 2, 10, 658814) I am glad to be able to say that the residents of Delhi do not want the senseless destruction that is going on.
('96', 351, 2, 11, 658926) I am prepared to understand the anger of the refugees whom fate has driven from West Punjab.
('96', 351, 2, 12, 659019) But anger is short madness.
('96', 351, 2, 13, 659047) It can only make matters worse in every way.
('96', 351, 2, 14, 659092) Retaliation is no remedy.

('96', 357, 4, 8, 671246) 475. TAKE CARE
('96', 357, 5, 9, 671261) Unless the Governments and their Secretariats take care, the English language is likely to usurp the place of Hindustani.
('96', 357, 5, 10, 671383) This must do infinite harm to the millions of India who would never be able to understand English.
('96', 357, 5, 11, 671482) Surely, it must be quite easy for the provincial Governments to have a staff which would carry on all transactions in the provincial languages and the interprovincial language, which, in my opinion, can only be Hindustani written in Nagari or Urdu script.
('96', 357, 5, 12, 671738) Every day lost in making this necessary change is so much cultural loss to the nation.
('96', 357, 5, 13, 671825) The first and foremost thing is to revive the rich provincial languages with which India is blessed.
('96', 357, 5, 14, 671926) It is nothing short of mental sluggishness to plead that in our courts, in our schools and even in the secretariats, some time, probably a few years, must lapse before the change is made.
('96', 357, 5, 15, 672114) No doubt a little difficulty will be felt in multi lingual provinces, as in Bombay and Madras, until redistribution of provinces takes place on a linguistic basis.
('96', 357, 5, 16, 672278) Provincial Governments can devise a method in order to enable the people in those provinces to feel that they have come into their own.
('96', 357, 5, 17, 672414) Nor need the provinces wait for the Union for solving the question, whether for interprovincial speech it shall be Hindustani written in either Nagari or Urdu script or mere Hindi written in Nagari.
('96', 357, 5, 18, 672613) This should not detain them in making the desired reforms.

('96', 360, 3, 5, 677032) I am, of course deeply pained to hear it.
('96', 360, 3, 6, 677074) I have spent considerable time in the Frontier Province.

('96', 365, 1, 2, 689496) 479. MY STATUE 1
('96', 365, 2, 3, 689513) There is a talk in Bombay of spending ten lacs of rupees on erecting my statue on a public site.

('96', 365, 2, 6, 689815) Only the wise sift the grain from the chaff.

('96', 365, 2, 8, 689930) I must say that I have dislike even for being photographed; nevertheless, photographs have been taken of me.
('96', 365, 2, 9, 690039) I have let artists make models more than once.
('96', 365, 2, 10, 690086) Notwithstanding this inconsistency, I must dissent emphatically from any proposal to spend any money on preparing a statue of me, more especially at a time when people do not have enough food and clothing.
('96', 365, 2, 11, 690292) In Bombay the beautiful, insanitation reigns.
('96', 365, 2, 12, 690338) There is so much overcrowding that poor people ae packed like sardines.

('96', 365, 2, 15, 690528) Money thus wisely spent will make an adequate return.
('96', 365, 2, 16, 690582) Imagine how many hungry mouths would be filled if the amount was spent on growing more food crops!

('96', 366, 3, 4, 691392) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Long ago, perhaps in 1915, when I came to Delhi I had met Hakim Saheb 1 and Dr. Ansari.
('96', 366, 3, 5, 691502) I was told that Delhi was ruled not by the British but by Hakim Saheb.

('96', 374, 6, 14, 712086) 484. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 3
('96', 374, 7, 15, 712118) NEW DELHI, September 15, 1947 During the night as I heard what should have been the soothing sound of gentle life giving rain, my mind went out to the thousands of refugees lying about in the open camps at Delhi.
('96', 374, 7, 16, 712331) I was sleeping snugly in a verandah protecting me on all sides.
('96', 374, 7, 17, 712395) But for the cruel hand of man against his brother, these thousands of men, women and children would not be shelterless and in many cases foodless.
('96', 374, 7, 18, 712542) In some places they could not but be in knee deep water.
('96', 374, 7, 19, 712599) They have no other choice.
('96', 374, 8, 20, 712626) Was it all inevitable?
('96', 374, 8, 21, 712649) The answer from within was an emphatic ‘No.’ Was this the first fruit of freedom, just a month old baby?
('96', 374, 8, 22, 712754) These thoughts have haunted me throughout these last twenty hours.
('96', 374, 8, 23, 712821) My silence has been a blessing.
('96', 374, 8, 24, 712853) It has made me enquire within.
('96', 374, 8, 25, 712884) Have the citizens of Delhi gone mad?
('96', 374, 8, 26, 712921) Have they no humanity left in them?
('96', 374, 8, 27, 712957) Have love of the country and its freedom no appeal for them?
('96', 374, 8, 28, 713018) I must be pardoned for putting the blame first on the Hindus and Sikhs.

('96', 375, 1, 4, 713714) Not that the former too do not have any.

('96', 379, 1, 2, 718660) 492. SPEECH AT R. S. S. RALLY 1
('96', 379, 2, 3, 718692) NEW DELHI, September 16, 1947
('96', 379, 3, 4, 718722) Gandhiji said that he had visited the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh camp years ago at Wardha, when the founder Shri Hedgewar was alive.
('96', 379, 3, 5, 718856) The late Shri Jamnalal Bajaj had taken him to the camp and he (Gandhiji) had been very well impressed by their discipline, complete absence of untouchability and rigorous simplicity.
('96', 379, 3, 6, 719039) Since then the Sangh had grown.
('96', 379, 3, 7, 719071) Gandhiji was convinced that any organization which was inspired by the ideal of service and self sacrifice was bound to grow in strength.
('96', 379, 3, 8, 719209) But in order to be truly useful, self sacrifice had to be combined with purity of motive and true knowledge.
('96', 379, 3, 9, 719318) Sacrifice without these two had been known to prove ruinous to society.
('96', 379, 4, 10, 719390) The prayer that was recited at the beginning was in praise of Mother India, Hindu culture and Hindu religion.
('96', 379, 4, 11, 719500) He claimed to be a sanatani Hindu.
('96', 379, 4, 12, 719535) He took the root meaning of the word sanatana.
('96', 379, 4, 13, 719582) No one knew accurately the origin of the word Hindu.
('96', 379, 4, 14, 719635) The name was given to us and we had characteristically adopted it.
('96', 379, 4, 15, 719702) Hinduism had absorbed the best of all the faiths of the world and in that sense it was not an exclusive religion.
('96', 379, 4, 16, 719816) Hence it could have no quarrel with Islam or its followers as unfortunately was the case today.
('96', 379, 4, 17, 719912) When the poison of untouchability entered Hinduism, the decline began.
('96', 379, 4, 18, 719983) One thing was certain, and he had been proclaiming it from house tops, that if untouchability lived, Hinduism must die.
('96', 379, 4, 19, 720103) Similarly, if the Hindus felt that in India there was no place for anyone else except the Hindus and if non Hindus, especially Muslims, wished to live here, they had to live as the slaves of the Hindus, they would kill Hinduism.
('96', 379, 4, 20, 720332) Similarly if Pakistan believed that in Pakistan only the Muslims had a rightful place and the non Muslims had to live there on sufferance and as their slaves, it would be the death knell of Islam in India.
('96', 379, 5, 21, 720538) It was an unfortunate fact that India had been divided into two parts.
('96', 379, 5, 22, 720609) If one part
('96', 379, 6, 23, 720621) went mad and did ugly deeds, was the other part to follow suit?
('96', 379, 6, 24, 720685) There was no gain in
('96', 379, 7, 25, 720706) returning evil for evil.
('96', 379, 7, 26, 720731) Religion taught us to return good for evil.
('96', 379, 8, 27, 720775) He had seen their Guruji a few days ago.
('96', 379, 8, 28, 720816) He had mentioned to him the various complaints about the Sangh that he had received in Calcutta and Delhi.
('96', 379, 8, 29, 720923) The Guruji had assured him that though he could not vouch safe for the correct behaviour of every member of the Sangh, the policy of the Sangh was purely service of the Hindus and Hinduism and that too not at the cost of anyone else.
('96', 379, 8, 30, 721157) The Sangh did not believe in
('96', 379, 9, 31, 721186) 1 Held in the sweepers’ colony
('96', 380, 0, 1, 721217) VOL. 96: 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 381
('96', 380, 1, 2, 721262) aggression.
('96', 380, 1, 3, 721274) It did not believe in ahimsa.
('96', 380, 1, 4, 721304) It taught the art of self defence.
('96', 380, 1, 5, 721339) It never taught retaliation.
('96', 380, 2, 6, 721368) Today the ship of India was passing through troubled waters.
('96', 380, 2, 7, 721429) The leaders in charge of the Government were the best that India possessed.
('96', 380, 2, 8, 721505) Some people were dissatisfied with them.
('96', 380, 2, 9, 721546) He would ask them to produce better men if they could and he would advise the old guards to hand over the reins to their betters.
('96', 380, 2, 10, 721676) After all the Sardar was an old man and Pandit Jawaharlal, though not old in years, looked old and haggard under the burden he was carrying.
('96', 380, 2, 11, 721817) They were doing their utmost to serve the people, but they could only act according to their lights.
('96', 380, 2, 12, 721918) If the vast bulk of the Hindus wanted to go in a particular direction, even though it might be wrong, no one could prevent them from doing so.
('96', 380, 2, 13, 722061) But even a single individual had the right to raise his voice against it and give them the warning.
('96', 380, 2, 14, 722161) That is what Gandhiji was doing.
('96', 380, 2, 15, 722194) He was told that he was the friend of the Muslims and the enemy of the Hindus and the Sikhs.
('96', 380, 2, 16, 722287) It was true that he was a friend of the Muslims, as he was of the Parsis and others.
('96', 380, 2, 17, 722372) In this respect he was the same today as he had been since the age of twelve.
('96', 380, 2, 18, 722450) But those who called him the enemy of the Hindus and the Sikhs did not know him.
('96', 380, 2, 19, 722531) He could be enemy of none, much less of the Hindus and Sikhs.
('96', 380, 3, 20, 722593) If Pakistan persisted in wrongdoing, there was bound to be war between India and Pakistan.
('96', 380, 3, 21, 722684) If he had his way, he would have no military; not even police.
('96', 380, 3, 22, 722747) But all this was tall talk.
('96', 380, 3, 23, 722775) He was not the Government.
('96', 380, 3, 24, 722802) Why did not Pakistan plead with the Hindus and the Sikhs and ask them not to leave their homes and ensure their safety in every way?
('96', 380, 3, 25, 722935) Why could not they in the Indian Union ensure the safety of every Muslim?
('96', 380, 3, 26, 723009) Today both the parties appeared to have gone crazy.
('96', 380, 3, 27, 723061) The result could be nothing but destruction and misery.
('96', 380, 4, 28, 723117) The Sangh was a well organized, well disciplined body.
('96', 380, 4, 29, 723172) Its strength could be used in the interest of India or against it.
('96', 380, 4, 30, 723239) He did not know whether there was any truth in the allegations made against the Sangh.
('96', 380, 4, 31, 723326) It was for the Sangh to show by their uniform behaviour that the allegations were baseless.
('96', 380, 5, 32, 723418) At the conclusion of the speech, Gandhiji invited questions.
('96', 380, 5, 33, 723479) One person asked if Hinduism permitted killing of an evil doer.
('96', 380, 5, 34, 723543) 2 If not how did he explain the exhortation by Lord Krishna in the second chapter of the Gita to destroy the Kauravas.
('96', 380, 6, 35, 723662) The reply to the first question, said Gandhiji, was both yes and no.
('96', 380, 6, 36, 723731) One had to be an infallible judge as to who was the evil doer before the question of killing could arise.
('96', 380, 6, 37, 723837) In other words one had to be completely faultless before such a right could accrue to one.
('96', 380, 6, 38, 723928) How could a sinner claim the right to judge or execute another sinner?
('96', 380, 7, 39, 723999) 1Vide also “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 12 9 1947. 2 What follows is reproduced from The Last Phase.
('96', 381, 0, 1, 724099) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 381, 1, 2, 724141) As for the second question, granting that the right to punish the evildoer was recognized by the Gita, it could be exercised by the properly constituted Government only.
('96', 381, 1, 3, 724311) Both the Sardar and Pandit Nehru will be rendered powerless if you become judge and executioner in one.
('96', 381, 1, 4, 724415) They are tried servants of the nation.
('96', 381, 1, 5, 724454) Give them a chance to serve you.
('96', 381, 1, 6, 724487) Do not sabotage their efforts by taking the law into your own hands.

('96', 381, 6, 15, 724959) 494. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('96', 381, 7, 16, 724989) NEW DELHI, September 17, 1947 After my experience of last evening 2 I have decided not to hold the prayers till every man present in the audience is ready for it.
('96', 381, 7, 17, 725152) I have never imposed anything on anybody, then how can I impose a highly spiritual thing like prayer?
('96', 381, 7, 18, 725254) The prompting to pray or not to pray should come from within.
('96', 381, 7, 19, 725316) There is no question at all of pleasing me.
('96', 381, 8, 20, 725360) 1 In a letter to the addressee Sushila Nayyar inter alia wrote: “Bapu is going to have a hard time of it here.
('96', 381, 8, 21, 725471) Yesterday he was saying that he would not be surprised if some of us might have to go the way of the leaders of the French Revolution.
('96', 381, 8, 22, 725606) The exchange of population is actually taking place however much we may dislike it.
('96', 381, 8, 23, 725690) Will there be a mass exodus of Hindus from East Pakistan after the manner of West Pakistan?
('96', 381, 8, 24, 725782) Bapu says it would be a catastrophe.” 2 At the prayer meeting on September 16, as soon as the recitation from the Koran had commenced, someone in the gathering shouted: “To the recitation of these verses, our mothers and sisters were dishonoured, our dear ones killed.
('96', 381, 8, 25, 726051) We will not let you recite these verses here.” Some shouted: “Gandhi murdabad” (death to Gandhi).
('96', 381, 8, 26, 726149) All efforts to restore order having failed, the prayer was abandoned.
('96', 382, 0, 1, 726219) VOL. 96: 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 383
('96', 382, 1, 2, 726264) My prayer meetings have become really popular.
('96', 382, 1, 3, 726311) It appears that millions of people have been benefited from these meetings.
('96', 382, 1, 4, 726387) But in these times of mutual tension I very well understand the anger of the people who have undergone great hardships.
('96', 382, 1, 5, 726507) My only condition for holding the prayer is that I should not be expected to omit that particular portion to which there may be some objection.
('96', 382, 1, 6, 726651) Either the prayer should be heartily accepted as a whole or it should be rejected.
('96', 382, 1, 7, 726734) For me the recitation from the Koran is that part of the prayer which cannot be discontinued.
('96', 382, 1, 8, 726828) I can understand your resentment and the impatience it generates.
('96', 382, 1, 9, 726894) But if you wish to qualify yourselves to deserve your freedom, you will have to curb your anger and will have to depend on your Government to get the fullest justice done to you.
('96', 382, 1, 10, 727073) I am not proposing to you my method of non violence, much as I would like to, for I know that today no one is going to listen to my talk about non violence.
('96', 382, 1, 11, 727230) That is why I have suggested that you should adopt the ways followed by all democratic countries.
('96', 382, 1, 12, 727328) In democracy, every individual has to abide by the wishes of the people, that is, the Government, and has to direct his own wishes in that light.
('96', 382, 1, 13, 727474) If every man takes the law into his own hands the State cannot function.
('96', 382, 1, 14, 727547) It would mean anarchy, which means end of social order.
('96', 382, 1, 15, 727603) That is, the State would not exist.
('96', 382, 1, 16, 727639) That is the way to lose our independence.
('96', 382, 1, 17, 727681) I believe that if you would let the Government carry out its tasks, there is no doubt that every Hindu and Sikh refugee would return home with honour and respect.
('96', 382, 1, 18, 727844) But you cannot expect these things to happen if you want your Muslim compatriots to be driven out of India.
('96', 382, 1, 19, 727952) I find any such thing dreadful.
('96', 382, 1, 20, 727984) You cannot secure justice by doing injustice to the Muslims.
('96', 382, 1, 21, 728045) Apart from that, if it is true that the minorities, that is, the Hindus and the Sikhs have been treated very badly in Pakistan, it is also true that in East Punjab the monority people, that is the Muslims, have been badly treated.
('96', 382, 1, 22, 728276) For both the countries the right way to arrive at a proper agreement is that both sides should acknowledge their mistakes with clean hearts and arrive at a mutual settlement.
('96', 382, 1, 23, 728451) If it is not possible to come to a settlement they must resort to arbitration and accept the arbitrator’s decision.
('96', 382, 1, 24, 728567) Another way is the uncivilized way of war.
('96', 382, 1, 25, 728610) I hate the very idea of war.
('96', 382, 1, 26, 728639) But there would be no alternative to war in the absence of mutual settlement or decision by an arbitrator.
('96', 382, 1, 27, 728746) I therefore hope that in such circumstances people will give up their madness and come to their senses and reassure
('96', 383, 0, 1, 728862) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 383, 1, 2, 728904) their Muslim neighbours who have chosen not to go to Pakistan, and persuade them to return to their hearths by promising safety and protection to them.
('96', 383, 1, 3, 729056) This thing cannot be accomplished with the help of the army.
('96', 383, 1, 4, 729117) It can be achieved only when people come to their senses.
('96', 383, 1, 5, 729175) I have decided not to live to witness the country being ruined by fratricide.
('96', 383, 1, 6, 729253) I am constantly praying to God that.
('96', 383, 1, 7, 729290) He should take me away before any calamity befalls this sacred and beautiful land of ours.

('96', 383, 1, 9, 729426) I am grateful to the Hindu and Muslim workers 1 for working together in amity.
('96', 383, 1, 10, 729505) If you would work with perfect unity, you would provide a worthy example to the country.

('96', 383, 1, 12, 729669) Have I not said that if only you knew your own power and continued to do constructive work with understanding, you would become true owners and rulers and your employers would be your trustees and friends to help you in the times of difficulty?
('96', 383, 1, 13, 729914) That happy moment can come only when they realize that rather than gold and silver which only the workers bring out from the earth, the workers themselves are the true wealth.

('96', 384, 2, 3, 730730) NEW DELHI, September 18, 1947
('96', 384, 3, 4, 730760) Addressing them Gandhiji said that they had to be brave and declare firmly that they would not leave their homes whatever might happen.
('96', 384, 3, 5, 730896) They should look to none but God for their safety and protection.
('96', 384, 3, 6, 730962) He was there to do whatever he could.
('96', 384, 3, 7, 731000) He had pledged himself to do or die in Noakhali, Bihar, Calcutta and now in Delhi.
('96', 384, 3, 8, 731083) He would not ask those who had left their homes to come back till there was real peace and the Hindus, the Sikhs and the Muslims agreed to live as brothers without the help of the police and the military.
('96', 384, 4, 9, 731288) He was the friend and servant of the Muslims as of the Hindus and others.
('96', 384, 4, 10, 731362) He would not rest till every Muslim in the Union, who wished to live as a loyal citizen of the Union, was back in his home living in peace and security and the Hindus and the Sikhs returned likewise to their homes.
('96', 384, 4, 11, 731577) He had served the Muslims for a long time in South Africa and in India.
('96', 384, 4, 12, 731649) He could never forget the unity of the Khilafat days.
('96', 384, 4, 13, 731703) It did not last, but it demonstrated the possibilities of lasting friendship between the Hindus and the Muslims.
('96', 384, 4, 14, 731816) That was what he lived for and worked for.
('96', 384, 4, 15, 731859) He was on his way to the Punjab to see that all the Hindus and the Sikhs who had been turned out of Pakistan should be able to return to their homes and live there in safety and honour.
('96', 384, 4, 16, 732045) But on his way he was held up at Delhi and he would not leave it till real peace returned to the capital.
('96', 384, 4, 17, 732151) Even if he was the only one to say it, he would never advise the Muslims to leave their homes.
('96', 384, 4, 18, 732246) If they lived as law abiding, honest and loyal citizens of India, no one could touch them.
('96', 384, 4, 19, 732337) He was not the Government, but he had influence with those in the Government.
('96', 384, 4, 20, 732415) He had long talks with them.
('96', 384, 4, 21, 732444) They did not believe that in India the Muslims had no place or that if the Muslims wished to stay here they had to do so as slaves of the Hindus.
('96', 384, 4, 22, 732590) Some people had said that Sardar Patel encouraged the idea of Muslims going away to Pakistan.
('96', 384, 4, 23, 732684) The Sardar was indignant at the suggestion.
('96', 384, 4, 24, 732728) But he told him (Gandhiji) that he had reasons to suspect that the vast majority of the Muslims in India were not loyal to India.
('96', 384, 4, 25, 732858) For such people it was better to go to Pakistan.
('96', 384, 4, 26, 732907) But the Sardar did not let his suspicion colour his actions.
('96', 384, 4, 27, 732968) Gandhiji was convinced that for the Muslims who wished to be citizens of the Indian Union, loyalty to the Union must come before everything else and they should be prepared to fight against the whole world for their country.
('96', 384, 4, 28, 733193) Those who wished to go to Pakistan

('96', 385, 4, 19, 735215) 497. DISCUSSION WITH H. S. SUHRAWARDY
('96', 385, 5, 20, 735253) [September 18, 1947] 2
('96', 385, 6, 21, 735276) Shaheed took upon himself the mission of bringing about a rapprochement between the two Dominions.
('96', 385, 6, 22, 735375) Gandhiji tried to impress upon him that the crux of the problem was that both Governments should make a clean breast of their mistakes and failures.
('96', 385, 6, 23, 735524) They should honestly and sincerely strive to bring about conditions, each in its own Dominion, that would enable all the refugees to go back to their original homes with a guarantee of safety and equal treatment.
('96', 385, 6, 24, 735737) What was actually happening in either Dominion was for cible evacuation of the minorities without compensation or any of the guarantees that go with a planned transfer of populations on a reciprocal basis.
('96', 385, 6, 25, 735943) As a result the refugees had begun to take the law into their own hands and to squeeze out the minorities from the respective Dominions.
('96', 385, 6, 26, 736080) Pressure was being put upon the Union Government to apply reciprocity to the Indian Muslims.
('96', 385, 6, 27, 736173) This could
('96', 385, 7, 28, 736184) 1 This paragraph is from Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. II, p.

('96', 386, 1, 2, 736327) easily lead to a war between the two countries as the Pakistan Government had already declared that they would permit refugees from East Punjab to come over but would resist the entry into Pakistan of Muslims from other parts of India.
('96', 386, 2, 3, 736563) Due to his old associations with the Pakistan leaders, Shaheed possessed a certain initial advantage which he could turn to good account, if he set about the business in the right spirit and in the right way.
('96', 386, 2, 4, 736772) Gandhiji told him that he should go to Karachi only if his own heart was free of all prejudice.
('96', 386, 2, 5, 736868) His usefulness would depend upon his ability courageously to get his old colleague Qaid e Azam to face up to his own declarations respecting the minorities which were being honoured more in the breach than the observance.
('96', 386, 2, 6, 737090) If Shaheed himself lacked the conviction or if his own mind was clouded, his visit would do more harm than good.

('96', 399, 3, 4, 764166) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims cannot continue to live the way they are living now.

('96', 402, 1, 2, 771142) 510. MY DUTY 1
('96', 402, 2, 3, 771157) This heading has reference only to my duty about the conducting of the Harijan papers.
('96', 402, 2, 4, 771244) A fair number of replies have been received in answer to my query 2. The majority of the readers with a few exceptions want the papers to be continued.
('96', 402, 2, 5, 771396) The purport of these letters is that the readers desire my views on present day topics.
('96', 402, 2, 6, 771484) This means that probably after my death these will no longer be required.
('96', 402, 2, 7, 771558) My death can take place in three ways : 1. The usual dissolution of the body.
('96', 402, 2, 8, 771636) 2. Only the eyes move but the mind no longer works.
('96', 402, 2, 9, 771688) 3. The body and mind may work but I may withdraw from all public activity.
('96', 402, 2, 10, 771763) The first kind overtakes everybody—some die today, others tomorrow.
('96', 402, 2, 11, 771831) It demands no consideration.
('96', 402, 2, 12, 771860) The second variety is to be wished by or for nobody.
('96', 402, 2, 13, 771913) I for one do not wish for any such imbecile state.
('96', 402, 2, 14, 771964) It is a burden on earth.
('96', 402, 2, 15, 771989) The third variety does demand serious consideration.
('96', 402, 2, 16, 772042) Some readers suggest that the period of my active life should be over now.
('96', 402, 2, 17, 772117) A new age for India began on 15th August last.
('96', 402, 2, 18, 772164) There is no place for me in that age.
('96', 402, 2, 19, 772202) I detect anger in this advice as it is worded.
('96', 402, 2, 20, 772249) It therefore carries little weight with me.
('96', 402, 2, 21, 772293) Such counsellors are few.
('96', 402, 2, 22, 772319) I have come to an independent conclusion.
('96', 402, 2, 23, 772361) The Harijan papers are being conducted and published under the Navajivan Trust.
('96', 402, 2, 24, 772441) The trustees can stop publication whenever they choose.
('96', 402, 2, 25, 772497) They have full powers.
('96', 402, 2, 26, 772520) They do not desire any such stoppage.
('96', 402, 2, 27, 772558) My life line is cast in active public service.
('96', 402, 2, 28, 772605) I have not attained the state which is known as “action in inaction”.
('96', 402, 2, 29, 772675) 3 My activity, therefore, seems at present to be destined to continue till the last breath.
('96', 402, 2, 30, 772767) Nor is it capable of being divided into water tight compartments.
('96', 402, 2, 31, 772833) The root of all lies in Truth otherwise

('96', 406, 1, 2, 777362) 517. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('96', 406, 2, 3, 777394) NEW DELHI, September 22, 1947 Though I believe that I was wise in having yielded to a solitary objector and refrained from holding public prayer, 2 it is not improper to examine the incident a little more fully.
('96', 406, 2, 4, 777606) The prayer was public only in the sense that no member of the public was debarred from attending it.
('96', 406, 2, 5, 777707) It was on private premises.
('96', 406, 2, 6, 777735) Propriety required that those only should attend who believed whole heartedly in the prayer including verses from the Koran.
('96', 406, 2, 7, 777860) Indeed the rule should be applicable to prayer held even on public grounds.
('96', 406, 2, 8, 777936) A prayer meeting is not a debating assembly.
('96', 406, 2, 9, 777981) It is possible to conceive prayer meetings of many communities on the same plot of land.
('96', 406, 2, 10, 778070) Decency requires that those who are opposed to particular prayers shall abstain from attending the meetings they object to.
('96', 406, 2, 11, 778194) The reverse would make any meeting impossible without disturbance.
('96', 406, 2, 12, 778261) Freedom of worship, even of public speech, would become a farce if interference became the order of the day.
('96', 406, 2, 13, 778370) In decent society the exercise of this elementary right should not need the protection of the bayonet.
('96', 406, 2, 14, 778473) It should command universal acceptance.
('96', 406, 2, 15, 778513) I have noticed with great joy at the annual sessions of the Congress on its exhibition grounds several meetings held by religious sects or political parties holding their gatherings, expressing divergent and often diametrically opposite views without molestation and without any assistance from the police.
('96', 406, 2, 16, 778820) There have been departures from this fundamental rule and they have excited public condem nation.
('96', 406, 2, 17, 778918) Where has that spirit of healthy toleration gone now?
('96', 406, 2, 18, 778972) Is it because having gained our political freedom, we are testing it by abusing it?
('96', 406, 2, 19, 779056) Let us hope it is only a passing phase in the nation’s life.
('96', 406, 2, 20, 779117) Let me not be told, as I have often been, that it is all due to the misdeeds of the Muslim League.
('96', 406, 2, 21, 779216) Assuming the truth of the remark, is our toleration made of such poor stuff that it must yield under some uncommon strain?
('96', 406, 2, 22, 779339) Decency and toleration to be of value must be
('96', 406, 3, 23, 779385) 1 As Gandhiji was observing silence his written speech in Hindustani was read out at the meeting.
('96', 406, 3, 24, 779483) 2 Gandhiji was referring to the incident of the previous day; vide 1st footnote to “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 21 9 1947.
('96', 407, 0, 1, 779605) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 407, 1, 2, 779647) capable of standing the severest strain.
('96', 407, 1, 3, 779688) If they cannot, it will be a sad day for India.
('96', 407, 1, 4, 779736) Let us not make it easy for our critics (we have many) to say that we did not deserve liberty.
('96', 407, 1, 5, 779831) Many arguments come to my mind in answer to such critics.
('96', 407, 1, 6, 779889) But they give poor comfort.
('96', 407, 1, 7, 779917) It hurts my pride as a lover of India, of the teeming millions, that our tolerant and combined culture should not be self evident.
('96', 407, 1, 8, 780048) If India fails, Asia dies.
('96', 407, 1, 9, 780075) It has been aptly called the nursery of many blended cultures and civilizations.
('96', 407, 1, 10, 780156) Let India be and remain the hope of all the exploited races of the earth, whether in Asia, Africa or in any part of the world.
('96', 407, 1, 11, 780283) This brings me to the bugbear of unlicensed, hidden arms.
('96', 407, 1, 12, 780341) Some have undoubtedly been found.
('96', 407, 1, 13, 780375) Driblets have been coming to me voluntarily.
('96', 407, 1, 14, 780420) Let them be unearthed by all means.

('96', 407, 1, 16, 780534) Hidden arms used to be possessed even during the British regime.
('96', 407, 1, 17, 780599) No one worried then.
('96', 407, 1, 18, 780620) By all means explode all the hidden magazines, when you have made sure beyond doubt that they are hidden in a particular place.
('96', 407, 1, 19, 780748) Let there be no repetition of much cry and little wool.
('96', 407, 1, 20, 780804) Nor let us apply one code to the British and set up another for ourselves when we profess to be politically free.
('96', 407, 1, 21, 780918) Let us not call a dog a bad name in order to beat him.
('96', 407, 1, 22, 780973) After all is said and done, to be worthy of the liberty we have won after sixty years of toil, let us bravely face all the difficulties that confront us, however hard they may be.
('96', 407, 1, 23, 781153) Facing them squarely will make us fitter and nobler.
('96', 407, 1, 24, 781206) Surely it is cowardly on the part of the majority to kill or banish the minority for fear that they will all be traitors.

('96', 420, 3, 9, 807941) 529. IMPLICATIONS OF FASTING 1
('96', 420, 4, 10, 807972) A friend writes :
('96', 420, 5, 11, 807990) It seems to me that to put your life in jeopardy has become the final and natural remedy for you.
('96', 420, 5, 12, 808088) Be that as it may, I cannot help thinking that the remedy is akin to keeping a patient alive by administering injections or oxygen to him.
('96', 420, 5, 13, 808227) The above reflection proceeds from pain due to affection.
('96', 420, 5, 14, 808285) Nevertheless, I must say that the writer has not given much thought to his criticism.
('96', 420, 5, 15, 808371) Many other well wishers probably entertain the same hasty opinion.
('96', 420, 5, 16, 808438) Hence this public discussion.
('96', 420, 5, 17, 808468) The critic’s simile is inapplicable.
('96', 420, 5, 18, 808505) Administration of injections or oxygen are outward remedies, calculated merely to prolong bodily existence.
('96', 420, 5, 19, 808613) Therefore, they are properly described as of momentary value.
('96', 420, 5, 20, 808675) Nothing will be lost if those remedies were not applied.
('96', 420, 5, 21, 808732) A physical body cannot be made immortal.
('96', 420, 5, 22, 808773) All that medical skill can do is to prolong the existence for a while.
('96', 420, 5, 23, 808844) This temporary prolongation confers no lasting benefit.
('96', 420, 5, 24, 808900) On the other hand, fasting is never intended to affect another’s body.
('96', 420, 5, 25, 808971) It must affect his heart.
('96', 420, 5, 26, 808997) Hence it is related to the soul.
('96', 420, 5, 27, 809030) And in this sense the effect, such as it is, cannot be described as temporary.
('96', 420, 5, 28, 809109) It is of a permanent character.
('96', 420, 5, 29, 809141) Whether the fasting person is spiritually fit for the task and whether he has properly applied the remedy is a different matter, irrelevant to the present purpose.
('96', 420, 5, 30, 809305) Of all the fasts of which I have recollection, of one 2 only it can be said that though there was no fault in the conception it was alloyed with external remedy with contraindication.
('96', 420, 5, 31, 809489) Had this mistake not been made, I have no doubt that its natural, beneficial result would have

('96', 431, 2, 3, 831231) [September 26, 1947] 1
('96', 431, 3, 4, 831254) GANDHIJI: Have you returned as the king of the forest or as a jackal?
('96', 431, 4, 5, 831324) SUHRAWARDY: Sir, only as a mouse.
('96', 431, 4, 6, 831358) The mouse is a very discreet creature.
('96', 431, 5, 7, 831397) GANDHIJI: Now, listen.
('96', 431, 5, 8, 831420) Once there was a lion.
('96', 431, 5, 9, 831443) He got caught in a hunter’s net.
('96', 431, 5, 10, 831476) A mouse pursued by an owl from above and a mongoose from below also ran into the net.
('96', 431, 5, 11, 831562) “You give me protection, I shall set you free,” the mouse proposed to the lion.
('96', 431, 5, 12, 831642) The lion agreed.
('96', 431, 5, 13, 831659) The bargain was struck.
('96', 431, 5, 14, 831683) The mongoose scuttled away.
('96', 431, 5, 15, 831711) But the round, shining eyes of the owl were still riveted on his prey.
('96', 431, 5, 16, 831782) “When are you going to begin?”, the lion impatiently asked the mouse.
('96', 431, 5, 17, 831852) “Where is the hurry?”, the cunning mouse replied, “I shall set you free when the hunter appears on the scene.” And instead of setting the lion free, it crouched under his fur and had a quiet nap!
('96', 431, 5, 18, 832048) The lion was furious, but what could he do?
('96', 431, 5, 19, 832092) When the hunter appeared on the scene, the mouse unhurriedly gnawed at the net strings and before the enraged lion could do anything, away the cunning creature scuttled for its own hole.
('96', 431, 5, 20, 832279) You know ‘wily whiskers’ is a very treacherous creature.
('96', 431, 5, 21, 832336) It bites you unawares while you are asleep.
('96', 431, 5, 22, 832380) It is only when the blood comes out that you know of its presence.
('96', 431, 5, 23, 832447) Is that how you are going to act?
('96', 431, 6, 24, 832481) SUHRAWARDY: Sir, you know everything.
('96', 431, 6, 25, 832519) So what can I say?

('96', 432, 2, 7, 833268) He is a big vaidya.
('96', 432, 2, 8, 833288) As he narrated his tale he burst into tears.
('96', 432, 2, 9, 833333) He agreed that in the light of the training he had received from me he should have laid down his life there.
('96', 432, 2, 10, 833442) But he confessed he had not the courage to do so.
('96', 432, 2, 11, 833492) He told me that he had always respected me and felt that what I said was the only right thing.
('96', 432, 2, 12, 833587) But it was a different matter following truth in practice.
('96', 432, 2, 13, 833646) He said the truth was that he was not able to carry it out in practice.
('96', 432, 2, 14, 833718) He was prepared to go back if I said so.
('96', 432, 2, 15, 833759) I told him that if we were convinced that we could never expect justice at the hands of the Pakistan Government and if they did not admit their mistakes then we had our own Cabinet which included Jawaharlal, Sardar Patel and many other good men.
('96', 432, 2, 16, 834005) If even they cannot stop the Pakistan Government from indulging in those things, then ultimately they would have to resort to war.
('96', 432, 2, 17, 834136) Let us arrive at a mutual and friendly settlement.
('96', 432, 2, 18, 834187) Why can we not do so?
('96', 432, 2, 19, 834209) We Hindus and Muslims were friends till yesterday.
('96', 432, 2, 20, 834260) Have we become such enemies today that we cannot trust one another?
('96', 432, 2, 21, 834328) If you say that you are never going to trust them, then the two sides would have to fight.
('96', 432, 2, 22, 834419) Speaking in terms of logic it may be asked what else would people do when they have army and police and are forced to depend on them?
('96', 432, 2, 23, 834553) If they decide to kill two persons for every person killes in Pakistan, who would care for whom?
('96', 432, 2, 24, 834650) If we want to have justice, let me tell you the matter does not lie with you or me.
('96', 432, 2, 25, 834734) It is the function of the Government.
('96', 432, 2, 26, 834772) Tell the Government, it is there to help us.
('96', 432, 2, 27, 834817) We should not take the offensive.
('96', 432, 2, 28, 834851) But we must be ready to fight, because when war comes it does not come after giving a warning.
('96', 432, 2, 29, 834946) We should not take any initiative to fight, but if the other side takes the initiative, both the Governments face their doom.
('96', 432, 2, 30, 835072) War is no joke.
('96', 432, 2, 31, 835088) After all, how long can I go on stressing the point?
('96', 432, 2, 32, 835141) But if there is no settlement between the two sides, there would be no alternative.
('96', 432, 2, 33, 835225) In that event, if all the Hindus have to die fighting, I would not be sorry.
('96', 432, 2, 34, 835302) But we have to choose the path of justice.
('96', 432, 2, 35, 835345) I would not bother if all the Hindus and all the Muslims have to die following that path.

('96', 433, 2, 28, 837320) Whoever wants to live in India, whether Hindu, Sikh, Parsi, Christian, will have to fight and die for India.
('96', 433, 2, 29, 837429) If all the Indians would lay down their lives for the country, no power could defeat us or push us back, irrespective of the army we may or may not have.

('96', 434, 7, 13, 838433) Your letter of 26th September arrived here yesterday from the Navajivan Office.

('96', 434, 7, 15, 838575) You may consult Sardar Patel.
('96', 434, 7, 16, 838605) It is he who is in charge of the affairs dealing with the rulers and the subjects.

('96', 435, 2, 3, 838967) APPENDIX I LORD MOUNTBATTEN’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW WITH GANDHIJI 1
('96', 435, 3, 4, 839031) July 9, 1947
('96', 435, 4, 5, 839044) I think and hope that I have satisfactorily cleared up the misunderstanding
('96', 435, 5, 6, 839120) referred to in his letter of the 27/28th June, 1947. I told him that my sole object up to
('96', 435, 6, 7, 839210) 15th August was to ensure a peaceful and efficient transfer of power to the two
('96', 435, 7, 8, 839290) Dominions in accordance with the will of the people of India and their respective
('96', 435, 8, 9, 839372) future Governments.
('96', 435, 8, 10, 839392) He next raised with me the fear which he had expressed
('96', 435, 9, 11, 839447) consistently in his recent post prayer meetings that the British would leave a legacy
('96', 435, 10, 12, 839533) of war, and that the partitioned armies would be left in a state in which there was every
('96', 435, 11, 13, 839623) likelihood that they would be used for making war on each other.
('96', 435, 12, 14, 839688) 2. I told him that of course I shared his view that nothing should be left
('96', 435, 13, 15, 839763) undone which would ensure the removal of the threat of war between two
('96', 435, 14, 16, 839834) neighbouring members of the British Commonwealth.
('96', 435, 15, 17, 839884) 3. I told him in confidence that Lord Ismay was this day seeing the
('96', 435, 16, 18, 839952) British Chiefs of Staff to discuss the future Commonwealth defence arrangements with
('96', 435, 17, 19, 840037) particular reference to India.
('96', 435, 17, 20, 840068) While I could not prophesy what would be the outcome of
('96', 435, 18, 21, 840124) those discussions, I hoped that they would result in defence discussions between the
('96', 435, 19, 22, 840209) United Kingdom, Pakistan and India taking place after the 15th August and before
('96', 435, 20, 23, 840290) 31st March.
('96', 435, 21, 24, 840302) 4. I pointed out that the institution of the Joint Defence Council, which
('96', 435, 22, 25, 840376) would last until at least that date, would remove all risk of war before that date, and
('96', 435, 23, 26, 840464) that this gave us eight months in which to arrange some form of agreement which
('96', 435, 24, 27, 840544) would reduce the chances of the two countries fighting each other.
('96', 435, 25, 28, 840611) 5. I pointed out that the greatest guarantee for the future peace of the Indian
('96', 435, 26, 29, 840691) Sub Continent lay in both nations remaining members of the British
('96', 435, 27, 30, 840758) Commonwealth.
('96', 435, 27, 31, 840772) He reproved me for using the word ‘nations’ and invited me to use
('96', 435, 28, 32, 840838) States or Countries instead.
('96', 435, 29, 33, 840867) 6. I further pointed out that so long as Pakistan and India remained within
('96', 435, 30, 34, 840943) the Commonwealth, there was no reason why a Commonwealth Conference should
('96', 435, 31, 35, 841018) not be called to Delhi since this was the most central capital in the whole
('96', 435, 32, 36, 841094) Commonwealth, and at such a meeting arrangements could be discussed which would
('96', 435, 33, 37, 841174) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 9 7 1947.
('96', 436, 0, 1, 841218) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 437
('96', 436, 1, 2, 841264) ensure other members of the Commonwealth devising means to prevent Pakistan and
('96', 436, 2, 3, 841344) India from making war on each other.
('96', 436, 3, 4, 841381) 7. We next discussed the question of the Indian States.
('96', 436, 3, 5, 841437) He asked me to do
('96', 436, 4, 6, 841455) everything in my power to ensure that the British did not leave a legacy of
('96', 436, 5, 7, 841531) Balkanization and disruption on the 15th August by encouraging the States to declare
('96', 436, 6, 8, 841616) their independence, or by leaving the arrangements between the States and the
('96', 436, 7, 9, 841694) Dominions of India and Pakistan in a state of chaos.
('96', 436, 8, 10, 841747) 8. He further went on and said that H. E. H.’s decision about Berar returning
('96', 436, 9, 11, 841825) to the Nizam was a crime.
('96', 436, 10, 12, 841851) 9. I told him that I had already invited H. E. H.’s representatives to meet me
('96', 436, 11, 13, 841930) on the 11th to discuss the questions of Berar and Secunderabad.
('96', 436, 11, 14, 841994) I told him that on the
('96', 436, 12, 15, 842017) 25th July all States including Hyderabad would send representatives to discuss the
('96', 436, 13, 16, 842100) stand still agreement, and I hoped also the terms under which they would join one or
('96', 436, 14, 17, 842185) the other dominion.
('96', 436, 15, 18, 842205) 10. I told him that since Pandit Nehru had authorized me to negotiate in the
('96', 436, 16, 19, 842282) first instance alone with the States’ representatives on the basis of their being
('96', 436, 17, 20, 842364) granted full membership of the dominion on adhering only to the three Central
('96', 436, 18, 21, 842442) subjects mentioned in the Cabinet Mission Plan, I felt very hopeful of being able to
('96', 436, 19, 22, 842527) bring in almost every State including even Travancore.
('96', 436, 20, 23, 842582) 11. I made it a condition however that no leaders must make any more
('96', 436, 21, 24, 842651) threatening or provocative speeches.
('96', 436, 22, 25, 842688) 12. I told Mr. Gandhi “You always talk about wooing people, and yet in the
('96', 436, 23, 26, 842763) case of the States you threaten.
('96', 436, 23, 27, 842796) Would you woo a girl you wanted to marry with a stick
('96', 436, 24, 28, 842850) and expect her to accept?” He laughed and admitted the truth of this statement, and
('96', 436, 25, 29, 842934) said he would make no statements that would embarrass my negotiations.

('96', 436, 30, 35, 843162) July 29, 1947
('96', 436, 31, 36, 843176) I explained that I had called this meeting to consider Pandit Nehru’s projected
('96', 436, 32, 37, 843256) visit to Kashmir.
('96', 436, 32, 38, 843274) I recalled the history of this affair from the time I arrived, and said
('96', 436, 33, 39, 843346) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 29 7 1947. Jawaharlal Nehru and Vallabhbhai Patel also were present.
('96', 437, 0, 1, 843449) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 437, 1, 2, 843491) that Pandit Nehru had from the very beginning repeatedly expressed to me his strong
('96', 437, 2, 3, 843575) desire to visit Kashmir which I understood was based on the incidents that occurred
('96', 437, 3, 4, 843659) there during the visit of the Cabinet Mission last year.
('96', 437, 3, 5, 843716) I expressed sincere sympathy
('96', 437, 4, 6, 843745) with Pandit Nehru’s mental distress at having been unable to keep his promise to
('96', 437, 5, 7, 843826) visit his friends in Kashmir and endeavour to effect the release of Sheikh Abdulla.
('96', 437, 6, 8, 843910) I reminded the meeting that it had been agreed that Mr. Gandhi should visit
('96', 437, 7, 9, 843986) Kashmir in place of Pandit Nehru if this was generally thought to be a better solution
('96', 437, 8, 10, 844073) : and I took the full blame for having delayed this visit by offering to go myself to
('96', 437, 9, 11, 844159) Kashmir.
('96', 437, 9, 12, 844168) I repeated my regret at having been unable to discuss the release of Sheikh
('96', 437, 10, 13, 844244) Abdulla with the Maharaja on the last day of my visit owing to His Highness’s
('96', 437, 11, 14, 844322) indisposition.
('96', 437, 11, 15, 844337) I admitted having asked Mr. Gandhi to wait until the arrival of the
('96', 437, 12, 16, 844405) Prime Minister of Kashmir, Pandit Kak.
('96', 437, 12, 17, 844444) But I said I was at a loss to understand how,
('96', 437, 13, 18, 844490) consequent on Pandit Kak’s visit to both Mr. Gandhi and Pandit Nehru to ask neither
('96', 437, 14, 19, 844574) of them to go, the result should have been that Pandit Nehru wished to go instead of
('96', 437, 15, 20, 844659) Mr. Gandhi.
('96', 437, 16, 21, 844671) Whatever Pandit Nehru’s personal emotions might be, I felt I should be failing
('96', 437, 17, 22, 844750) in my duty if I did not point our that this was hardly the time for the Vice President of
('96', 437, 18, 23, 844840) the Interim Government and the Prime Minister of the Dominion Government which
('96', 437, 19, 24, 844919) was to take over power in 17 days, to leave the capital on what really amounted to
('96', 437, 20, 25, 845002) almost private business; at all events on a visit which it would be extremely difficult
('96', 437, 21, 26, 845090) to explain away to world opinion.
('96', 437, 22, 27, 845124) I also pointed out that a visit by any Congress leaders could not fail to be
('96', 437, 23, 28, 845201) badly received in the world Press just at the time it was known that Kashmir had the
('96', 437, 24, 29, 845286) choice of Pakistan or India before its Ruler; but that this effect would be somewhat
('96', 437, 25, 30, 845371) mitigated if Mr. Gandhi went on account of the religious aura that surrounded
('96', 437, 26, 31, 845449) him, whereas if Pandit Nehru went it would be regarded as a piece of straightforward
('96', 437, 27, 32, 845534) political lobbying.
('96', 437, 28, 33, 845554) Mr. Gandhi agreed with what I had said, and stated that although at Mr. Kak’s
('96', 437, 29, 34, 845632) request he had agreed not to go, if I seriously regarded Pandit Nehru’s proposed visit
('96', 437, 30, 35, 845719) as objectionable, he would himself be prepared once more to take his place.
('96', 437, 31, 36, 845795) Sardar Patel gave it as his view that neither of them should go, but that in view
('96', 437, 32, 37, 845877) of Pandit Nehru’s great mental distress if his mission in Kashmir were to remain
('96', 437, 33, 38, 845958) unfulfilled, he agreed that one of them must go.
('96', 437, 33, 39, 846007) He very bluntly remarked : “It is a
('96', 437, 34, 40, 846043) choice between two evils and I consider that Gandhiji’s visit would be the lesser
('96', 437, 36, 41, 846125) Pandit Nehru held forth at some length about his mental distress and defended
('96', 438, 0, 1, 846203) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 439
('96', 438, 1, 2, 846249) his visit on the grounds that (A) nothing would be more natural than that Congress
('96', 438, 2, 3, 846332) should send a high level emissary to lay before the Government of Kashmir the
('96', 438, 3, 4, 846410) advantages of joining the Dominion of India, and (B) that it was well known that he
('96', 438, 4, 5, 846494) was over worked, that he would like to go away for three or four days’ rest somewhere
('96', 438, 5, 6, 846580) in any case, and that Kashmir would be a delightful place in which to have a brief
('96', 438, 6, 7, 846663) holiday.
('96', 438, 6, 8, 846672) The fact that he might be engaged on local work would be a sufficient change
('96', 438, 7, 9, 846749) of occupation to give him the necessary rest.
('96', 438, 8, 10, 846795) The rest of us each argued in turn with Pandit Nehru and finally Mr. Gandhi
('96', 438, 9, 11, 846871) specifically renewed his offer to go provided Pandit Nehru would accept that offer,
('96', 438, 10, 12, 846955) which he urged him to do since Sardar Patel and I, who were the two “outside”
('96', 438, 11, 13, 847033) members of the party, were so strongly in favour of Gandhi’s going.
('96', 438, 12, 14, 847101) Finally it was agreed that Mr. Gandhi should leave on the following night
('96', 438, 13, 15, 847175) train via Rawalpindi and that I would send telegrams to the Resident in Kashmir and
('96', 438, 14, 16, 847259) the Governor of the Punjab.

('96', 438, 21, 24, 847466) I spoke to him about the increasing tendency of responsible leaders and
('96', 438, 22, 25, 847538) Ministers to become communal in outlook.
('96', 438, 22, 26, 847579) He agreed that his was so.
('96', 438, 23, 27, 847606) I told him that I thought that only the Prime Minister himself was completely
('96', 438, 24, 28, 847684) free from the taint of communalism.
('96', 438, 24, 29, 847720) Maulana Azad, for a Muslim, was of course
('96', 438, 25, 30, 847762) remarkably free of bias; though it must be remembered that he was in a peculiar
('96', 438, 26, 31, 847842) situation.
('96', 438, 26, 32, 847853) I did not know whether Kidwai could be regarded as quite free, though he
('96', 438, 27, 33, 847926) had shown no signs of communalism.
('96', 438, 27, 34, 847961) Matthai and Rajkumari still seemed fairly free;
('96', 438, 28, 35, 848009) but Bhabha was a disappointment since he had been selected specially as Chairman of
('96', 438, 29, 36, 848093) the Delhi Emergency Committee not only for his business efficiency and strong
('96', 438, 30, 37, 848171) personality, but because as a Parsee he should be non communal.
('96', 438, 30, 38, 848235) I was informed,
('96', 438, 31, 39, 848251) however, that in the last two days he appeared to have gone completely communal.

('96', 439, 1, 2, 848581) I told Mr. Gandhi that it was not a bit of good preaching to the people unless
('96', 439, 2, 3, 848660) he had converted the leaders; and I urged him to devote his full energy towards
('96', 439, 3, 4, 848740) keeping the leaders, and particularly the Deputy Prime Minister, as straight as
('96', 439, 4, 5, 848820) possible.
('96', 439, 5, 6, 848830) Mr. Gandhi said he entirely agreed with every word I had spoken; that he
('96', 439, 6, 7, 848903) already knew it, and that he was interested to see that I had summed up the position so
('96', 439, 7, 8, 848991) correctly.
('96', 439, 8, 9, 849002) He promised to do his very best, and offered never to mention my name in this
('96', 439, 9, 10, 849080) matter or that we had these conversations.
('96', 439, 10, 11, 849123) He complained bitterly about the wording of Mr. Jinnah’s appeal for money,
('96', 439, 11, 12, 849198) since it was apparently intended only to help Muslims wherever they might be and
('96', 439, 12, 13, 849279) not the people of Pakistan.
('96', 439, 12, 14, 849307) He asked me if I could take this up with Mr. Jinnah
('96', 439, 13, 15, 849359) personally, and I told him I did not feel I should be right in doing this, but I would ask
('96', 439, 14, 16, 849450) Lord Ismay to take it up the next time he visited Karachi.
