('96', 439, 21, 24, 849691) Mr. Gandhi broke in with a wise observation.
('96', 439, 21, 25, 849736) He pointed out that the mere
('96', 439, 22, 26, 849765) refutation of Pandit Kunzru’s remarks 2, particularly by Nehru (who was now suspect
('96', 439, 23, 27, 849849) for not being sufficiently communal on the Hindu/Sikh side) or by himself (whose
('96', 439, 24, 28, 849930) remarks were becoming more and more obnoxious to the people of India), would not
('96', 439, 25, 29, 850011) effect the main purpose we had in mind of checking the spread of this anti British
('96', 439, 26, 30, 850094) feeling among Indians.
('96', 439, 27, 31, 850117) He therefore considered it of overriding importance that Pandit Kunzru should
('96', 439, 28, 32, 850195) be immediately recalled to Delhi; should be confronted with his statement; should be
('96', 439, 29, 33, 850280) asked to substantiate it; and, on failing to do so, should be called upon to make an
('96', 439, 30, 34, 850365) unqualified apology and unhesitating withdrawal.
('96', 439, 30, 35, 850414) This would have a really profound
('96', 439, 31, 36, 850448) effect as in the Gokhale case of 1896.
('96', 439, 32, 37, 850487) 1 As recorded by Lord Mountbatten; vide “Interview with J. B. Kripalani”, 25 9 1947. 2 Criticizing British officers
('96', 440, 0, 1, 850603) VOL. 96 : 7 JULY, 1947 26 SEPTEMBER, 1947 441
('96', 440, 1, 2, 850649) Mr. Gandhi suggested that Gen.
('96', 440, 1, 3, 850680) Thimayya should either see Pandit Kunzru, in
('96', 440, 2, 4, 850725) view of their friendship and the unique position he was in to convince him of the
('96', 440, 3, 5, 850807) truth; or at the very least should leave a full personal letter behind for him to read.
('96', 440, 4, 6, 850895) Pandit Nehru here pointed out a complication, in that Pandit Kunzru was really
('96', 440, 5, 7, 850974) attacking the whole of the present Government and not merely the British; and that it
('96', 440, 6, 8, 851060) might be difficult to separate the two.
('96', 440, 6, 9, 851100) I, however, urged that the British case was the
('96', 440, 7, 10, 851148) more pressing and that it should be grappled with strength at this moment.
('96', 440, 8, 11, 851223) Mr. Gandhi went on to say that he was perfectly prepared to support this line
('96', 440, 9, 12, 851301) at the proper moment by elaborating it in his post prayer meeting discussions.
('96', 440, 10, 13, 851380) also offered to see Mr. Birla (his present host), who owned The Hindustan Times, and
('96', 440, 11, 14, 851465) to talk to his son, Devdas Gandhi, the editor, to try and ensure that in the mean while
('96', 440, 12, 15, 851553) the right line was taken up in this newspaper.
('96', 440, 12, 16, 851600) I urged that he should also invite his
('96', 440, 13, 17, 851639) son to use his influence with the editor of the Indian News Chronicle.
('96', 440, 13, 18, 851710) Mr. Gandhi
('96', 440, 14, 19, 851721) said that he thought Sahni had left, but no doubt his son would be able to make
('96', 440, 15, 20, 851801) contact with the new editor.
('96', 440, 16, 21, 851830) The rest of the party then left, and I remained alone with Mr. Gandhi.
('96', 440, 17, 22, 851901) He told me that the time had come when I must consider what action
('96', 440, 18, 23, 851968) I should take to help in the present position if I did not wish to bury my own
('96', 440, 19, 24, 852047) reputation and even the reputation of the British here in India where at present it
('96', 440, 20, 25, 852131) stood so high.
('96', 440, 21, 26, 852146) So far as I could make out his idea was that I should telegraph to Mr. Attlee in
('96', 440, 22, 27, 852227) my personal capacity as an Englishman and say that the British Commonwealth
('96', 440, 23, 28, 852303) should not hesitate to expel any member of that Commonwealth which could be
('96', 440, 24, 29, 852379) proved guilty of sharp practice and which intended to make war on another member.
('96', 440, 25, 30, 852461) He was not saying this against Pakistan, for the rest of the Commonwealth
('96', 440, 26, 31, 852535) might come to the conclusion that it was India, though he himself felt certain that
('96', 440, 27, 32, 852619) they would not.
('96', 440, 28, 33, 852635) He did not see how the rest of the Commonwealth could support two members
('96', 440, 29, 34, 852709) in their midst which were drifting towards a stage that sooner or later might mean war.
('96', 440, 30, 35, 852797) For instance, he considered that it was most unfortunate that Sir Francis
('96', 440, 31, 36, 852871) Mudie, Sir George Cunningham and Sir Frederick Bourne should be Governors of
('96', 440, 32, 37, 852948) Pakistan provinces at this time.
('96', 440, 33, 38, 852981) I asked him whether he believed Nishtar, Ghazanfar Ali and Chundrigar would
('96', 440, 34, 39, 853057) prove a greater deterrent to war if they had been Governors.
('96', 440, 35, 40, 853118) To my surprise Mr. Gandhi replied that he would prefer to see them as
('96', 440, 36, 41, 853188) Governors now, for then the full duplicity and hostile intent of Pakistan would stand
('96', 441, 0, 1, 853274) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('96', 441, 1, 2, 853316) revealed in all its nakedness, whereas now they were covering up their intentions
('96', 441, 2, 3, 853398) behind a facade of honourable British Governors.
('96', 441, 3, 4, 853447) I said I assumed that Mr. Gandhi quite understood that in the event of a war
('96', 441, 4, 5, 853524) between the Dominions, British officers would be withdrawn from both Dominions
('96', 441, 5, 6, 853603) immediately, since they could hardly be expected to fight each other.
('96', 441, 5, 7, 853673) I further
('96', 441, 6, 8, 853683) pointed out that this sanction acted 90 per cent against Pakistan, for it was they who
('96', 441, 7, 9, 853770) were short of senior officers and administrators and it was they who would be crippled
('96', 441, 8, 10, 853857) by the removal of the British; whereas in India, though in my opinion they would
('96', 441, 9, 11, 853938) lose great efficiency, they would not be crippled in the same way.
('96', 441, 9, 12, 854005) Mr. Gandhi agreed.
('96', 441, 10, 13, 854024) I told Mr. Gandhi I could not possibly communicate with Mr. Attlee behind
('96', 441, 11, 14, 854098) Pandit Nehru’s back and I would require to show him what I proposed to send and
('96', 441, 12, 15, 854178) would need his full approval.
('96', 441, 13, 16, 854208) “Ah!”, said Mr. Gandhi, “I am afraid you may have difficulty there; for though I
('96', 441, 14, 17, 854289) agree you must do that, he has already refused to accept my suggestion of including
('96', 441, 15, 18, 854373) this proposal in his reply to the Prime Minister on the question of the Pakistan
('96', 441, 16, 19, 854454) telegrams to the Commonwealth.”
('96', 441, 17, 20, 854486) I now felt we were in such deep water, and the point was so very unclear, and as
('96', 441, 18, 21, 854567) the time was now past 2 p.
('96', 441, 18, 22, 854594) m., that it was better to let him go and ask him to put up
('96', 441, 19, 23, 854653) his proposals in writing to me, which he promised to do.
